business.start.para: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Sir Alister McMullin) took the chair at 3 p.m., and read prayers.

talk.start.para: - Is the

speech.para: Leader of the Government in the Senate aware that today is 9th May? Is he also aware that this is a day of considerable significance to the Australian Parliament? Does he recall that sixty-six years ago today the First Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia was opened' in Melbourne by the Queen's personal representative? Does he further recall that forty years ago today the Commonwealth Parliament assembled in Canberra for the first time? As such a day passes almost unnoticed by the majority of people in Australia, will the Minister ask his colleagues in the Ministry to consider the desirability of commemorating the events to which I have referred, particularly among the school children in the various States and more especially in Canberra?

talk.start.para: - The honourable senator has been studying history a little more closely than I have. I was aware that forty years ago today the Commonwealth Parliament assembled in Canberra for the first time, because the Prime Minister referred to that event in King's Hall today during the presentation of two magnificent chairs by the Returned Services League to the Australian Parliament. He mentioned that this was the fiftieth anniversary of the League and also the fortieth anniversary of the first sitting of the Parliament in Canberra. So 1 was aware of that part of our history. In regard to the rest of the honourable senators question, it' he puts it on the notice paper I will see what information I can obtain for him from the Prime Minister.

- My question, which is directed to you, Mr President, is supplementary to the one that Senator Hendrickson has just asked. Do you intend to take any action by way of the publication that is available at the front door to draw the attention of the very large number of people who visit Parliament House to the fact that today is the fortieth anniversary

speech.para: of the first sitting of the Commonwealth Parliament in Canberra?

talk.start.para: - I have had discussions with Mr Speaker about the reprinting of the booklet to which Senator Branson referred, lt has tremendous sales and plays a very important part in the school life and studies of children. 1 believe that the booklet should be reprinted. I agree that this would be a suitable time to pay respect to the fortieth anniversary of the opening of the Commonwealth Parliament in Canberra.

- 1 ask the Minister representing the Minister for Shipping and Transport a question. Can he give the Government's reasons for briefing a firm of private engineers, namely, Maunsell and Partners, to prepare a report on the whole of the work remaining to be done on the standard gauge railway in Western Australia?

- 1 sought this information, and I am able to say that since the inception of the railway agreement with Western Australia in 1961 Maunsell and Partners had been employed by the Western Australian Government Railways as consulting engineers. The agreement was based on developmental as well as standardisation work, but did not set out all details of the work to be carried out under these two headings. By .1965 it became apparent that the original estimate of SS2,400,000 would be considerably exceeded. It was necessary to have a comprehensive and detailed master plan of the remainder of the works and a reliable estimate of the total cost to be met on the project. At the request of the Commonwealth and with the approval of the State Government, Maunsell and Partners carried out this task. The State and Commonwealth Governments are examining the report at the present time.

- I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate a question without notice. If the referendum to be held on 27th May to break the nexus between the two Houses of the Parliament is carried, does the Government propose an initial increase of thirteen members in the size of the House of Representatives? Further, what would be the approximate cost to the people each year of supporting thirteen additional members of the House of Representatives, including the cost of such factors as salary, parliamentary allowances, transport, secretarial assistance, office accommodation, stationery and telephone expenses?

- 1 am sure the honourable senator would not expect me to have at hand all the details that he has asked for. I suggest that if he puts his question on notice I shall do my best to obtain for him all the costs and details to which he has referred.

- I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer whether it is a fact that Mr J. A. Keely, counsel for the Commonwealth in the national wage hearing in Melbourne, has opposed the claim for wage increases on the ground that inflationary pressures would result. Does the Government have any other plans in mind to arrest inflationary trends, or is it intended that the wage earning community should shoulder the entire burden?

- The honourable senator has raised a very interesting question. He has mentioned the economy of this country. Of course, over the sixteen or seventeen years during which the present Government has been in office, the economy has been stable. Indeed, any government could be proud of the development that has taken place throughout the Commonwealth as well as the increase in real wages in comparison with costs. In regard to the details asked for by the honourable senator, I suggest that he place his question on the notice paper. It should really go to the Minister for Labour and National Service, for I believe this matter is more in his field. However, if the honourable senator places his question on the notice paper I shall see what answer I can get for him.

- I ask the Minister for Education and Science: What restriction has been forced on the proposed construc tion of new buildings at the University of Tasmania by any reduction in funds to be provided in the new triennium by the Commonwealth Government? Will any aspect of Commonwealth policy in respect of finance for universities inhibit plans already agreed upon for buildings and equipment for the new medical school at the University of Tasmania? If the answer to my second question is yes, is there any way in which the original plans can be adhered to in view of the fact that any curtailment of original buildings would have long term disadvantages to the proper and required development of this new medical school?

- The amount recommended by the Australian Universities Commission for the University of Tasmania over the triennium was, I think, $2,106,000. The amount actually granted was $ 1,900,000-odd, which was the upper limit suggested by the State Government for those buildings. From those figures the honourable senator may see the reduction in the whole programme. Two recommendations were made by the Commission in respect of buildings for medical purposes. One was for the completion of the medical sciences building. The recommendation was that $70,000 should be allocated in respect of that building and S70,000 is being allocated in respect of that building; there has been no reduction. The other recommendation was for an animal house for the medical sciences building. The recommendation was that $58,000 be provided and in fact $50,000 has been provided. 1 point out, too, to the honourable senator that recommendations for the provision of amounts totalling $1,560,000 for teaching hospitals in respect of that university were made and the university is getting $1,560,000. So I do not see how it can be said that there is any curtailment other than in respect of $8,000 in relation to the animal house.

- I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for External Affairs. Has the Australian Government agreed to the twenty-four hours truce in Vietnam proposed by the Government of South Vietnam for 22nd May, the anniversary of the birth of Buddha? Has the Government been consulted about the proposal from the Government of North Vietnam that the duration of this truce be extended for forty-eight hours? If so, does it support the proposal? Finally, as we are one of the few nations with combat forces in Vietnam and in view of the ever mounting toll of casualties, military and civilian, will the Government assure the Senate that it will place Australia alongside the British Foreign Secretary, Mr Brown, and many other world leaders who hope that this truce will offer an opportunity for peace moves to end the war?

- I am not in a position to tell the honourable senator whether the Department of External Affairs has been approached by the Government of South Vietnam on the matter of a twentyfour hours truce. If he wishes me to do so. 1 shall seek to get the information from that Department for him. In relation to the other part of his question, the Australian Government has made it perfectly clear that it will back and support any moves for a peace in Vietnam, provided that peace is one which protects the rights of the individual in South Vietnam and is a peace which will be just and enduring. That is a requirement for a continuing peace.

- Is the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Industry aware that a deadlock has been reached in negotiations between the Tasmanian Pea Growers Association and the processors regarding the price to be paid for next year's crop? It is claimed that because processors' costs have increased the pea growers should take less and make up the leeway. Should this deadlock continue and not reach a solution - fears have been expressed in this direction - what are the implications regarding the New ZealandAustralia Free Trade Agreement? Will the Minister closely watch the position?

- I am aware of the position that the honourable senator mentions. I have watched it very closely, naturally enough. I think that in any dispute such as this we should start with the understanding - I am sure that both sides to the dispute have this understanding - that neither the processing industry nor the grower can do without the other. This is basic common sense. If the processing industry is to continue, it must have men who can grow the product. If the men are to grow the product, they must have a factory where it can be processed. Together, they must find an equitable price for both sides. This is a matter of dispute and negotiations are necessary in regard to it. I should like to refer the matter of the New Zealand-Australia Free Trade Agreement to the Minister for Trade and Industry because I. would not like to answer it off the cuff. Therefore I suggest to the honourable senator that he put that aspect of his question on the notice paper. At this stage I shall not add anything, because I believe that while the parties are negotiating nothing should be done to inflame the position in any way.

- I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for the Interior. Is it a fact that many Commonwealth cars used for transporting repatriation patients, leading public servants, Cabinet Ministers, rehabilitation cases and senior N.ivy, Army and Air Force personnel are not fitted with safety belts? Are the drivers and passengers of those vehicles exposed to unnecessary danger, and is the Commonwealth itself taking grave risks in terms of liability for compensation by failing to equip the vehicles with safety belts as recommended by all competent scientific authorities who have given close study to this problem? Will the Minister also say whether it is Government policy to require the use of safety belts, at least by drivers, in those vehicles which are properly equipped?

- 1 am not aware of all the facts stated by the honourable senator. 1 do know that some Commonwealth cars are fitted with safety belts but 1 do not know whether the drivers are specifically instructed to see that they are worn at all times. I will direct the remainder of the question to the Minister for the Interior.
- 1 address a question to the Minister for Supply relating to the future of the Woomera rocket range. Has the Minister any information on a report in the London 'Daily Telegraph' that

speech.para: Australian Federal Ministers were deeply concerned about the future of the Woomera rocket range? Can the Minister say whether the newspaper is correct in saying that it is doubtful whether the present arrangement under which Great Britain pays half the cost will continue?

talk.start.para: - At the moment the Government and the Department of Supply are consulting with the British authorities responsible under the arrangement for the joint financing of the Woomera rocket range and the Weapons Research Establishment at Salisbury. The negotiations are being held with a view to arriving at the terms of a further agreement. There is no further information that I can give on the matter at the moment. It is a matter for discussion between the two Departments concerned and representatives of the British Government.

- I address a question to you, Mr President, following upon a question asked by Senator Branson and the reply given to him. I am informed by the Clerk of Papers that the valuable publication 'Introduction to the Federal Parliament' which was first issued in 1956 and which contains statistics relating to the parties in the Parliament, is now out of print. I ask whether you will consider the reprinting of this booklet in an up-to-date form.

- The booklet to which the honourable senator refers was first published in 1959. I appreciate its value. I think that the time is now ripe for publishing a further up-to-date edition containing all the information that the honourable senator desires. An interesting point about the booklet is that only about 3,000 copies were printed and these have been in such great demand that it is likely that, before very long, no copies will be available. It is much sought after by libraries overseas, and the publication of the booklet with uptodate information is desirable.

- I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer whether it is a fact that in the first three months of this year new and increased lend ing commitments by the trading banks were higher than in any previous period and exceeded the level in the corresponding months of 1966 by no less than 50%. Could the Minister inform the Senate whether there has been a corresponding increase in the rural sector of bank lending?

- I have the latest figures available for new and increased lending commitments to all classes of borrowers. They are those for the six months ended January 1967. The total new lending commitments to rural businesses was $105m for the six months ended January 1966. For the six months ended January 1967, the total was $144m. I point out that between these two periods total bank lending increased substantially, and the proportion of rural lending was more than maintained. In fact, it increased from 19.5% to 20.1%. Later figures of this kind are not available, but I am sure there has been a considerable increase in the level of new trading bank lending in the rural sector in the three months since January 1967.

- I address a question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. In view of the fact that the electors of Tasmania are fast gaining the impression, through the activities of certain Government senators, that the Government does not support a Yes vote in the forthcoming referendum in that State, will the Minister indicate the steps which the Government proposes to take to correct this impression?

- The honourable senator is aware, of course, that the pamphlet setting out both cases in this referendum has just been issued and the campaign relating to the referendum is only starting. I can assure the honourable senator that in Tasmania and everywhere else those persons who agree with and support the Yes case in the referendum will be fighting vigorously in the campaign.

- In the light of my remarks on the motion for the adjournment of the Senate on Thursday night last in relation to the military takeover in Greece, can the Minister representing the Minister for External Affairs make any statement on the specific issues that I raised?

- Mr President, I am not sure of the specific issues to which the honourable senator is referring. He raised the question of Australia entering into diplomatic relations with the Greek Government. I have stated before in this place, and the Minister for External Affairs has stated before in the other House, that a country is recognised diplomatically by a government accrediting its representative to the Head of State of that country.
- But not China.

- Australia recognises the China that the United Nations recognises. Australia accredits its representative to the Head of State of China. The honourable senator makes my point for me. We accredit our representative to the Head of State of the country concerned. Then, if a government had any reason for refusing or not wishing to continue diplomatic relations with a country - for instance, if that government disapproved of the government of that other country - then that government would withdraw its representative or the accreditation to the Head of State. [ am not sure that the honourable senator believes that we should withdraw our representative because we disapprove of the Government in Greece. If that is what he is suggesting, then I do not believe this Government would do that.
- Does the Government disapprove of the Greek Government?

- I do not think that any need exists for recognition to imply approval; nor does recognition imply that a government recognises a government as a democratic government in the sense that we understand the term. Australia has just entered into diplomatic relations with the Government of Yugoslavia. I am glad that we did. But nobody could describe the Government of Yugoslavia as a democratic government in the terms that we understand it. We have continued our recognition of the Government in Ghana where, quite recently, a military takeover has occurred. We apply the test as to whether or not the government is in control of the country and is governing the country. Unless there are reasons why we should not recognise a government, then there are reasons why we should recognise a government. This does not imply, as I said, approval or that it is a democratic government. There were one or two other specific matters that the honourable senator raised concerning Greek individuals.
- Dual nationality.

- Yes. The dual nationality claims of the Greek Government are not the claims of this Greek Government only. All Greek governments have always claimed that people born in Greece and of Greek citizenship cannot divest themselves of that citizenship no matter whether they go to any other country or whether they take any other citizenship, be it American, Australian or any other. If these people return to Greece they are subject to the laws in Greece as Greek nationals. That has been the continuing claim of the Greek Government. If there were some particular individual cases concerning Greeks with Australian citizenship who were adversely affected by that law, and if those cases were brought to the attention of the Government, the Government might inquire what was happening in those cases. But it is still the Greek claim and always has been that Greek citizenship is retained.

- I desire to ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate or the appropriate Minister a question. I preface my question by referring to the recent news item from Washington in which the United States Central Intelligence Agency acknowledged that it had been financing secretly student and other organisations over the past fifteen years. I now ask the appropriate Minister whether the Government has any knowledge of CIA moneys flowing to Australian organisations.

- To my knowledge this has not happened. However, I believe that the honourable senator would want much greater authority than mine. If he puts his question on the notice paper I shall see that he gets an answer.

- My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General or to the Leader of the Government, whichever of the two is appropriate. Is it a fact that a branch of the Ku Klux Klan has been established in

speech.para: Australia? If so, and if it is in the Minister's power to do so, will he take the necessary steps to see that this organisation does not indulge in religious and racial terror tactics as practised by the Klan in the United States of America?

talk.start.para: - I may be wrong, but I believe that the honourable senator's question is based solely on a claim by somebody in the United States that he had established a branch of the Ku Klux Klan in Australia. This was recently reported in the newspapers, but whether the man concerned made this claim I do not know. I am not aware of any establishment of the Klan in Australia. Indeed,I think members of that organisation would look awfully silly moving about the Australian countryside clad in bed sheets.I think it is highly unlikely that a branch of the Klan has been established here.

- I address my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is it a fact that Mr J. A. Keely, counsel for the Commonwealth in the national wage case currently being heard, has opposed the claim for wage increases on the ground that inflationary pressures will result from an increase? Has the Government in mind any plans to arrest the inflationary trend, or is it intended that the wage earning community as usual shall shoulder the entire burden?

- Obviously there has been some mix-up in the distribution of favours on the other side of the chamber. I have already been asked the same question. I suggest to Senator Devitt that he puthis question on notice. If he does so, I shall see that answers are given to both it and the one that I was asked a few minutes ago.

- I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration. By way of preface I refer to question No. 67 on the notice paper. I placed it on the notice paper on 8th March. It concerns the policy of the Department of Immigration. I now ask: In the absence of an answer to that ques tion upon notice, why has priority apparently been given to the supplying of answers to similar questions raised at the Public Accounts Committee hearing this week?
- I shall inquire of the Minister for Immigration concerning this matter.

- I do not want to raise this matter too frequently, but I ask honourable senators to give a little attention to the need to ask only questions that Ministers may reasonably be expected to answer at question time. This requirement ought to be observed if the best use is to be made of question time. Questions that Ministers may not reasonably be expected to answer immediately should be put on notice. When the proceedings are not being broadcast, no advantage is gained by going through the process of asking orally a question that has to be put on notice. This procedure wastes time and is an untidy way of conducting our business.
asked the Minister representing the Minister for Civil Aviation, upon notice:

item.para: On what date did Qantas Empire Airways Ltd commence its flights to Rome?
Were various newspapers and radio representatives included in the inaugural flight complement; if so, what were their names?

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Civil Aviation has supplied the following answers:

item.para: Qantas commenced its flights to Rome on 26th October 1948 as a technical stop, and on 10th June 1950 with traffic rights.
No record is available of Qantas operating an inaugural flight to Rome.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice:

item.para: What is the machinery whereby new drugs are admitted to the pharmaceutical benefits list?
From whom does the initiative come to have these drugs admitted?
What criteria are needed before a drug is accepted and what guarantees are required for a drug's value and safety?

Is it a fact that responsible members of the medical profession require that a drug shall have been widely tested and reported in responsible English language medical journals before it is released for general use in Australia?
Are there any reports in any responsible English language medical journals relating to the drug Gondafon; if so, in which journals?
Why was the drug Gondafon admitted to the pharmaceutical benefits list?

talk.start.para: - The Acting Minister for Health has furnished the Following reply:

item.para: An expert committee, known as the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee, has been established under section101 of the National Health Act. The Committee's functions include the making of recommendations to the Minister as to the drugs and medicinal preparations which it considers should be made available as pharmaceutical benefits. The National Health Act provides that no drug or medicinal preparation may be listed asa pharmaceutical benefit unless a recommendation to that effect is received from the Committee.

From the expert knowledge of its members, the Committee itself initiates considerations of the listing of drugs and medicinal preparations as pharmaceutical benefits. The Committee also receives applications for the listing of drugs and preparations, from specialist bodies such as the Australian Medical Association and the Royal Australasian College of Physicians and from medical practitioners, manufacturers and members of the public.

The Committee makes its recommendations on therapeutic grounds, taking into consideration all known properties of a drug, including its toxic effects. All drugs and medicinal preparations available us pharmaceutical benefits are tested by the National Biological Standards Laboratory to ensure that they conform to the required standards of potency and purity.
I am not in a position to answer this question.
Reports on Gondafon have been published in the following English language journals:

speech.para: British Medical Journal', of 1 8th September 1965.
Journal of the Irish Medical Association', of June 1965, and May 1966.
South African Medical Journal', of11th December 1965.
Diabetes', (American) Vol. 14, No. 2, of February 1965, and Vol. 15, No. 10. of October 1966.
British Journal of Clinical Practice', of August 1966.
Proceedings of the Endocrine Association of Australia', of August 1966.

item.para: The Minister for Health accepted a recommendation by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee that Gondafon be listed as a pharmaceutical benefit.

talk.start.para: - Question No.111 which stands in my name was placed on notice on 12th April and then concerned a future event but it will now be answered,

speech.para: I presume, inthe past tense. It is as follows:

In view of the retirement, in the very near future, of Sir William Hudson, Commissioner of the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Authority, has the Government given consideration to providing some form of recognition, by way of a testimonial dinner at Parliament House, or some other appropriate gesture of appreciation as a mark of respect and thanks for the outstanding services rendered to the nation, the Parliament and the people of Australia by this distinguished New Zealand administrator, engineer and citizen?

talk.start.para: - The Prime Minister has provided me with the following answer to the honourable senators question:

quote.para: I appreciate the honourable senator's bringing to notice the retirement of Sir William Hudson from the position of Commissioner of the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Authority and his expression of appreciation for the services which Sir William has rendered. This is a sentiment with which I am in full agreement. However, at the same time,I must add that it is not the practice of the Government, nor I understand of previous Governments, to take any formal action such as the holding of a testimonial dinner on the occasion of the retirement of any officer from either the Commonwealth Public Service or from a Commonwealth statutory authority.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice:

item.para: To what extent are the private banks of Australia owned or controlled by corporations or persons other than persons resident in Australia or corporations owned or controlled by Australian residents?
Which are the principal corporations or persons, and what is the extent of their ownership or control?

talk.start.para: - The Treasurer has supplied the following information: 1 and 2. The precise information sought is not available to me. Of the seven major private trading banks conducting business in Australia, five have their head offices in Australia and two- namely, the Australia and New Zealand Bank Ltd and The English, Scottish and Australian Bank Ltd - in London. I understand that a high proportion of the shares of the major trading banks with head offices in Australia would be held in this country, while a substantial proportion of the share capital of the two banks with head offices in London would be held outside Australia.
asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice:

item.para: Is the disposal of Australia's wheat crop proceeding satisfactorily?
What truth is there in a Press suggestion that difficulties are anticipated in disposal, with consequent problems due to shortage of storage facilities?

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

item.para: Having regard to the fact that this season's crop is almost 100 million bushels greater than the previous record of 369 million bushels in 1964-65 and that there is an exportable surplus from the crop of over 350 million bushelsI would say that the disposal of the crop is proceeding satisfactorily. In discussing the export sales programme early in April the Chairman of the Australian Wheat Board stated that good progress had already been made with sales totalling 180 million bushels.

Such is the magnitude of the crop that disposal will present a difficult task for the Australian Wheat Board and there are bound to be receival and storage problems, worse in some regions than in others. It seems to me these problems are general ly being met with resolution and efficiency, to the credit of all concerned. Overshadowing all else is, of course, the consideration that this bountiful crop not only helps the wheat industry to recover from the effects of last season's drought but also brings great benefit to the economy as a whole.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the PostmasterGeneral, upon notice:

item.para: What are the names of all commentators who have appeared on the Australian Broadcasting Commission's programme 'Let's Find Out'?
Has one of these commentators been a Miss Dita Cobb of Sydney?
On how many occasions did Miss Cobb appear on the programme?
When was the last time she appeared?
Is Miss Cobb no longer appearing on the programme? If so, why not?

talk.start.para: - The PostmasterGeneral has supplied the following answers:

item.para: The names of all the women guests who have appeared as commentators in 'Let's Find Out' are:
Yes.
Miss Cobb appeared in forty programmes.
14th March 1967.

Miss Cobb is not at present appearing on the programme. 'Let's Find Out' has only one permanent commentation, ABC staff member Ellis Blain. The programme is broadcast five times a week. The twenty-five people named above are all guests engaged for one programme at a time. No engagement form or contract has ever been offered for more than one appearance at a time. The ABC changes the panel whenever it becomes desirable to inject fresh thoughts and points of view into the programme.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice:

item.para: What is the present position regarding payments for Australian wheat sold to Mainland China by the Australian Wheat Board?
Are reports correct that some payments are overdue? If so, to what extent?

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

item.para: All payments due to date by Mainland China to the Australian Wheat Board have been made.
No.

talk.start.para: - On 5th April Senator McManus asked the following question:

quote.para: My question is directed to the Minister representing the Postmaster-General. Will he inquire into serious allegations contained in the issue of the journal 'Spotlight' of 15th March, which stated that in defiance of the Postal Regulations the names of persons renting postal boxes in Melbourne had been disclosed to unauthorised persons on a number of occasions? If the allegations are correct, what action has been taken against those responsible?

speech.para: The Postmaster-General has now furnished the following information in reply:

quote.para: Inquiries made have failed to reveal any evidence that the names of persons renting private postal boxes in Melbourne have been disclosed to unauthorised persons.

debateinfo.title: FORM OF GOVERNMENT FOR THE NORTHERN TERRITORY

talk.start.para: - by leave - I have a statement which was made in another place by the Minister for Territories (Mr Barnes) on 4th May and which deals with discussions on the form of government for the Northern Territory. With the concurrence of honourable senators, I incorporate it in Hansard. The statement is as follows:

speech.para: Talks have been taking place in Canberra this week between the Government and representatives of the Legislative Council for the Northern Territory. The Government was represented at these talks by the Minister for Territories (Mr Barnes), the Minister for National Development (Mr Fairbairn), the Attorney-General (Mr Bowen), and the Minister for Works (Mr Kelly). Messrs H. Chan, M.L.C., R. J. Withnall, M.L.C. and F. W. Drysdale, M.L.C., who are elected members, and Mr B. Kilgariff, M.L.C., a nominated nonofficial member, represented the Legislative Council. These talks were held at the request of the Legislative Council which, among other things, had sought clarification of the Government's attitude towards the functioning of the Legislative Council and the Administrator's Council for the Northern Territory. The talks provided an opportunity for a full exchange of views on both sides.

The Legislative Councillors amplified their view that the Commonwealth was exercising unduly detailed supervision over ordinances passed by the Legislative Council, and was unreasonably denying a legitimate extension of the scope of the Legislative Council and the Administrator's Council. The Ministers pointed out that of 390 ordinances passed by the Legislative Council between 1960 and 1966 there had been only nine substantive cases of rejection of whole Ordinances, or 2.3% of the total, and one case of disallowance of a single section.

The general attitude of the Commonwealth Government is that the Legislative Council and Administrator's Council are intended to provide the means by which the representatives of the Northern Territory community have the greatest possible oppor tunity to participate in the government of the Territory. At the same time, because of the dependence of the Northern Territory on financial provisions made by the Commonwealth Parliament, because of the smallness of the population and because of its importance in the future development of Australia, matters would arise from time to time on which, in order to discharge the responsibilities resting upon it, the Commonwealth Government needed to retain the right of final decision.
In the Government's view, whatever arrangements were adopted for the government of the Northern Territory, they would need to be consistent with the following principles:
Final authority of government has to be related to financial autonomy.
The responsibility for taking executive decisions cannot be separated from the responsibility for carrying out those decisions.

Other than in areas of special concern to the Commonwealth, the Commonwealth will not normally intervene in decisions of the Legislative Council or the acceptance of advice of the Administrator's Council. So long as the financial, administrative and political resources of the Territory provide an insufficient basis for effective government the Commonwealth cannot divest itself of final authority in areas of special concern to it. Within those special areas it will give full weight to the views of the Legislative Council and of the Administrator's Council in its consultative role.

In the present stage of Territory development, executive and legislative power, if exercised by Northern Territory institutions without Commonwealth surveillance, must be defined on a very limited scale to accord with the practical situation. On the other hand participation in government by Territory elected representatives need not be so narrowly limited if that participation takes place with recognition that a measure of surveillance by the Commonwealth is part of the basic constitutional and practical position.
There are no barriers to the extension of local government.

The Legislative Councillors stressed that their approach was a responsible one and maintained that on many issues they would be the best judges of which course would best serve the Territory's interests. It was agreed that there was scope, without statutory change, for extension of consultation in the Administrator's Council on a variety of matters of Northern Territory concern. The Ministers agreed that ways of putting this into practical effect would be examined. The following comments apply to specific matters raised by Legislative Councillors:

The Ministers would give further consideration to representations for the replacement of the three nominated nonofficial members of the Legislative Council by elected members. The Ministers pointed out that the present structure of the Legislative Council provided a careful balance between the eight elected members, the six official members, and the three non-official members. Any change which disturbed that balance would need to provide means by which there would be reasonable opportunity for the Executive to secure passage of necessary official legislation.

Continuation of membership of the Administrator's Council of a nominated non-official member was linked with the question of continuation of nominated non-official membership of the Legislative Council.

Ordinances which may be passed by the Legislative Council to enlarge the statutory range of matters referred to the Administrator's Council would be considered sympathetically. There had in the last few years been a substantial enlargement of that range. Nevertheless, there were matters on which the Commonwealth could be expected to maintain its full executive authority.

In the light of present opportunities for elected and non-official members of the Administrator's Council to have matters discussed by that Council, no alteration in present statutory arrangements was considered by Ministers to be warranted. As stated above, it was intended that an extension of consultation in the Administrator's Council under existing statutory provisions would be arranged.

The Legislative Councillors maintained that there was particular injustice in denial of full voting rights to the Northern Territory Member of the House of Representatives in the light of the Government's insistence on retention of ultimate authority on Territory matters and the withholding from the Legislative Council of powers of appropriation. The Ministers agreed to recommend that full voting rights should be accorded to the Northern Territory member after the next Federal elections.

The Ministers reiterated that the Government attached importance to the extension and growth of local government in the Territory. The Legislative Councillors stated that they noted with satisfaction the proposal to recommend that the member for the Northern Territory should have an unlimited voting right in the House of Representatives. As to the Minister's expressed intention to consider the representations for the abolition of the offices of nominated non-official members, Councillors noted this intention but did not accept that any such action should be accompanied by any subtraction from the present authority of the Legislative Council. As to the other proposals brought forward for discussion Councillors expressed dissatisfaction with the attitude of the Ministers that no extension of the statutory authority of the Legislative Council and Administrator's Council in the administration of government in the Northern Territory will be considered. They agreed that consultation can be useful but is no substitute for direct participation in the affairs of local concern. They considered that the Ministers in these talks had shown little, if any, intention to relax the tight control over the details of administration, and forecast that continuance in this attitude will result in increasing dissatisfaction amongst the people of the Territory. The Legislative Councillors expressed regret that the Ministers had shown so little understanding of the situation in the Northern Territory as to meet their proposals for legislative reform of the organs of government in the Territory with little more than an elaborate refusal.

The Ministers considered that the views expressed by the Legislative Councillors did not sufficiently acknowledge the extent of real influence they have on the government of the Territory under present arrangements, which, in the view of the Ministers are working reasonably well. The Ministers considered it fundamental that the Commonwealth must have the final responsibility at this stage of the Territory's development, but they expressed the hope that the people of the Territory would have an increasing voice and influence.

Consideration of House of Representatives message.

item.label: (ii)

debate.para: After paragraph (b) in the definition of " eligible organization" insert "and (ba) a trade union registered under a law of the Commonwealth or of a State,".
Reasons of the House of Representatives for disagreeing to the amendment of the

quote.para: Because:

A trade union is in no different position to any other organisation that does not fall within paragraph (a) of the definition of eligible organisation. There is no more reason why a trade union should be selected for specific mention in a separate paragraph than there is for other organisations such as the Country Women's Association, Rotary Clubs, Lions Clubs, Apex Clubs or associations of employers. It would be open to any of these organisations including a tradeunion to establish a trust for charitable or benevolent purposes such as the conduct of an aged persons home, and have that trust approved by the GovernorGeneral for the purposes of the Act. The trustee or trustees of the trust would then be an eligible organisation under paragraph (e) of the definition.
Alternatively a trade turton could be approved by the Governor-Genera, under sub-paragraph (iv) of paragraph (a) if it was not carried on for the purpose of profit or gain to its individual members.
That the Committee do not insist on the amendment disagreed to by the House of Representatives.

speech.para: The House of Representatives has disagreed to the Senate's amendment to the Bill for reasons which have been circulated to honourable senators. Those reasons, in substance, are the same as those that I advanced previously, during the debate on the amendment in this chamber.

The Government takes the view that the amendment is unnecessary, since the legislation before the Senate permits the participation by a trade union in the scheme. Much has been said previously in this chamber about whether trade unions are organisations the principal objects of which are charitable or benevolent. I should like once more to attempt to make the position perfectly clear. If a trade union is carried on otherwise than for the purposes of profit or gain to its individual members, and is an organisation the principal objects of which are charitable or benevolent, it could be admitted under paragraph (a) (ii) of the proposed definition of 'eligible organisation'. If it is carried on otherwise than for the purpose of profit or gain to its individual members but could not be regarded as an organisation the principal objects of which are charitable or benevolent, it could be admitted under paragraph (a) (iv) as an organisation approved by the GovernorGeneral for the purpose of the Act. If a trade union did not qualify under either of those sections, it could establish a trust for charitable or benevolent purposes, and that trust could be approved by the Governor-General for the purpose of the Act. The trust or the trustee or trustees of the trust would then be eligible for inclusion under paragraph (e) of the definition. I am sure that I need hardly say that the conduct of an aged persons home would be acceptable as a charitable or benevolent purpose. I must also point out that, in regard to the alternatives I have mentioned, it would be necessary for a trade union - as it is with any other organisation other than a religious body - to show that its constitution did not prevent it from establishing and conducting homes for the aged or prevent it from establishing a trust for this purpose. Obviously il would be quite wrong for the Government to make a grant of money towards a project if the organisation were prevented by its own constitution from undertaking the project.

It might interest the Senate to know that twenty-eight organisations have been approved by the Governor-General as eligible organisations under the. latter two methods to which I have referred; they include the Country Women's Association, friendly societies, Rotary clubs, lodges of various categories, and trustees of a number of estates. It is not possible - and indeed it would not be sensible - to attempt specifically to list in the definition all the types of organisations that could be eligible. If trade unions were shown, many other organisations, including employer organisations and others such as I have already mentioned, could well expect specific reference. Further, the Government considers that trade unions would be most appropriate bodies to establish and conduct homes for the aged, and would welcome their participation in this activity. Although it has been made clear on a number of occasions in the past in this House and in another place that trade unions could be eligible bodies, it is an unfortunate fact that no trade union has so far, either directly or indirectly, made application for approval as an eligible organisation. I emphasise that in the Prime Minister's policy speech last November he undertook to include local government bodies as eligible organisations. The Government, therefore, has a mandate from the electors to put into effect the proposal it has submitted in this Bill. I hope that the Senate will permit the Government to do so. and I hope that it will not insist on this amendment.

talker.electorate: New South WalesLeader of the Opposition
talker.name: MURPHY, Lionel
Senator MURPHY

talk.start.para: - This matter was well thrashed out in this chamber in the Committee stage of the consideration of this Bill last week. The reasons which were advanced by the Opposition then were never properly rebutted by the Government. The action of the Government in refusing to accept the Senate's amendment is petulant. It is a petty approach. The Government concedes that the trade unions are most appropriate bodies to establish and conduct homes for the aged. Those are the very words of the Minister for Social Services (Mr Sinclair). The Government has taken the line that the trade unions are covered in the sense that they might fall under sub-paragraph (ii) of paragraph (a), which reads: an organization the principal objects or purposes of which are charitable or benevolent;

speech.para: The Committee has heard the argument on that matter and it is apparent that the trade unions would not fall within that subparagraph. Perhaps if some of them did it would be by accident. It would be hard to imagine a trade union whose principal objects or purposes were charitable or benevolent. That argument has never been dealt with by Ministers. The suggestion that trade unions come within that provision cannot be sustained. I repeat that it is clear that a trade union may have objects or purposes that are charitable or benevolent but those are not the principal objects of the trade union.

talk.start.para: - If they are named in the Bill and they are not charitable or benevolent organisations, they qualify. Is that not the position?
- If individual bodies were to be named, of course these bodies would become eligible organisations.
- Even if they were not charitable.

- The proposal of the Opposition is not to name bodies. It is to use the description 'a trade union registered under a law of this Commonwealth or of a State'. We have not even suggested that individual organisations be named. Notwithstanding this, the reasons advanced by the Government set out that if we were to mention trade unions specifically we would do the same for Country Women's Associations, Lions Clubs and Apex Clubs. No-one has suggested that we should include a whole list of trade unions or selected trade unions. The description is: a trade union registered under a law of the

speech.para: Commonwealth or of a State.

There was no suggestion that individual ones be named. That reasoning is baseless. One Government senator has said, and we agree, that it is wrong in principle that a trade union should have to seek the approval of the Governor-General. The objection to this was made all the stronger when the Minister for Repatriation (Senator McKellar) suggested that a politicial test be applied to registered trade unions in respect of a matter such as this, that is, providing homes for the aged. Apart from the constitutional aspects of such an approach, it is an approach that would not be accepted, I think, by any person who had any regard for civil liberties in this community. If one wanted to encourage people to think that they were martyrs or that the system of society was wrong, one would apply that approach. Here is an object of providing homes for the aged. A registered trade union is an entity in itself. It is registered under Federal or State law; it has rules which are required to conform to Federal or State law; it has electoral processes which are required to conform to Federal or State law; its administration is supervised by Federal or State tribunals, and it is required to submit balance sheets to Federal and State officials. In all ways trade unions are bodies setup subject to an extremely high degree of control under Federal and State law.

talk.start.para: - Do any of the reasons the honourable senator has stated invalidate the opportunity for a trade union to form a trust for this purpose?

- Before it can form a trust it has to be an organisation referred to in paragraph (a). This suggestion of a trust is misleading. It is a red herring, because the real question is how an organisation comes within the ambit of paragraph (a), not whether it can form a trust. The latter is completely beside the point, because an organisation must come within the provisions of paragraph (a) (i), (ii), (iii) or (iv) before the provisions as to trust operate. Can the honourable senator understand that this is merely a subsidiary way of dealing with an organisation? An organisation is eligible either directly under that or by way of a trustee. This does not advance the matter at all, and if the honourable senator peruses the clause in question and ponders it he will see that what I am saying is correct. Before the provisions as to trusts operated an organisation would still have to be either a religious organisation or it would have to fall within the requirement of sub-paragraph (ii), and be an organisation the principal object or purposes of which are charitable or benevolent, or sub-paragraph (in) and be an organisation of former members of the Defence force established in every Stats or a St.:te branch of such an organisation, or sub-paragraph (iv), and be an organisation approved by the Governor-General. It is no advance at all. One may say that an organisation is set up either by its governing body or it is set up under a trust. This is only the machinery of the thing. It is not the real point.
- 1 completely understand that, but I cannot comprehend why the Leader of the Opposition argues that one cannot form a trust in accordance with sub-paragraph (iv).

- The question is whether the trade unions should be eligible organisations coming within one of these categories or whether they should be discriminated against and be forced to obtain approval from the Governor-General in accordance with sub-paragraph (iv). To say that a trade union could form a trust does not in any way get away from that point. If unions were prepared to set up trusts they would still have to get approval as organisations under sub-paragraph (iv). Then it is clear in logic that the matter as to trusts is only machinery, lt has nothing to do with the gravamen of the matter. Trade unions do not fit in under subparagraph (i); they do not fit in under subparagraph (ii), as we have demonstrated, notwithstanding the reasons advanced; they do not fit in under sub-paragraph (iii) and they should not have to fit in under subparagraph (iv).
- They do.

- They do not fit in under sub-paragraph (iv) unless they get approval. The Opposition has taken the stand - and the Government has advanced no satisfactory argument to the contrary - that there is no reason why a registered trade union should not be on the same footing as a religious organisation, as an organisation the principal objects or purposes of which are charitable or benevolent or an organisation of former members of the defence force established in every State or a State branch of such an organisation. That is the argument. It is as simple as that. Why should trade unions not be on the same footing as those organisations? That argument is in no way answered by what has been put forward by the Government. When one knows the background of the matter, and when it is conceded, as I repeat, by the Minister for Social Services that these are the most appropriate bodies to establish and conduct homes for the aged, it appears to us that the amendment which has been proposed by the Opposition should have been accepted by the Government without any fuss or bother. Instead, the Government is taking a stand in this place to reject the proposed amendment because it wants to show that it will insist on its view notwithstanding the lack of argument to support it and that it will force its will upon the Senate.

- I would not like the honourable senator to think that the Government's stand is not reinforced with very good and sound arguments. Under this legislation the Government's policy is that religious bodies, charitable and benevolent organisations and organisations conducted on a non-profit basis may qualify. I '.till have not received from the honourable senator a reply to my question as to what happens if a nominated registered trade union does not come within those provisions. If 'registered trade unions' were written into the legislation and there happened to be one which was conducted for profit-
- It is impossible.
- It is not impossible unless that were specifically stated in the union's constitution.
- But that is a requirement of Federal and State law. A trade union is not a business enterprise.

- That may be so, but it may not be so. There has been no instance of a trade union applying, but if one did apply and it was conducted for charitable or benevolent purposes or on a non-profit basis it would qualify automatically. That is the position. If it did not want to meet those requirements it could set up a trust. This is a very simple matter and I believe the argument advanced by the Government is sound. 1 have not yet heard the honourable senator say what would happen if such bodies were nominated and it was found that one or two were not conducted wholly on a non-profit basis.

talker.electorate: New South WalesLeader of the Opposition
talker.name: MURPHY, Lionel
Senator MURPHY

talk.start.para: - If it is convenient I propose to answer this question immediately. No trade union can be conducted for the profit of its individual members. The definition of 'trade union' under Federal and State law forbids that. That is not the nature of trade unions. They are not by any definition business enterprises conducted for the profit of individual members.

- I seem to remember payments to maritime unions or some practice of that kind in the past. I would be worried if we gave such an organisation, as a charitable or benevolent society, access to funds to engage in providing homes for the aged.

- -The Minister has revealed two facts by that interjection, firstly, that it is proposed to apply some political test - quite wrongly - to trade unions, and secondly, that his understanding of a trade union operating for the profit of individual members is completely against the notion of a trade union.
- Does the honourable senator mean that a trade union cannot conduct some enterprise and make a profit out of it?

- If any trade union were to do that it would be acting wrongly. It would be acting in breach of the rules of the union and would be subject to correction by its members. Everyone knows that. For Government senators to pursue that line, as they apparently intend to do, discloses an anti-union bias on their part. Senator Henty has deliberately evaded the words of sub-paragraph (ii). It is not a question whether an organisation is a charitable or benevolent body. It is a question whether an organisation is one the principal objects or purposes of which are charitable or benevolent. I repeat the words the principal objects or purposes'. So there can be trade unions which are charitable or benevolent but, because their principal object is not charitable or benevolent but industrial, they therefore do not come within paragraph (ii), they do not come within paragraph (i), and they do not come within paragraph (iii). This means, notwithstanding all that the Minister has said, that it is not open to them to form a trust.
- It is under paragraph (iv).

- This is the very point of the amendment. It has been said - and 1 am pleased to see that the Minister is at last coming to grips with it - that trade unions cannot qualify under the first three paragraphs notwithstanding what appears in the reasons which have been put forward. It is said that it would be open to any of these organisations, including trade unions, to establish a trust for a charitable or benevolent purpose, such as conducting an aged persons home and have that trust approved by the Governor-General for the purposes of the Act.
- Does the honourable senator say that is an incorrect statement?

- That is an incorrect statement because the organisation must be one the principal objects of which are charitable or benevolent. I ask honourable senators in fairness to look at what is in the Bill. Paragraph (ii) refers to an organisation the principal object or purpose of which is charitable or benevolent. In the including part of the Bill, mention is made of the trustee or trustees under a "rust established by an organisation referred to in paragraph (a) of the definition. So it has to be established by an organisation the principal objects of which are charitable or benevolent. If that cannot be seen, then 1 am afraid those who do not see will not see. There is no substance in what has been advanced by the Leader of the Government and I would ask the Senate again to reject the Bill in its present form and insist upon the amendment made by the Senate.

speech.para: Senator DameANNABELLE RANKIN (Queensland - Minister for Housing) [4.12] - I must remind the Senate again, as I did previously that the reason given by the House of Representatives for disagreement with the amendment is that a trade union is in no different position to any other organisation that does not fall within sub-paragraphs (i), (ii) or (iii) of paragraph (a) of the definition of 'eligible organization'. But it is still possible for it to qualify as have a variety of other organisations which L shall name in a moment. They have qualified under either paragraph (a) (iv) as organisations approved by the Governor-General for the purposes of the Act . or sub-clause (e) as a trust established for charitable or benevolent purposes and approved by the GovernorGeneral for the purposes of the Act. To date, no trade union has applied to benefit in this way.

I think it will be of interest to the Senate to know what organisations have been approved by the Governor-General under sections 5 (1) (b) (iv) and 5 (2) of the existing Act. A wide variety of organisations have received assistance in this way. They are the Australasian Trained Nurses Association of New South Wales, the Country Women's Associations of Queensland, South Australia, Victoria and Western Australia, the Grand Lodge of Western Australia of Ancient Free and Accepted Masons, the Grand United Order of Oddfellows Friendly Society of New South Wales, the Independent Order of Oddfellows of New South Wales, the Manchester Unity Independent Order of Oddfellows in New South Wales, South Australia and Victoria, the Rotary Club of Maitland, New South Wales, the Royal Antediluvian Order of Buffaloes Grand Council of Australia Incorporated of Western Australia, the South Australian United Ancient Order of Druids, the United Ancient Order of Druids Friendly Society Grand Lodge of New South Wales, and thirteen trusts established by the trustees for the estates of various persons. These are all organisations which have been approved by the GovernorGeneral under these provisions and which have received assistance.

I come back to the point I made previously. It does not seem logical or sensible that each one of these various organisations should be specifically named in the legislation. I cannot see that a trade union, if it is carried on otherwise than for the purposes of profit or gain for its individual members and is an organisation thi' principal objects of which are charitable or benevolent, cannot be admitted under the proposed new paragraph (a) (2). If it is carried on otherwise than for the purposes of profit or gain for its individual members and cannot be regarded as an organisation. the principal objects of which are charitable or benevolent, it can be admitted under paragraph (iv) as an organisation approved by the Governor-General for the purposes of the Act. If it docs not qualify under that provision, then it can establish a trust and if that trust is approved by the GovernorGeneral for the purposes of the Act it then becomes an eligible organisation under paragraph (e) of the definition.

As I said previously, I believe the Bill as drafted covers the point raised relating to a trade union. A trade union can benefit under the legislation. 1 submit that the Bill covers the wish of honourable senators that a trade union shall be able to accept a grant. So far no trade union has ever made application, but if it does and it fulfills the conditions laid down, it can receive a grant as have other organisations which have been assisted.

talk.start.para: - I see more importance in rejecting the recommendation from the other place on this occasion than I saw in approving the Senate amendment when we discussed it last Tuesday. Last Tuesday, the Government parties were of the opinion that trade unions were covered by the Bill and there was no need to mention them specifically. The Opposition was of the opinion that trade unions should be mentioned specifically. There was no strong denial from this side of the Chamber that trade unions may be covered already. Why is there this disagreement between the Government and- the Opposition over this matter? The inclusion of trade unions would not affect the Government in any way; it would not be a blow to the prestige of the Government. Therefore, we must look for the reason for this strong opposition from the Government. Why does the Opposition insist upon the inclusion of trade unions if, as the Government argues, they are covered? Because the Government is so insistent upon rejecting our suggestion, the Opposition is very suspicious of the Government's action over this question. It was argued in the House of Representatives and repeated by the Minister for Housing today that a trade union is in no different position to any other organisation that does not fall within paragraph (a) of the proposed new section 2. There was also mention of paragraph (iv). It was argued that the position of a trade union would be analogous to that of an organisation coming under that provision.

speech.para: Last Tuesday night I raised the question of the legal interpretation of that part of the definition which relates to an organisation carried on otherwise than for the purpose of profit or gain to its individual members. I accept the interpretation of the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Murphy) who argues that a trade union would not be carried on for the purpose of profit or gain to its individual members and therefore would qualify under paragraph (a). The important point in all these matters is the interpretation placed upon these words by the Minister or the Department. lt is most unlikely that anyone would challenge a gift to an organisation. I think the power to challenge would be restricted. But although the Minister for Housing (Senator Dame Annabelle Rankin) has stated the reasons for the rejection of the Senate amendment by the other place, the point relating to an organisation the principal objects or purposes of which are charitable or benevolent was not mentioned during the course of the debate in that place.

The Minister for Housing is not sure, I think, whether trade unions do come under that provision of the Act, and the Leader of the Opposition has told the Committee that they do not come under that provision of the Act. We then come to the only other question in relation to this point. We find in paragraph (a) of the definition that an eligible organisation means:

item.label: (iv)
item.para: an organisation approved by the GovernorGeneral for the purposes of this Act.

speech.para: Organisations have to be approved by the Governor-General in order to be eligible to receive the grant. The reasons given in another place for the rejection of our amendment include the argument that trade unions are covered by paragraph (e) of the definition. I am inclined to believe that trade unions could even be organisations that are carried on otherwise than for profit or gain if they create a: trustee or trustees under a trust established for charitable or benevolent purposes and approved by the Governor-General for the purposes of this Act.

Some doubt exists whether a trade union could not be included in the definitions of either paragraph (a) sub-paragraph (iv) or paragraph (e) of the definition. But the Opposition has asked why trade unions should be in a different class from Rotary clubs or Apex clubs. Why should they be different from religious organisations or any other organisation? The distinction between trade unions on the one hand and Rotary and Apex clubs on the other is that the Rotary and Apex clubs are more or less charitable organisations of which all responsible sections of the community approve. Trade unions are organisations of which some sections of the community do npt approve. Trade unions are different from Apex clubs, Rotary clubs or even Country Women's Associations. No-one can object if approval is given to a local town branch of the Country Women's Association to receive a loan to build an aged persons home. But it seems that someone would object if a loan to build an aged persons home were given to the Carpenters Union in Tasmania.

talk.start.para: - No-one could object if the trade union was a charitable or benevolent organisation and came within the definition of the Act. It would be quite all right. How could anyone object?
- An organisation comes under the Act only if it is approved by the Governor-General.
- The union could set up a trust.
- Even if it sets up a trust, it has still to be approved. The Bill provides for an eligible organisation to include: an organisation approved by the GovernorGeneral for the purposes of this Act.

speech.para: An eligible organisation must be approved by the Governor-General. The point is that approval is given to acceptable charitable organisations without any dispute or argument. But trade unions are controversial organisations in our society. They are not liked by some sections of the Government forces. Therefore the question arises of granting approval to trade unions. We have heard evidence of the thinking of some members of the Government. Senator Heatley from Queensland is not prepared to give a donation to the organisation with which Pat Mackie was associated. The Minister for Repatriation (Senator

Mckellar) would not give the grant to what he terms Communist organisations. That is the distinction between the attitudes adopted by Senator Heatley and the Minister for Repatriation. I do not think that it has been suggested that Pat Mackie was a Communist, but in Senator Heatley's eyes he was undesirable and therefore the organisation to which he belonged should not receive a grant. Consequently, in the eyes of Government members a number of trade unions should not receive a grant. This means then that under this Act only those trade unions that are approved by the Government will be recognised as eligible. The grant becomes a reward for an organisation that obtains Government approval. This boils down to the establishment of tame cat unions. If a union does the right thing, it will receive Government approval and its assets for the building of homes for its aged persons will be increased by two-thirds from Government finance.

But is there any danger in granting approval to the union of which Pat Mackie was a member or to a union that has Communist leadership? The security that is provided in this respect is found in section 7 of the Aged Persons Homes Act. Sub-section (3.) provides:

quote.para: A payment under this Act shall not be made except to a corporation in which, or to trustees in whom, the approved home is to be vested.

speech.para: This is met in paragraph (e) of the definition of eligible organisation which provides that the money must be invested by the trustee or trustees under a trust established for charitable or benevolent purposes. So, I do not see why even an organisation in which Pat Mackie was involved or to which he belonged could not obtain the grant if it had a system of trustees. Section 8 of the Act provides: (1.) A grant to an eligible organisation under this Act may be made upon such terms and conditions, not inconsistent with this Act as the Director-General thinks fit.

talk.start.para: - From what ls the honourable senator reading?
- I am reading from the Aged Persons Homes Act 1954-67, and am quoting section 8. Sub-section (2.) provides:

quote.para: Before making a grant under this Act to an eligible organisation, the Director-General may require the organisation to enter into an agreement wilh him with respect to the terms and conditions upon which the grant is to be made.

speech.para: Sub-section (3.) states:

quote.para: An agreement under the last preceding subsection may, if the Director-General considers the circumstances so require, include an- undertaking by the eligible organisation with respect to the continued use of the home as a home for aged persons, and provision for the repayment of the grant to the Commonwealth in the event of a breach of the undertaking, and for the giving of security for the carrying out of the undertaking.

speech.para: First we see in respect of the whole system the necessity for trustees. A grant is given for a building under the conditions laid down by the Director-General. If the conditions are not fulfilled, the grant is to be repaid. There is no question of any abuse of this grant by anyone who represents a trade union if such a body were approved. Under section 8 of the Act, it is impossible for abuse to occur. Safeguards are provided and are used for that purpose. The question of someone misappropriating the money does not arise. It is a payment in respect of capital that has been spent on a building or is being spent on a building in course of erection. The Commonwealth does not give money to anyone. Every safeguard in the world is provided. With all these safeguards provided, what the Government wants to do is to make grants to organisations of which it has approved and refuse grants to organisations to which it has objected. The Government has rejected the organisations regarding which there is a difference of opinion as to their desirability. Surely the Government can see the importance of this? It has reached the stage now where it is deciding on political issues whether it should or should not approve an organisation.

This is an important matter to the Opposition. The Government might reject an organisation or a trade union because the secretary of that organisation or trade union has, in the opinion of the Government, an undesirable political following. But that secretary will not be there permanently whereas the homes that are built will be permanent. Let us consider how this question fits into the pattern in the second reading speech by the Minister. With tears in her eyes she stated:

quote.para: We are all aware, Mr President, that adequate housing in congenial surroundings is one of the greatest needs of old people.

speech.para: Then the Minister spoke of providing comfortable housing for people in the eventide of their lives. She went on to say:

quote.para: This was achieved through the introduction of the Aged Persons Homes Act which has given encouragement and financial help to the religious and charitable organisations and enabled them to expand their activities. The success of the Act is a matter of record. Since its inception, subsidies in excess of $66m have been approved and accommodation provided for more than 25,000 aged persons.

speech.para: Then we come to the pride expressed in the Minister's speech regarding the achievements of the Government. The Minister stated that the Government commenced the scheme with religious organisations that had some experience in caring for old people. But the scheme has now been extended. The Minister says in this regard:

quote.para: An important development in recent years has been the increased interest in aged persons homes shown by local governing bodies, many of which have assisted aged persons homes organisations by grants of land and in other ways. The Government welcomes this interest. In order to enable local governing bodies to participate more directly in the operation of the Act ... it has introduced this Bill . . .

The Act covers the situation in which there could be any fear of the activities of an organisation. So there would be no danger at all in the Opposition's amendment as originally accepted by the Senate. However, the Government wants to reserve to the Governor-General the right to approve or disapprove of a trade union. This distinction does not apply to other organisations-

As with other organisations, a trade union can receive the grant if it fulfils the required conditions. All the other organisations are not enumerated in the Bill. They are provided for in the provisions that I have mentioned. 1 believe that the extending of the scheme to local government organisations, as promised by the Prime Minister (Mr Harold Holt) in his policy speech for the recent general election, will extend the benefits of the aged persons homes scheme. 1 would like to see this measure passed without the amendment originally made at the instigation of the Opposition. talk.start.para: - Madam Temporary Chairman, on behalf of the Opposition I thank the Minister for again staling to us what seems to be the only basis for the Government's insistence on its stand and its opposition to the amendment. If ever a case that was unsound and without substance was advanced it is the case that the Government has put up on this issue. We have asked again and again why the Government has taken this stand, but we have not been given the slightest reason why a trade union not conducted for the gain or profit of its members should not be provided for in terms of the amendment that we had inserted in the measure. In relation to the aged persons homes scheme a trade union is in the same position as a local government body, a religious, charitable or benevolent organisation and any of the other kinds of organisation mentioned by the Minister and, like them, would have to comply strictly with the terms and condi tions laid down in the principal Act. Senator Cavanagh went through them in detail. Organisations assisted under the scheme can be tied hand and foot by various conditions relating to financial stringency, guarantees, audits and anything else that the Government requires. No organisation can indulge in any nonsense. These provisions apply equally to all.

speech.para: Why should a trade union be discriminated against? Why should it be treated differently from, say, a religious organisation? All sorts of bodies may conduct religious organisations. No-one applies to them the test that they must be approved by the Governor-General or by anyone else. Neither is that test applied to an organisation the principal objects or purposes of which are charitable or benevolent. Such organisations can spring up all over the place. There are thousands of them in this country. So long as the principal object or purpose of such a body is charitable or benevolent, it does not need the approval of the Governor-General. It is true that such an organisation has to comply with certain financial conditions, just the same as a trade union would have to do, but there is no requirement that the approval of the Governor-General must be obtained. Such organisations are automatically eligible, as are organisations of former members of the defence forces established in every State, or a State branch of such an organisation. Why should trade unions have to be approved by the Governor-General? Notwithstanding anything that has been said by the Minister or by the Leader of the Government (Senator Henty) there has been no answer to this argument. That is the kernel of the whole matter. The amendment which was proposed by the Opposition and which was inserted in the Bill is sensible. I repeat that the Government has been petulant in seeking to have it rejected. I ask the Committee to insist on the amendment.

talk.start.para: - Madam Temporary Chairman, there is little point in continuing for too long to go over all the grounds advanced by the Minister against the Opposition's argument that the amendment should be insisted on.
