She has said that if a trade union is carried on otherwise than for the purpose of profit or gain to its members and if it is an organisation the principal objects and purposes of which are charitable or benevolent it is an eligible organisation. We do not disagree with that. We disagree with the statement that a trade union is not an organisation the principal objects or purposes of which are charitable or benevolent and which therefore does not come within the section relating to such organisations. speech.para: Although it is claimed that a trade union comes within the Act, that is not one of the reasons why the Opposition should alter its attitude to the Bill because it is not one of the reasons advanced by the other place in refusing the amendment. We then come to sub-paragraph (iv) of paragraph (a) of the definition of 'eligible organisation' which refers to an organisation approved by the Governor-General for the purposes of this Act, or to paragraph (c) which refers to the establishment of a trust or trustees. The only other reason why we are asked not to insist on this amendment is that other organisations have to seek approval and trade unions should be in the same position. speech.para: The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Homes Savings Grant Act 1964-1966 in a number of ways. Certain proposed amendments will extend the scheme to include widowed persons aged less than thirty-six years with one or more dependent children and will increase from $14,000 to $15,000 the limit on the value of a home that may attract a grant. The scheme is still in its relative infancy and several amendments will, as promised by the Prime Minister (Mr Harold Holt) in his recent policy speech, relieve cases of hardship where young people have genuinely saved in an acceptable form for a home of their own, but, because they did not meet one or more requirements of the Act, failed to qualify for a grant. The Housing Ministry will be given new discretionary powers to meet these cases, and these powers will be operative from the date of commencement of the scheme. The amendments also include a number of new proposals that will be explained later in this speech. These will provide for some changes in the conditions under which savings are acceptable. And other provisions will simplify completion of the application form and the recording of savings.

The broad effect of all these amendments will be to permit more young people to receive a grant, and to permit others to receive larger grants by making some presently excluded savings acceptable for purposes of the scheme. In framing them, we have had continually in mind that the main purpose' of the scheme is to encourage young people to save as regularly as possible for the first home they own after marriage.

This Government is always keen to encourage home ownership. Over the years we have introduced a number of measures to foster this objective. The homes savings grant scheme is one of these measures. It was introduced during the last Parliament with the dual objectives of encouraging young people to save for their first matrimonial home and of increasing the savings deposited with Australian institutions that make the bulk of long term loans for housing purposes. Persons aged less than thirty-six years are encouraged to save by the offer of a grant of $1 for every $3 saved for the first home they own after marriage. The savings must be made over a period of at least three years and held in an approved form. The grant to a married couple, or to a husband or wife if only one is eligible, is a maximum of $500 on savings of $1,500 or more. The grant is a tax-free gift. Paid as a reward for saving, it assists young people to own and establish a home. The scheme applies to young couples whose prescribed dates are on or after 2nd December 1963. The prescribed date is the day on which a person enters into a contract to buy or build the home or, as an owner-builder, commences to build it. As this date is a most significant date for the purposes of the operation of the scheme, and as I will be referring to it quite frequently during the remainder of my remarks, please let me repeat the definition. The prescribed date is the day on which a person enters into a contract to buy or build the home or, as an owner-builder, commences to build it.

Up to 5th May 1967, some 77,000 young couples had received homes savings grants totalling over $34} million to assist them lo own and establish a home. This and our other measures to foster home ownership have been very effective. Australia now has a percentage of home ownership unequalled by any other country in the world, and the general, standard of housing in this country is something of which we can all be proud. Half the homes in Australia today have been constructed since this Government came to office in 1949. But we are not content to rest on our past achievements. There are still people seeking homes in Australia who are in need of assistance, and others who are living under conditions that are not generally acceptable.

As notes explaining each clause and subclause of the amending Bill have been circulated to all honourable senators, it will not be necessary for me to discuss all the clauses in detail. However, honourable senators will I am sure welcome an outline of the more significant proposals. This Bill will make it possible for widowed persons aged less than thirty-six years with one or more dependent children to become eligible for the grant. It will apply to widowed persons who, on or after 28th November 1966, entered into a contract to buy or build- a home or, as owner-builders, commenced its construction, and, of course, those who do so in future. The definition of a 'dependent child' follows the definition of that expression contained in the Social Services Act in relation to widows pensions. As from 1st January 1968, young widowed persons will be required to hold their acceptable savings, other than those spent on the purchase of land, on a deposit on the home or on materials for the home, in a home savings account with a bank, or with a building or housing society. But I emphasise that this requirement will not apply to widowed persons until 1st January 1968. The intervening period will be regarded as a transitional period during which special provisions will apply to their savings.

Under these provisions, a widowed person whose prescribed date is earlier than 1st January 1968, may hold savings at the prescribed date in any form of bank account, or with a friendly society or credit union. Moreover, savings at earlier savings dates may be held in any other bona fide form of saving. This is of course in addition to savings in the forms acceptable from 1st January next. In the case of a widowed person whose prescribed date is on or after 1st January 1968, savings held in any form of bank account, or with a friendly society or credit union, or in any other bona fide form will be acceptable in these forms up to 31st December 1967. However, to be acceptable after 31st December 1967 any such savings must have been converted into one of the forms acceptable at all times under the Act; that is, into a home savings account with a bank, or with a building or housing society. In addition, all new acceptable savings made on and after 1st January 1968 must be made in one of the forms acceptable at all times. Like others, widowed persons will be required to show that they have saved for at least the three years immediately preceding their prescribed dates. In meeting this requirement, savings held in an acceptable form by the deceased spouse up to the date of death and bequeathed to the widowed person will be acceptable, as also will such savings held in the estate of the deceased spouse for the eventual benefit of the widowed person. As we promised last year, there is provision in this Bill to increase the limit on the value of a home that can attract a grant from $14,000 to $15,000. This new limit will apply in respect of applicants whose prescribed dates are on or after 28th November 1966.

Another amendment will benefit many young couples who failed to lodge an application for the grant within the statutory period permitted under the existing legislation, lt will extend the time limit for the lodgment of applications from three months to twelve months, and will authorise acceptance of applications lodged within a further period if this would seem to be justified. Under what may be described as an act of grace, the Government has decided that, if this amendment is accepted by Parliament, all applications that have been lodged later than the permissible time limit will bs accepted. There will be no need for these applicants to lodge a further application. Those who did not submit an application, because they were told or understood their applications would be received too late to be accepted, are invited to do so forthwith. However, as the grant is not only a reward for saving, but is also intended to assist young people as early as practicable in the process of buying or building their own homes, it is important that in future all applications should be lodged as soon as possible and certainly within twelve months of the prescribed date except in very unusual circumstances. Under the existing Act the Department has no authority to pay a grant to the surviving partner of a marriage where one partner dies after the prescribed date but before determination of an application. The amending Bill will give us this authority.

The existing Act requires i:he land on which the home is built to be held in one of the approved forms exclusively by one or both of the married couple. This creates a problem where the applicant builds a house on farm land owned jointly or as tenant-in-common with a parent or other close relative. To meet cases such as these, the Bill will empower my Department to accept an interest in the land held jointly by an eligible person and a person other than his or her spouse. The eligible person will however be required to have exclusive right of occupancy of a home on the land. For reasons that I think are obvious, this amendment will not extend to cases where a single residence is purchased jointly by two couples for occupation by both.

Neither of a couple may be paid a grant if either has owned another dwelling during their marriage, even though they have never occupied it or regarded it as their matrimonial home. Persons who purchase homes in their own names for their aged parents, owners of sub-standard homes, beneficiaries who are bequeathed unsuitable homes and persons who are temporary owners of dwellings in the normal course of their business may therefore all be ineligible. The amending Bill will empower my Department to disregard ownership of another dwelling house' if it would be unreasonable to regard that house as the matrimonial home or as suitable for this purpose.

Where the effective date of a contract is not the day on which the applicant signs it, he may be mistaken as to the correct day on which his prescribed date falls. He may obtain savings certificates from a bank or building society in respect of a date that may be a few days before or after his prescribed date. Solely to avoid the inconvenience caused to applicants and savings institutions in having new certificates prepared, it is proposed to allow some flexibility in this respect. This will not alter the determination of the prescribed date, and eligibility for a grant will continue to be determined by reference to this date. Another discretionary power will permit my Department to ignore a brief hiatus in a person's savings period where, for example, savings may be held in cash or otherwise whilst being transferred from one acceptable form to another. All these new discretionary powers that I have mentioned may be exercised in respect of applications from persons with prescribed dates on or after the date of commencement of the scheme, namely, 2nd December 1963.

Provided certain conditions are met, a further proposed amendment will make both a husband and wife eligible for the grant even though neither has held acceptable savings in his or her name throughout the full period of the three years before their prescribed date. The conditions are that each has held acceptable savings in his and her name during part of the minimum savings period, that when these savings are aggregated the husband and wife as a couple would have held acceptable savings throughout this period and that both are under thirty-six years of age and are eligible in all other respects. In other words, we propose to ease the requirements so as to permit payment of the grant to a couple who are now both ineligible because neither has held acceptable savings in his or her name throughout the minimum three-year period although together they have done so.

Moreover, where both the husband and the wife hold acceptable savings at the prescribed date, but one of them is ineligible solely because he or she has not held acceptable savings in his or her name for the full three-year period, that partner will now become eligible for the grant, and the grant payable to the couple may thereby be increased. These liberalised provisions will apply to persons whose prescribed dates are on or after 1st May 1967.

Further amendments will change the definition of the amount of acceptable savings in a savings year. At present there is a limit of $500 on the annual savings made by an eligible person that may attract the grant. This limit was set to encourage continuous saving over a period of at least three years. As the minimum savings period is three years and as $1,500 must be saved to qualify for the maximum grant, the annual limit of $500 is exactly one-third of this. Persons who save $1,500 over three years seldom, if ever, save exactly $500 each year. They are naturally disappointed when annual savings of more than $500 are disallowed. We have decided to ease this provision, and the Bill proposes that the limit on the acceptable savings of an individual in a savings year be raised from $500 to $600. The minimum total savings required to receive the maximum grant will remain unchanged at $1,500. This amendment will apply to all applicants in respect of savings years commencing on or after 1st May 1966.

For simplicity of administration, an amendment will provide that the annual limit on savings will apply only throughout the period of the three years immediately preceding the prescribed date instead of the seven preceding years as at present. This will mean that savings, regardless of amount, held in an acceptable form at the start of the third year prior to the prescribed date will qualify. In future, applicants will need to supply detailed information of their savings only in respect of their final three savings years. This will greatly simplify the application form. This amendment will apply from the date of assent to the amending legislation.

Under the existing Act, a husband and wife may each have acceptable savings of $500 in any of their savings years. As I said earlier, we now propose that the limit on acceptable individual savings in a year be raised from $500 to $600. lt would, however, be contrary to the aim of encouraging regular and relatively even saving over a minimum period of three years if the husband and wife were both permitted to have acceptable savings of $600 in one year, or, in other words, to save in a year $1,200 of the $1,500 on which the maximum grant is payable. Moreover, now that we are proposing that, in certain circumstances, the savings of a husband and wife may be treated as joint savings, this is also a good reason why the new liberalised limit of $600 for annual savings should apply to the total savings of the husband and the wife. An amendment will provide that the limit on the total acceptable savings of a husband and wife in any savings year shall be $600, and that this will apply to the savings of all applicants in savings years commencing on or after 1st May 1966.

Other amendments will provide that the minimum grant payable shall be $10, and that moneys deposited in a savings bank account or on fixed deposit with a trading bank shall be acceptable savings if the account, as an alternative to being designated as a home savings account, has been designated with a form of words having an implied meaning similar to 'home savings account'.

The present Commonwealth and State Housing Agreement, which began to operate from 1st July last, permits the allocation of some Home Builders Account moneys to an approved State government lending institution for lending to private home seekers in rural areas not served by building societies. In States where there is not a State bank, approval may be sought to make such loans through the State housing authority. However, the Act does not permit a grant to be made in respect of a home if there are Agreement moneys owing to a State housing authority in respect of the house. The Bill contains an amendment to give effect to the original intention that homes acquired with the assistance of a loan of Home Builders Account moneys shall be eligible for the purposes of the scheme.

Honourable senators will be interested to know that work is proceeding on a revision of the booklet 'A Grant for Your Home' to include the amendments now submitted for consideration by the Parliament. It will be reprinted and distributed as soon as possible after the legislation receives the royal assent. The introduction of this Bill demonstrates the Government's continuing desire to offer maximum reasonable assistance to young people who are making strenuous efforts to save to acquire their own homes. The proposed amendments should assist a considerable number of deserving applicants to satisfy the basic requirements of the scheme. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.

talk.start.para: - The purpose of this Bill is, to set up an Australian Tourist Commission, it is an original Bill, not an amending one. It gained the support of both sides of the House of Representatives. We members of the Australian Labor Party offer no opposition to the establishment of this Commission, which will consist of five voting members and two non-voting members. It is interesting to note that it will be administered by the Department of Trade and Industry. Figures that have been supplied show thai last year tourism meant $65m to Australian trade. The forecast is that that figure will rise to $120m by 1970 and $208m by 1975. That increase will be brought about by an expected increase to 607,000 in the number of visitors to Australia. Tourism is a two way trade. Many Australians go overseas and spend money there. At the moment the balance of trade, as it were, is against us. This Bill represents an effort to reach the break even point and then to reverse the balance in our favour.

speech.para: So far the Government, on behalf of the taxpayers, has spent $5m on grants to the Australian National Travel Association which has been the forerunner of the Australian Tourist Commission and the instigator of this Bill. On reading the second reading speech made by the Minister for Supply (Senator Henty) and looking at the Bill, I wondered about a few matters. The Government Ls unable to forecast what amount will be spent. Listening to Senator Henty, I wondered what the future grants would be. He pointed out that because this matter is in such a fluid state the Government is unable to say what they will be. Undoubtedly future budgets will show what they will be.

The Minister mentioned that the people who have surveyed this field have set an estimate of 607,000 visitors in 1975, bringing with them $208m. The estimate is set on four points, three of which are related to improved transport in Australia. This indicates that we are not completely satisfied with the present transport. Although the Commission is to work with travel agents, transport authorities and other people who are already in the field, I note that it will act as a public relations agent; that is to say, it will send out literature, films and general information, to be distributed throughout the world. The power to assist in this field has already been dealt with, although I believe that Senator Henty said that this was only a minor part of the duties of the Commission. Nevertheless, he went into detail and explained that the Commission envisaged setting up its own travel agencies in various parts of the world not already covered by private people in this line of business. The Minister did not use the expression 'travel agencies' hut 1 took him to mean travel agencies. He made it clear, also, that although the Commission would bridge this gap in the areas where no promotional work or travel agencies had been established, when someone else wanted to move into the field, it would move out and let the others take over. It seems that this is one of 'those slight bits of Socialism. The Commission will move in to the point where the operation 'becomes profitable and then it will move out. I thought the Minister made this abundantly clear.

Although this is an important part of trade - and one has only to look at other places in the world to see how important tourism is in the field of trade - it goes much further than mere trade. From tourism arises the image of Australia that is projected in other countries, and it would be impossible to think that 607,000 people in future would travel through this country and not go back to their homelands with some definite ideas of what Aus tralia and Australians are like. Therefore, it is up to this Commission to make sure that our visitors go back as advocates, and not devil's advocates, for Australia. People who visit this country will publicise Australia much more than any pamphlet, film or lecture by someone in an embassy overseas; indeed, they will do much more than could be done by members or servants of the Commission. The personal recommendations of people who return to their homelands after visiting this country will be the greatest form of advertising.

I do not seek to lecture the Commission or to do what was done in another place. I am sure that during this debate some honourable senators will enumerate the tourist attractions of Australia; undoubtedly we shall hear about the Great Barrier Reef and the northern areas. I feel for the Commission when 1 say that the importance of a good start is an overwhelming consideration. The Leader of the Government referred to three suggestions for improvement, especially in the field of transport. I completely understand this, for if we are to get off the beaten track and have tourists travelling to our northern areas, we must realise that they will not want to be travelling up the north coast of Queensland or Western Australia in overcrowded, outdated small aircraft. People who travel north along these coasts will want to get not only into a town but also out of it within a reasonable time, and certainly when they want to get out. These are some of the problems that will have to be handled fairly quickly. Obviously the Commission will not have dictatorial powers; yet it will need to have great powers of persuasion if it is to get the two main airline operators to do something over and above what they would want to do in the normal pursuit of trade.

One of the suggestions made in another place deals with a baggage allowance. This is something that could be taken into consideration by the Commission, which could sell it to other people. This would be a tremendous start, for it deals with problems associated with travelling long distances. If an American decides to go for a holiday - or a vacation, as the Americans call it - he might go to Canada for a week or two. Then comes the problem of carrying extra clothes, especially if a woman is in the party; she will worry about the changes of weather, different kinds of hats, shoes and so on. People who have travelled have heard the maxim: If in doubt about an article of clothing, you do not want it. The chances are that the weather will not get hot or cold; it will not rain; whatever you are worrying about will not happen. But obviously this is a problem that will confront passengers who are travelling great distances to Australia. They have this problem even when they are travelling to Europe, Canada and the other places that have become tourist magnets over the years. We have vastly different problems when it comes to providing for travellers to this country. I am sure that hotel accommodation will be mentioned by some honourable senators. 1 notice that the fly problem has already been mentioned in another place; I believe a Western Australian member mentioned it, but I doubt whether the Queenslanders will concede the heavyweight belt to us in this respect. We do not want people going away from this country saying: 'If there is one thing I remember about Australia it is the flies'. This reminds me of a story that an honourable senator told me about the visit of his child to Canberra. After giving the boy the full treatment and showing him everything here, including all the glories and beauties of Canberra, when the boy went back to school and his teacher asked him what was the most impressive thing he saw, he replied that, without doubt, the Canberra blowflies would remain longest in his memory. That is the type of thing that an honourable member in another place had in mind when he mentioned this matter. Impressions are built on small experiences. How often does one hear people who have visited countries overseas relate at length some little incident that has caused them to leave the country they visited with a certain image of the people there?

We must remember that it is not all as golden as it might seem when it comes to attracting great numbers of people. Tourism and tourists can be ugly words. How often have we heard people say: 'I am not going there; it is the tourist season, and I do not want to go running into all the trappings that go with tourists'? Above all, we must remember that not all tourists are millionaires, and that we have to cater for vastly greater numbers of tourist class than some countries did a few years back. We have a tremendous advantage in this country, for we are just coming into the market, and thus have an opportunity to study the tourism experiences of countries not only in Europe and Canada but also in Asia, which over the past few years has been coming more into calculations. We have an opportunity to examine what they have done, to assess their mistakes and to make sure that we do not repeat them. I hope that our beauty spots, and even some of our cities, are not dressed up in a lot of tinsel in order to get great numbers of millionaires to go there; indeed, 1 hope that our beauty spots will not be crowded out. 1 understand that in some countries one has to pay to go on to the beaches. If there is one thing Australia has it is great beaches, spread over tremendous distances. We have wonderful beaches in Queensland, in Western Australia, and all round the Australian coast - not only at Bondi and a few of the other places that we read about. Beaches are just one of the gifts that nature has given to the healthy, sun-loving Australian people, and we must avoid dressing some of them in tinsel and all these other things, in the hope that in future a charge will be made to visit them. We can benefit from the mistakes of other countries. Not everyone wants to be a kibitzer, which is the Americans' term for a stickybeak, or as we call a person who stays for just a few hours to look at a place. People v/ho have travelled a bit have a great desire to get away and settle down for a few months. That is where our beach resorts and to a lesser extent, or to another extent - perhaps I should not give priorities - our mountain resorts can play a very great part, so that visitors will not race through the country.

We give this Bill our entire blessing. We wish the Commission all the success in the world. I do not want to lecture it. I am sure that its members will take the remarks that are made in both Houses of the Parliament in the spirit in which they are offered. The Commission will have to do a tremendous job. Not only will it have to attract tourists to Australia - a good start must be made - but also it must make sure that the visitors leave this country contented and happy. The Commission will have to face up to the four points mentioned by Senator Henty in relation to cheaper and better transport. Because of our vast distances we must offer the tourist more leisurely forms of transport - hire cars, caravanettes and that type of thing. Undoubtedly we have something unique to sell to the world. It looks to me as if we are starting along the right lines to sell it. The Commission will have the dual function of bringing people to the country and making sure that they leave contented. No doubt we have a great heritage. We want to be able to sell this to the world, without making mistakes that other countries have made and without damaging the natural resources that we have. There is the advantage that, by developing these attractions within Australia, we will encourage greater travel within the country by our own people. Australians are great travellers. I do not know to what extent we shall persuade people who plan to go overseas to reconsider their itinerary but if we make travel within our own country much more comfortable and convenient for them we shall be building up the tourist trade.

The Opposition wishes the Bill well. It welcomes the remarks that have been made and it wishes the Commission very great success. Undoubtedly, as forecast by the Minister, it will consist of able men who will be devoted to this very peculiar and modern form of trade and the fostering of good public relations for the Australian nation.

talk.start.para: - It is very pleasing to know that the Opposition in the Senate as well as in the other place gives its blessing to this Bill, which I believe is an extremely good one. I propose to open my comments by reading a few lines of the preface of the report by Harris, Kerr, Forster and Co. - known as the HKF report - which deals with the Australian travel and tourist industry. This preface was written by Mr Bates, Chairman of the Australian National Travel Association. It reads:

quote.para: This report ... is the first comprehensive survey of the travel and tourism industry to be carried out in Australia and probably the most detailed of its kind to be done for any country. Commissioned in 1964 by the Australian National Travel Association ... it had as its general object the provision of an authoritative assessment of, and guidelines for, the development of travel and tourism in this country.

speech.para: I think this is a suitable introduction to the comments that I want to make. The members of this team travelled some 25,000 unduplicated miles in Australia. They viewed and reported as experts on practically every tourist attraction. They made many expert recommendations - many more, of course, than were mentioned by the Minister for Supply (Senator Henty) in introducing the Bill. Indeed, right through this report arc recommendations in respect of various spheres. I do nol propose to repeat the recommendations. Indeed, 1 do not propose to touch on any of the specific tourist areas in Australia, because it would only be to repeat what has been published in this book, and published possibly in a more unbiased way than we who are Australians would be able to do ourselves. For my purposes I propose to address myself to the Bill itself and to inquire whether the machinery which is being set up is in fact adequate. This Bill does not deal with any internal tourism. It is a Bill for an Act to establish an Australian Tourist Commission for the purpose of the encouragement of visits to Australia, and travel in Australia, by people from other countries. The whole purpose of this piece of machinery is not to do those things that many of us may feel should be done in Australia but rather to take the steps that are necessary to bring tourists to Australia, lt is that background that 1 wish to develop.

Here 1 should like to mention that I have had some knowledge of the development of the tourist industry because I was Minister in charge of the tourist industry in Queensland for quite a number of years. I have studied the subject intensively for a long time. The first point 1 want to make is that the industry has mushroomed enormously over the past decade. This is so in most States, if not in all. I know that it has done so in practically every State. This is because of the activity internally of many groups. I shall detail them in a few moments. Here I am not blowing the trumpet of Queensland vis-a-vis other States, because I have not detailed statements of their development but I think it could be taken broadly that they have developed as Queensland has.

I am now dealing entirely with the internal development. The Queensland Government Tourist Bureau has increased its takings from its various agencies by thirty times in the last ten years, which is a fantastic development as I think everybody will agree. In Brisbane ten years ago there were no motels. In 1962 there were twelve. Today there are twenty-six, all of which provide first class accommodation. The same applies in the broad to Queensland generally. There were three first class and thirteen other motels ten years ago. In 1960 the number of first class motels had grown to 106, and today there are 420.

Evidence of the hug; internal growth of the tourist industry is to be found in the money that has been spent by the Government and other people on its development. For example, in Queensland in the financial year 1955-56 an amount of $208,000 was spent by the Government, of which $12,000 was on advertising. These amounts increased in 1958-59 to $390,000 and $36,000 respectively. In the case of expenditure on advertising, three times as much was spent in 1958-59 as in 1955-56. In 1961-62 expenditure had increased to $580,000, including $56,000 on advertising, and in the last financial year for which I have figures the expenditure was $715,000, of which $120,000 was on advertising. That trend has been reflected in nearly every State and for that reason the tourist industry internally has grown enormously.

Before looking at the machinery of the Bill I think we must examine why tourism has grown and why it obviously will continue to grow. The first thing we must recognise is that the industry is made up of many thousands of people who are tremendously enthusiastic about it. I do not think there is any industry which has engendered more enthusiasm in the people engaged in it. Such enthusiasm is probably one of the industry's most prominent characteristics. For that reason I was delighted when I learned that Mr Chipp had been appointed MinisterinCharge of Tourist Activities. Not only is he a man of great enthusiasm and dynamic drive, he is also an outstandingly good organiser and administrator. However, I have been somewhat disillusioned to discover that he has little administrative responsibility in regard to the tourist industry because such responsibility lies with senior Ministers, the Minister for Trade and Industry (Mr McEwen) and, in his absence, the Minister for Social Services (Mr Sinclair).

Please let me not be misunderstood. I am not denigrating either the Minister for Trade and Industry or the Minister for Social Services, who are extremely able men; but I feel that ministerial responsibility in relation to the tourist industry should not be divided. I would have been infinitely more satisfied with the machinery of the Bill had Mr Chipp been responsible directly to Cabinet and, through Cabinet, to the Parliament. I say that in all friendliness to the other Ministers I have mentioned. I believe that direct contact with Cabinet would have been infinitely better than the present set-up.

The tourist industry is mads up of several correlated segments which I shall mention briefly. Firstly, there are the individual resort proprietors. Probably I know most of those in Queensland. They have poured their money into their resorts year after year, almost decade after decade, to make their resorts increasingly better instead of sitting back and taking things easy on their profits. They have put their profits back into their resorts. This is due to their enthusiasm for their industry. Secondly, these individual resort proprietors are associated in what can be broadly described as district groups. If the leaders of the district groups are enthusiastic for this industry they can do a tremendous amount to help it. I can do no better than mention my friend, Senator Wood, as a classic example of an industry district leader encouraging his associates in the industry. The honourable senator is not in the chamber at the moment, but I still want to make these comments. All of us in Queensland know that the great boom in the tourist industry in the north commenced in the Whitsunday area, which is based on Mackay, and in the south on the Gold Coast. I think everyone in the Mackay area would agree wilh me that the tourist industry there has mads such rapid and constant progress largely because of the activities of Senator Wood.

Above the district groups within a State - I am speaking now of every State, not only of my own State of Queensland - are the State Government tourist authorities. If they are enthusiastic they can do a tremendous amount to help. Conversely, if they are apathetic they can and do retard the development of the industry within their particular State. I have met ministers of tourism many times. Indeed, I am proud to say that at my instigation the Tourist Ministers Council was formed. I suggested to Mr Cahill, the then Premier of New South Wales, that it would be desirable for all ministers associated with tourism to meet and discuss their problems. He was most helpful. We met a couple of months later but the meeting was very poorly attended. However, we persisted and at our next meeting every State was represented. More importantly, Western Australia and South Australia were represented by their Premiers, Victoria was represented by a very senior Minister, Tasmania by a Minister whose seniority I cannot just recall and New South Wales by the late Gus Kelly. Although Mr Kelly and I may have disagreed politically, at least we did not disagree on tourism, because he was one of the most enthusiastic supporters of the industry in Australia. This Council has developed wonderfully and has made a great contribution to the development of the industry within Australia, especially because the heads of the departments concerned with tourism are always present. In fact they have a meeting of their own on the day before the Ministers meet and this lends co-operation. 1 have mentioned the resort proprietors. Then there are the air, road and sea carriers and the private travel agents. However, the body which has been of vital importance since the late 1920s in the growth of the industry and in the general co-operation which now exists between all facets of the industry is the Australian National Travel Association, known as ANTA. In the last decade, the period for which I have known it. the organisation has done fantastic work. It has been headed by men of outstanding ability in the persons of Mr John Bates and, in latter years. Mr Basil Atkinson. As Chairman and General Manager respectively of the Association they have done wonderful work-. I do not think it would be possible to find two people who have the personality to do more than they have done. They have encouraged all the co-operating but sometimes conflicting interests of the various States into a coordinated effort.

Lest I forget it, 1 say now that 1 believe - this is only my personal view - that no two men would be better fitted to fill the respective positions of chairman and general manager of the commission which is being set up than Mr John Bates and Mr Basil Atkinson. That is not my province, but having been a Minister associated with tourist activities for so long I would be failing in my duty if I did not pay to those two gentlemen the compliment they so justly have earned.

As I. have mentioned, the tourist industry internally has grown considerably. People have travelled intrastate and interstate, and, of later years, it has grown internationally. Much of the work in publicising Australia as a venue for the overseas tourist has been done by the Australian National Travel Association. Indeed, this has been its major field other than the co-ordination of people within Australia itself. As I visualise it, this Commission which is being set up will in fact more or less replace the existing organisation known as 'ANTA'. 1 said a little while ago that this very valuable HKF report incorporates many recommendations. It makes certain recommendations so far as Australia internally is concerned. Senator Willesee referred to these things. But its overriding recommendation was that an organisation should be set up to look after the sales of travel in overseas countries. That is its. main purpose. As I read the Bill in conjunction with this report, I find certain points that I would like to raise both now and possibly later when we are discussing the Bill in committee.

First of all, we note that there are to be five members of this Commission who are to be voting members and two additional members who will be non-voting members. The Bill sets out quite clearly that of the five voting members two shall be from an organisation, and it is indicated that that organisation will be the ANTA. Here, of course, I am only assuming, from reading the Minister's speech, and from reading the Bill itself. But if it is to be the ANTA, then I shall be highly delighted. I do not think we could get two people from any other organisation more able to do this job. Then there is to be one officer from, I assume, the Department of Trade and Industry. That is clear-cut. Those three are more or less set out clearly.

But then there are two others to be added to the voting members of the Commission, and these are not set out quite as clearly. Perhaps this is a very wise precaution in a Bill of this nature. I know that if I were Minister, having got my first three men, one chairman - earlier I indicated whom I thought was the most outstanding man to serve in this office - and two members from the ANTA, I would then look at the balance and say: 'Here is a section of industry not at all covered and here is another section of industry not at all covered,' and from those two sections I would select the other two to make up the five voting members. I hope this will be done, and I assume that it will be done.

However, there are two more to be appointed who will not be voting members. They are to be appointed by the State Ministers' Council. This, too, is a very good thing. Some may quarrel with the fact that these two are to be non-voting members. I do not. I think this is desirable because the whole task of the Commission is to deal with selling outside Australia. This is set out specifically in the Bill and in the Minister's speech. The Commission will not go to Queensland and say: 'Your transport is bad and your facilities are bad. You must improve them.' That is left to the States themselves. As this is the case, I feel that the constitution of the Commission is entirely satisfactory. 1 was left in some doubt by one or two comments that were made by the Minister in his speech. He said:

quote.para: The remaining members of the Commission both voting and non-voting will be paid on a part-time basis.

speech.para: Then he goes on:

quote.para: Any officers of the Commonwealth Public Service being appointed ex officio. . . .

speech.para: This was something that aroused my interest because, a little earlier in his speech, the Minister referred to work that had been done on ANTA by other officers. I think he spoke of officers of the Prime Minister's Department, officers of the News and Information Bureau of the Department of the Interior and officers of the Department of Trade and Industry. I feared at first that these may have been in the mind of the Minister as the additional members of the Commission. I do not fear that any more as I read and study the Bill more carefully. I do not wish to develop this any further at this stage. Rather will I do so in committee when I can deal with it perhaps more precisely than I can deal with it at the present time.

The next point I want to raise is that, having viewed for ten years the work of the ANTA, I recognise that with the formation of this new Commission to take over the task of the international selling of tourism obviously the ANTA will not be doing it in competition and the very highly qualified officers that ANTA have recruited and trained will, I should imagine, become officers of the new Commission. So the administrative or sales work of ANTA will cease with the formation of the Commission.

One thing I most devoutly hope is that the organisation that we know as ANTA will not go out of existence. I must repeat here what I have said before. This is the only organisation in Australia which has succeeded in knitting together into a splendid pattern every interest in the tourist industry from resort proprietors to carriers and governments. If this work were to suddenly cease and ANTA were to go out of business, 1, for one, would be an extremely disappointed person. I repeat that it will be going out of business, if I may use that term, in selling, but thai it should remain as a co-ordinating body, to me. is of outstanding importance.

There are two or three other points [ want to make, but perhaps it would be best if I referred to ohe which is contained in the HKF report. I said earlier that this report contained dozens of recommendations. There is one which I consider is vital. It is that some assistance should be given in some way or other to the people who are providing accommodation at various resorts. I think probably Senator Wood would know a lot more about this than I do and possibly he may develop it. I will do no more than indicate that in my view this is a matter of vital importance. If I were asked to express my own view as to how they could best be helped, I would say that they should be given similar taxation assistance to that which is given to primary industry. I refer most particularly to the depreciation arrangements that are made. Having said that, 1 leave Hie matter not because I do not think it is very important - I repeat that I think it is of outstanding importance - but because we must keep on providing better accommodation buildings and better first class accommodation generally if we are to satisfy those overseas visitors whom the Commission is being set up to attract. 1 do not see things in quite the same way as Senator Willesee does with reference to moving into areas where other organisations do not exist. He may be quite right, but 1 do not think he is. Throughout America there are thousands of tourist agents. What the Commission will hope to do, I think, is to move into those areas and distribute what we know in the travel industry as travel manuals. A busy travel agent might receive an inquiry, as most travel agents do from people who come in and say: 'We have been to Europe. We have been to so and so. We want to go somewhere else. Can you give us any advice as to where to go?' The travel agent merely takes our the manual and says: 'Yes, here you are. Why do you not go to Australia?'. He is able to show them the brochures which set out exactly the various trips to Australia, the cost of those trips, what type of accommodation would be available, what attractions are in Australia, and all that sort of thing. I think that this is a way in which ANTA itself will work. The agency in Australia that first introduced travel manuals of this nature and distributed them to American travel agents was my own department in Queensland. We supplied these travel manuals to American travel agents. Believe me, although it cost us a few hundred pounds to distribute these manuals to American travel agents, we were fortunate, as a result of our manuals, in getting thousands of American tourists to our shores. This work in the broader fashion would be done by ANTA.

Having been associated with this work for a long time, I could say a great deal more, but I do not think it is desirable that one should speak too long on a subject such as this. I strongly commend the Bill. 1 hope that the Commission in the purpose on which it will set out - that is, the purpose of selling Australia overseas - will attract to its ranks the very best men that we have in Australia. 1 make no bones about repeating that the best as far as I can see in Australia for this purpose are those who have so wonderfully served ANTA in the same sphere in the past. I have expressed my regrets at the channels through which ministerial activity must proceed. Notwithstanding all this, I still have the hope that the Minister for Trade and Industry (Mr McEwen) will recognise the outstanding ability of his assistant, the Minister for the

Navy (Mr Chipp) and that in fact the work, decisions and administrative arrangements will be made by the Minister foi the Navy who is the Minister in Charge of Tourist Activities and who, I am sure, will obtain for Australia the overseas tourists in the numbers that have been predicted.

I wish to mention one more point that I nearly forgot. One of the great disadvantages of travel to Australia from America is that up to the present the big problem has been that many tourists have to retrace their steps. If they come from America, they call at Hawaii, usually come to Sydney and travel up to the Great Barrier Reef. That is the first time I have mentioned it, Senator Willesee.

talk.start.para: - The honourable senator disappoints me.

- Or, the tourist goes west to that most beautiful area in the south west part of Western Australia. One will not find anything better in the world. Whether one travels from Perth to Hie top of Cape York Peninsula, it is all beautiful but none of it is better, I concede, than what is to be found in Western Australia. However, the tourists who come from America have to retrace their steps by flying over the same route on their way home. For years I have advocated a north-about route. 1 am very delighted to see that it is now being put into practice. By this route, our visitors from America can leave their country, visit Honolulu and Hawaii, possibly see the islands of the South Pacific and then arrive in Australia. They travel north and see the beauties there. Having done that, they travel on through New Guinea and from New Guinea up to Hong Kong, Japan and back to America. This is a circuit route and is what I have always called the north-about route. It would provide the facilities for tourists if they wished not to retrace their steps to any great degree. I believe that this route will bring a great deal more business to Australia than we would get otherwise. If these comments of mine - I am modest enough not to expect it - are read by any members of the Commission, I hope that they will bear my recommendations in mind. I strongly commend the Bill.

- Mr Deputy President, I think all speakers on this Bill have approached the subject in a very sober fashion. I consider that this is because of the maturity that has developed in relation to the tourist industry in Australia. AsI listened to the various speakers, I thought that quite apart from the influx of overseas visitors an influencing factor in the field of tourism has been the post-war industrial gains.I have in mind such things as long service leave which is obtained now by people at an earlier age and which is appreciated. These industrial gains have injected a considerable amount of purchasing power into the tourist industry as a base over and above the benefits that have come from the overseas visitors.

speech.para: As to the functions of the Australian Tourist Commission, I think that we agree in general terms with what has been suggested. But I have one or two reservations regarding matters that I think the Commission will need to watch closely. If we study the situation in the United States of America, we will find that the point of no return has been reached in some cases because some of the massive motel chains have begun to get somewhat overaggressive. They have begun to feel as General Motors-Holden's does at times and adopted the view that is what is good for them is good for the community at large. 1 respectfully suggest that this is a phase that will have to be watched.

I was prompted to make that remark whenI was reading a debate in the Legislative Council for the Northern Territory. Controversy arose about the toilet facilities provided by Connellan Airways Limited for visitors to Ayers Rock. The increased patronage that this industry was receiving was quoted and it seemed to me that all anybody was concerned about was obtaining some additional service from the Department of Civil Aviation. The point that I make is this: This was expected. The Bill refers to a form of mutual aid with something being provided by the Commission and something being provided by the travel interests concerned, but we all know that while some of those concerned will always show a progressive line others involved may need to be stirred occasionally to maintain particular standards. A number of us are aware of the values which will accrue from increased tourist trade. Many of us know that it was only after a number of Australians went on working holidays and saw the saner drinking laws in Europe that these laws were gradually enacted here. The overseas visitor has certainly provided better hope for Australia's wine industry.

quote.para: That the Bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: - Mr President,when the debate was adjourned on Thursday of last week I had dealt with a number of aspects of the dairy industry. AsI proceed this evening I shall pick up the thread of the remarks that I made last week. I have received from Mr L. A. Lehmann, who is Chairman of the Federal Dairying Committee of the Australian Primary Producers Union, particulars of a five year plan for the dairy industry. Mr Lehmann and the members of his Committee have spent a good deal of time preparing this plan for the rehabilitation of the industry. I do not profess to have as intimate a knowledge of the industry as they have. However, I have examined the various proposals embodied in the plan that the members of the Committee consider would relieve the industry of its financial stress. The APPU, in this plan, recommends that long term loans at low interest rates be made available in order to raise annual production to 8,000 lb of butter fat. The description of the plan, referring to the report of the Dairy Industry Committee of Inquiry, stated:

quote.para: The APPU takes the view that the limit of 8,000 lb, which may have been appropriate when the report was completed, is now too low, and suggests that 10,000 lb would be a more suitable figure.

speech.para: It added:

quote.para: To be eligible for a loan, a farm must comply with the following conditions:

item.label: (i)
item.para: Possess a minimum of 20 dairy cows (ex cluding heifers, bulls and calves as at 1st July 1967).

item.label: (ii)
item.para: At least 50% of the gross income (including off farm income) had been derived from the sale of milk, milk products and/or butter fat in each of the three years prior to 1st July 1967.

item.label: (iii)
item.para: The farm must be capable of producing 10,000 lb of butter fat per annum and the farmer must be prepared to follow approved farm management practices.

speech.para: It may be appropriate to grant to farmers throughout the Commonwealth who satisfy those conditions loans to enable them to improve their farms and their dairy herds. Mr Lehmann classifies dairy farms in four groups. I do not propose to discuss them in particular. Some of them would require assistance. As I asked early in my speech: Why is it that at this stage of our development it is necessary for us to approve an annual bounty totalling $27m? If we examine the situation of the industry from beginning to end and acquaint ourselves fully with the history of the industry from its beginnings, we arrive at the conclusion that it is entitled to some form of national relief. If the figure of$27m is arrived at one can only conclude that that may be the correct level of bounty. However, it could be insufficient. Indeed, judging by what I see as I travel about certain dairying districts of Queensland, I would say that it is insufficient.

We speak of bounties. There is no sin on the part of the Commonwealth Government in paying bounties or subsidies. Last financial year the Commonwealth paid various bounties totalling $124,200,000. This financial year it proposes to pay a total of $142m in bounties. The petroleum search subsidy will total$1 6m. The superphosphate bounty will cause the Government to pay out $28m. The sum of $4,750,000 has to be found to meet the bounty on nitrogenous fertilisers. The dairy industry is a great industry on which many thousands of families depend for a living and for their future. They depend on the income from it to educate their children, for example. A bounty of $27m distributed among them all means little per head. This is especially striking when one considers that it represents a gilt edged investment for the Commonwealth.

The dairy industry has been and is being helped in various ways. The Department of Primary Industries in Queensland is engaged on many projects that are designed to advance the prosperity of the industry. Its work in this field is constant. It has undertaken projects in the following fields: investigation of mat grass infested pastures; the disease leptospirosis; dairy husbandry practices investigations; dairy pasture improve ment; and the effect of strategic supplementary feeding on production and reproduction. That department has set itself the task of undertaking projects in these fields and is fully discharging its obligations to dairy farmers. If we look to see whether the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation is doing anything about pastures in a general way and particularly in relation to the dairy industry, we find that over a number of years it has been playing its part actively. For example, it has investigated the contribution of tropical pasture legumes to soil fertility and animal production. It has also undertaken a breeding programme to produce varieties of lucerne adapted to a much wider range of environments than the existing commercial varieties.

The Organisation has established main regional experiment centres in various parts of Queensland. Some are in the subtropical, humid coastal lands at places such as Beerwah, Howard, North Deep Creek, and Kin Kin. Queensland has large tracts of spear grass, somewhat like the Northern Territory. Investigations in this connection are being carried out in regions such as Rodd's Bay, Westwood, Brian Pastures, Eskdale West, and in brigalow regions, such as Nunbank and in other places as well. Of course, there is a tropical wet coastal region, and that does not escape attention, either. This work is being carried out constantly and some reward must be reaped for these endeavours at some time or other. As this work progresses slight improvement occurs which benefits the dairy industry and other grazing industries. So when we consider the assistance that is provided by the Department of Primary Industries in Queensland, what the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation is doing in the scientific field and also what is going out in the form of cash to augment dairy farmers' incomes, one can say that dairy farmers will continue their unwelcome work in the future.

I sincerely hope that dairy farmers will be able to carry on and enjoy greater prosperity than they have done in the past. If in the future it is necessary to increase the subsidy that we are considering at the present time, there should not be any hesitation at all on the part of the Commonwealth Government to do so. The real trouble is to get around such a huge area. This industry is not confined to a State or to a district. It is established over the whole of the Commonwealth. It would be very difficult at any time to gauge the prosperity of the dairy industry with any degree of accuracy, but of course records of the undertakings which receive milk and cream would disclose what is going out to them. As I said before, if this subsidy is paid for the benefit of this important industry, then the Australian Labor Party will not hesitate to vote in favour of it.

talk.start.para: - I rise as one of the final speakers on the Dairying Industry Bill. I have read with pleasure the various speeches that have been made in this chamber and in another place. I believe that in relation to this particular industry, the general discussions that have been advanced show a high level of knowledge of the industry. I believe that the industry will benefit as a result of the discussions that have taken place. Dairying has had its critics inside as well as outside the industry. Those of us who are interested should be anxious to examine the criticisms and, if they are applicable, we should see what can be done to improve the present situation. I believe that the dairying industry which has been established for so many years has demonstrated that it is capable of meeting the challenge that we find in the various comments and that it has sufficient answer to those comments.

speech.para: As I understand the position, there are basically five reasons why financial support is given to this particular industry. They are that reasonable returns should be provided to the industry; that a lower price for the products should be made available to the consumer; that there should be encouragement for greater production of a most nutritious health product; that there should be greater efficiency in production within the industry; and that the products should earn overseas exchange, which is of importance to the industry and to the Government at this particular time.

I have noted with interest that during the debates the Opposition has claimed that it introduced the subsidy which resulted in benefits flowing to this particular industry. I think that the record should be put straight. What the Labor Government did when it was in office was to thrust upon the industry - and it thought that, this was the correct principle - an award which the industry was unable to meet at the time. In an endeavour to make the industry capable of paying the high wages which were put upon it at that time, a subsidy was granted. The principle behind the subsidy was that it was a consumer subsidy and that the price to the consumer would not rise as a result of the increased costs that were thrust upon it.

I believe that if we look back to the great action of a former member for Gippsland in the Federal Parliament, Mr Paterson, we might find a more real foundation for the scheme as we know it today. If we look at the consumer position today we find that Australians pay less for butter than do people in any country other than New Zealand and the. United Kingdom. This is a fairly good point to advance when we are speaking of the industry's efficiency. We find that the wholesale prices of butter in February 1967 were: Australia 52.08c per lb, Canada 54.58c per lb, Denmark 61.73c per lb, the United States of America 66.88c pet lb and Western Germany 76.54c per lb. This gives a fair indication that the level of production in this industry compares more than favourably with that of countries which have a similar standard of living to Australia.

The support which is given to the industry is now an integral part of the industry. The industry's economy is based upon the continuance of this support. I emphasise that the industry generally and the stabilisation plan have been of assistance to the consumer. Those in the industry will agree with me when I say that our home market is the all important one. We can demonstrate that point by the fact that in the last fourteen years while wages have increased by approximately 46.6% and the consumer price index has increased by 39.3%, the price of butter has increased by only 21.5%. This again indicates that the industry is working well within the bounds of what is good for its economy and for its basic home market. I believe that retail prices have shown great stability in movement. I suggest that this industry could challenge most other industries in that field. It will be found that it compares more than favourably - and indeed it has a duty to do so - on a national level.

I am anxious to refer to a statement on this particular matter which was submitted by the Victorian Dairy Farmers Association. In the statement the Association emphasises this factor of stability by pointing out that during the period from 1953 to 1965 the recognised dairy farm cost of production, based on surveys and index adjustments carried out by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, increased by 24.5%, from 4s Id per lb to 5s Id per lb. The cost of production figure as at June 1966 calculated by the Council on the results of the Bureau's surveys, and taking into account the usual imputed costs, was 5s 4d per lb. The consumer price index for the six State capital cities issued by the Commonwealth Statistician showed an increase from 102.1 in the June quarter 1954 to 136.5 in the June quarter 1966. The basic wage increased by 39% to current levels. Dairy farmers therefore have suffered a decline in the real value of their returns. As a further illustration of the stability in butler prices, in 1961 the retail price of butter was 49.1c per lb. In the five years to May 1967 it has risen to 52c per lb. So the price of butter has been most stable.

The word 'marginal' has been used to support the argument that dairy farmers are inefficient. If the efficiency of dairy farmers were measured it would be possible to rule a line and say that above that line are the 50% of farmers who are efficient and below it are the farmers who are in all probability inefficient. I doubt that that could be a fair proposition. The same test could be applied to any primary or secondary industry. I doubt that sufficient emphasis has been placed upon the return received from dairy farming for the work load imposed upon dairy farmers. Remembering that at one time dairying was one of the bases of the development of this country, in the early stages when production was for the home market, when the industry undertook gradual increases in dairy herds and pasture improvement and when families in the industry worked so hard, we can justifiably claim that the industry has been most efficient.

In turning to study some of the reasons why restrictions have been placed upon dairying I believe it is of interest to refer to the report of August 1960 of the Dairying Industry Committee of Inquiry. It is now somewhat old, but it has been referred to on a number of occasions during this debate. I think it is important to record these facts although maybe some of them are not completely up to date. Nevertheless, they indicate a very interesting position. It is stated at page 127 of the report:

quote.para: The Bureau of Agricultural Economics has recently obtained some information regarding dairy farmers' views on the technical possibilities of using their farms for other types of land use. In the 1956 survey of 126 dairy farmers distributed throughout Australia the survey farmers were asked the following question: 'Are you restricted solely to dairy cattle and pigs?' Exactly half the farmers answered 'Yes' and the other half answered 'No'. The farmers who said that they were restricted to dairying were asked to give the reason why their farms could not be used for other types of land use.

speech.para: The reasons stated by farmers are set out in the following table:

One farmer claimed that milk production was too profitable for him to bother with other enterprises. We must give great credit to the Government for one proposition it has taken to its heart and has suggested to the industry. I refer to the proposed amalgamation of small dairy farms. I believe the basis of that proposition is worthy of study, not in respect of greater efficiency within the industry but with a view to producing greater returns for dairy farmers. Figures have been produced to show that the average annual earnings of some dairy farmers amount to $2,000 at present. Many honourable senators would agree that that cannot properly be claimed to be an adequate return. While the wishes of individuals in the industry should be observed I think every honourable senator will agree that the average return to dairy farmers should be increased.

The question of increased efficiency In the dairying industry is of national importance. Criticism of the industry has been made to me not only by people engaged in primary industry but also by people engaged in retailing and manufacturing in metropolitan areas, lt is amazing to me that wheat and wool producers should criticise the support given to the dairying industry, though f agree that everyone should be at liberty to criticise. If their criticisms are found to be correct, they should be put to the industry so that it may overcome its problems. I believe that nationally there is general support for our primary and secondary industries.

It is interesting to note that every one of our primary industries receives a subsidy, bounty or protection within the economy. It is surprising that dairy farmers appear over a period to have been singled out for attack in this respect. Producers of canned fruits, wheat, wool, wine and vegetable oil seeds are all assisted in some way. Tariff protection is available for all efficient manufacturing industries. The great motor, chemicals and airline industries receive a measure of support. It must certainly be disheartening for dairy farmers to be the subject of attacks when they have a better record than most other producers. Encouragement through pay roll tax credits is available to exporting industries. There is very little criticism of the S28m allocated for that purpose.

talk.start.para: - Exporters have to earn those credits in a hard field.

- 1 find very little point in that comment. I am saying that protection is given to industries through tariffs and depreciation allowances, and aid is also given through research grants. Shortly every honourable senator will have the opportunity to support the assistance given through research grants to secondary industries. All these protections are actually subsidies maintained by the Australian people. It is very difficult to accept that the dairying industry should be singled out for criticism.

speech.para: I wish to comment now on the volume of support given to one or two industries. I am not aware that this point has been raised in this debate. In 1963-64 the shipbuilding industry received financial support of about $4,700,000. The following year that support was increased to about $5,800,000.

talk.start.para: - The honourable senator should not take it that I am disagreeing with him.

-I am anxious to present these figures. In 1966 that support rose to $7,796,000. The petroleum search subsidy increased progressively from $2,700,000 in 1961 to $24,983,000 in 1965. The gold mining subsidy increased from $1,700,000 in 1964-65 to $2,300,000 in 1965-66. We have not heard anything about the raw cotton bounty but it was about Sim in 1963-64, about $2m in the following year and $3,686,000 in 1965-66.

speech.para: Generally the support of these industries is of national importance. 1 ag.xc with it. The national thinking of this Government has been wise. The proposition of supporting industries by maintaining subsidies is at least acceptable. If we are to view the dairy industry as one of great export importance because it earns SI I Om of overseas exchange per annum, it is interesting to note that almost every dairy industry in the world is subsidised or protected. The excellent legislative research section of our Parliamentary Library has prepared for me very detailed information on the policies of a number of countries.

In the European Economic Community, which we will be discussing a great deal in future months, the common policy for milk and milk products was introduced in November 1964. It is aimed principally at supporting producer income, lt covers fresh, preserved, concentrated or sweetened milk and cream, butter, cheese and curd, lactose and lactose syrups and certain animal feeding stuffs containing milk or milk products. In the transitional period extending until 1970, member countries are permitted to maintain their national guarantees to farmers. In order to reach the desired target level, market receipts may be supplemented by direct subsidies to producers and by measures for the regulation of the fresh milk market.

talk.start.para: - How much of the Common Market's subsidised production of milk and butter is exported to countries outside the present Common Market area or the proposed Common Market area?

- I cannot give the honourable senator that figure. I am drawing attention to comments in support of my statement that almost every dairy industry in the world is subsidised. An attack has been made on the Australian dairy industry.

speech.para: In the Netherlands a fixed support is paid for all manufacturing milk. In Norway the dairy policy continues to be implemented by means of two-year agreements between the government and the farmer organisations. The main purposes of those agreements are to maintain a level of milk production which meets, even in the low production season, the demand for liquid milk, butter and cheese, and to adjust production to demand and thus to avoid surpluses. In order to achieve those purposes, the government, amongst a variety of other things, subsidises milk prices in order to raise producer prices and to keep prices at an adequate level. United Kingdom dairy policy provides for a guaranteed price related to a standard quantity of milk.

In Canada there is a similar proposition, with support of production levels. The United States also has very protective policies. Imports of dairy products into that country are controlled and import quotas are in force for butter, cheese of certain types and varieties, dried milk products, butter oil and other articles with certain exceptions. In addition, quotas are already in force against other countries. Investigation shows that Belgium, France, Germany, Italy, Ireland, Norway, Switzerland, Japan and other countries provide protection and stabilisation for their dairy industries.

Senator Ormondemade an interesting comment which I believe the Australian dairy industry should note. It was in relation to the inroads that could be made into the dairy industry by new foods which are being marketed under the guise of being milk foods but which in fact are frozen flavoured water. I believe that these foods should be available to the public. I have noted over the past year or so the disparity between the prices of these frozen water products and milk products. I can see a consumer, not knowing the difference, being a little misled by the label. He will go for the cheaper product. Senator Ormonde's comment about this matter was very timely. I hope that the inroads into the dairy industry will not be so great that consumers will not see that in paying for milk products for children or adults they are buying products with much greater food value than the products that are in competition with milk products today.

Comments have been made about the margarine industry. The attitudes of some of the margarine manufacturers and the actions of the management of one company in particular indicate the quality of management that can be found in industry. The margarine industry is not the only one in Australia that has based its advertising on something that is just a little short of the truth. As I recollect the advertising, two important points have had the effect of making inroads into the dairy products industry. Firstly, the advertising of margarine has been related to the question of Australian production. It has been seeking to set one primary industry against another. The question has been asked: Why should not Australians have the opportunity to buy Australian products if they so desire. One margarine manufacturer se* out to prove to the people that it was accepting all the Australian production of edible vegetable oils and could not obtain sufficient for production requirements.

It is interesting to note the levels of Australian production of oils available from peanuts, safflower and cottonseed, lt is also interesting to note the growth of this industry. In 1962, 3,084 tons was produced; in 1963, 2,929 tons; in 1964, 3,893 tons; in 1965, 7,242 tons; and in 1966, 7,000 tons. The figures for Australian utilisation of edible vegetable oils were: in 1962, 23,538 tons; in 1963, 28,518 tons; in 1964, 34,163 tons; and in 1965, 36,814 tons, ft was necessary for the Australian industry to import 20,454 tons in 1962, 25,589 tons in 1963, 30,270 tons in 1964 and 29,572 tons in 1965. To summarise, with local production of something less than 20% of the current manufacturing demands, there is terrific scope for the producer to increase production, and for manufacturers to accept it, before we need to be concerned about that particular branch of primary industry not receiving its adequate share of the market.

talk.start.para: - Does the honourable senator realise that people are nol cooking in mutton fat only these days - that they are cooking in oil also?

- I know that some parties are being pretty well cooked in oil, but I do not know whether it is margarine or butter. However, what the honourable senator says is correct. The health factor is the other point on which the margarine industry has undoubtedly damaged the butter industry, for many people have in mind that the consumption of butter could have some effect on heart disease.
- The Country Party sells its butter and eats margarine.

- It would be interesting if the honourable senator were able to prove his point. I noticed that he did not do so when he spoke during this debate, but perhaps he will have an opportunity at a later stage to prove the truth of his statement; but he knows that it is not true. I have been brought up on milk and I am proud of the fact. I shall now discuss this problem associated with the health hazard, and I shall place on record what was stated in the 'Medical Journal of Australia' of 18th February 1967 in a report on a review of dietary fat and coronary heart disease. The report staled:

quote.para: In recent years there has been intensive research into the relationship between diet and coronary heart disease. The Sub-Committee has considered the results of thi: re-search and has reached the following general conclusions:
