item.para: The incidence of coronary heart disease and the severity of the underlying atherosclerotic lesions are related to the serum concentrations of certain lipids notably cholesterol and triglycerides. There is no proof that the relationship is a causal one.

Serum cholesterol levels can be reduced by: (a) reduction in dietary saturated fat content; (b) addition of poly-unsaturated fat to the diet: (c) reduction of dietary cholesterol levels; (d) reduction of body weight by caloric restriction.
These modifications of dietary fat do not appear to have any detrimental effect on health.
The available evidence does not indicate whether or not the severity of atherosclerosis or the risk of coronary heart disease is reduced when serum lipid levels are lowered by changing the diet.
The risk of coronary heart disease is above average in persons who are overweight.
Excessive body weight can be reduced by caloric restriction.
The risk of coronary heart disease appears to be lessened after weight reduction.

speech.para: Last year France consumed twice the amount of butter per head consumed in the United Slates of America, yet on a per capita basis the United States has almost four times more deaths than France from heart disease.

I believe that the general level of advertising by the margarine industry has drawn no particular credit to those who have managed that aspect. It leads me to believe either that there is a terrific margin of profit in this industry or that enormous support is coming from beyond our shores for the establishment of the margarine industry. I hope that should this industry prove an efficient manufacture it will enter the export field. I only hope that for Australia's benefit its truth in advertising overseas is a little better than has been demonstrated in past years inside Australia.

It can be demonstrated that over a twelve year period there has been a gradual increase in production of dairy products. It is interesting to note that there has been a rise in the yield per cow of approximately 10.7 gallons per annum. In 1953 the yield per cow was 401 gallons per annum; today it is 467 gallons and the annual milk output at the present time about 1,516,000 gallons. It is interesting to note that on page 8 of the 'Statistical Bulletin of the Dairy Industry', volume 29, number 14, the average annual production of whole milk per cow for each State is set out. At the present time South Australia leads the rest of the States, closely followed by Victoria. Then follow Tasmania, the Australian Capital Territory. New South Wales and Queensland in that order. But the general facts are disclosed not so much in that particular report as in the general increase in production per cow. This is not an easy matter to discuss, for things such as the breeding of cows and feeding come into it. These are matters in which the industry has shown great efficiency. I believe that the Government, in holding the bounty at S27m, has not treated the industry fairly, although I put the proposition to the industry that it was in support of the bounty remaining at this figure. If we accept that the S27m is to cover the past five years and the next five years, my calculation is that during that period th; industry will have demonstrated efficiency that will probably result in something like a 25% drop in the value of the subsidy during the period, and that the industry has been able to cope. While in other industries the amount of support is increasing, the dairy industry is held - and is anxious to be held in the interests of efficiency - to a level of support over a tenyear period.

talk.start.para: - What about the marginal farmer? The honourable senator does not talk about him.

- I had something to say about the marginal farmer, in relation to the size of farms. I suggested that some consideration should be given to the amalgamation of farms. The expression 'marginal* in relation to farms and properties is something that I have not heard explained properly here by anyone with any wisdom. Individuals who say that an income of $2,000 per annum is far too low in the dairying industry would find that a dairy farmer receiving $2,000 is probably much better off than an individual getting 25% more than that in some other line of endeavour. I do not know whether we are to be a country which will nominate where a particular person will work. I hope that we do not do this, but it may be the choice of some people to get dairy farmers with low incomes out of the industry.

speech.para: I was about to say that the money saved by the Commonwealth in not increasing the subsidy could go to the industry through other avenues. This could be achieved by several methods. We have seen a considerable increase in the production per head of animals over a short period. This comes about in one or two ways. The benefit that can be achieved in increased quality by the use of artificial insemination is most important. Finance is one of the factors restricting the expansion of this important area of assistance to the industry. I think it will be found that on many dairy farms today - far too many for my liking - there is perhaps a stud bull or any run-of-the-mill bull which is in actual fact only bringing the cows round to their next lactation period. We should be persuading the farmer that for the good of the nation the most important thing that we can do is to increase the production of the cow quickly. I suggest that support to co-operatives that are doing such excellent work in this field should perhaps be given by way of finance from the Commonwealth to the various State governments that are assisting in this matter at present.

Greater consideration must be given not only to breeding but also to types of food and food concentrates and to an increase in the use of pasture improvement. I wish to put forward one point which I think will be of great assistance to the industry in the next ten years. I know that here I will meet some argument from the farming community. We are on the brink of great advances in the use of automatic data processing, commonly called ADP. I believe that we will follow the movement in which America is involved at present. Here is a branch of science that we are just commencing to use. Within the dairying industry and within primary production generally we should direct our attention to it. The Federal Government could put somebody into this particular field within primary industry to look into the advantages that can be gained.

talk.start.para: - Does the honourable senator think that the cows could understand it?

- Some cows would and some cows would not. I believe that it must be demonstrated to the farmer that efficiency can be gained by this method. I doubt whether the average farmer - I say average because there are those who are above the average and those who are below - would know accurately day by day the production per cow in his herd. ADP will assist. As the cow reduces production through its lactation period, there comes a time when it ceases to be efficient or economic. Data could be fed by means of computerisation to some central office. By the taking of specimens of milk, as is done today, the fat content of the milk being produced could be determined. By relating this to breeding we could in actual fact increase the efficiency of production per head much quicker than we are doing today.

speech.para: The average farmer today spends a great deal of money in putting on his land manure, superphosphate and nitrogenous and other fertilisers, whatever may be the encouragement for their use today. Applications may be at the rate of 1 cwt, or 96 lb to the acre, or at some other rate, depending on the type of ground in he various paddocks on the property. With the aid of computers we could indicate to him whether the rate should be 20 lb to the acre or 3 cwt to the acre. We could tell him whether he was getting increased production or no effect from the money he was spending. Perhaps the Department of Primary Industry could give a lead in this matter. The other day we heard of the Commonwealth Government spending $4m to add to an already extensive Commonwealth computer system. Perhaps some slot could be provided for primary industry to get into this most important field.

talk.start.para: - In what department was that?
- Through the Treasury and the Bureau of Census and Statistics.
- That is a pretty broad reply.

- It is a pretty accurate reply. My final point is to congratulate this industry on the success that it has had and to recommend - although I know that it needs no recommendation from myself or any other senator - the establishment of reconstituted milk factories in various countries around the world. This is a matter of particular significance. Since it appeared some years ago that the United Kingdom might enter the European Common Market, the dairying industry, mainly through the Victorian Dairy Products Board, has made a remarkable attempt to secure in some overseas countries outlets for reconstituted milk products. This is not an easy proposition. One might say that the advantages of what we in Australia are encouraging some countries to do are obvious. We have set up in our own country factories to manufacture the product and if I may make the suggestion perhaps we could give an overseas country an interest in the proposition. These factories are running efficiently and they provide a wonderful adjunct to the export market for Australian products, lt appears to be particularly wise. We can dry the product here and send it overseas, thereby cutting down the cost of transport and handling. Overseas the powder is reconstituted and put on the market in the form of milk and other products. We hear of a starving country such as India. Surely we should have half a dozen plants established there. What a wonderful thing it would be for that country if we could do that. If Britain should join the European Common Market we shall certainly have an excess production, particularly of dairy products This would be a wonderful opportunity to dispose of them to a people sorely in need of nutritious food, but in various countries we find there are trade or internal finance policies which prohibit this particular type of activity. This applies to India. Encouragement will need to be given to the Aus tralian Dairy Produce Board to try through its various agencies to get other countries to instal reconstituted milk factories. The exporting efficiency of the dairying industry is shown by the fact that today it sells its products in more than ninety-four countries. In all probability this year exports will extend to over 100 countries, indicating that this is an industry which challenges comparison with any other industry, primary or secondary, within this Commonwealth.

- I see in this Bill two significant features. Firstly, there is the proposal to continue the subsidy for a further five years at the present rate of $27m a year. Secondly, there is the aspect to which I shall turn my attention shortly, that, as far as 1 can see, neither the Bill nor the Minister's second reading speech contains any concrete or definite proposals to reorganise this industry to meet the problems which confront it. Certainly passing reference is made to proposals to provide accommodation through certain banking institutions or through a part of the banking structure to enable people on the land to obtain finance more readily. I hope this will be available at a better rate of interest than at present operates. Despite the fact that the dairying industry was reviewed in 1960 - I have before me the report of the Dairy Industry Committee of Inquiry of August 1960 - and despite the fact that certain recommendations and prognostications were made, we still are presented with a proposal to do something for another five years which differs only minutely from the proposal which has operated over the past five years. Let me deal more particularly with the dairying industry stabilisation plan. I invite the Senate to recall that the proposal to stabilise the industry was introduced by a Labor government in 1947. It is proper that I should remind honourable senators of that fact and, if any reminder is needed, of the fact that the Opposition has a very deep interest in the welfare of this industry.

speech.para: The provision of a bounty for this industry relates closely to procedures and practices which are followed in certain other sectors of primary and secondary industry in Australia. Any criticism levelled at the proposition that the dairying industry should be supported in this way falls down when one considers the fact that the tariff, for instance operates to protect certain secondary industries in this country. Criticism of primary industry by those who are in the corner of, say, secondary industry can be reversed and quite easily turned against secondary industry because of the level of protection which is afforded secondary industry by way of tariff and otherwise. We must also bear in mind that the application of tariff protection to secondary industry quite frequency operates very much against the interests cf the primary producer of Australia.

I want to try to reach some kind of rationalisation of how the amount of S27m per annum was reached as the bounty to be paid over the next five years. Surely one cannot argue that the bounty will maintain the status quo, because everyone in this chamber knows that costs have risen over the past five years and it would be quite remarkable if we were to lull ourselves into thinking that there would be no increase in cos's against this industry in the next five years. I suggest that the amount has been selected arbitrarily. It is an amount equal to that which has been agreed upon and paid in the past. It appears that someone in the Government has said: 'We have no SOl U ion of the problems confronting this industry. Therefore, as some kind of sop and so that it will not be strong in its condemnation of us for not proposing a positive plan, we will continue th; subsidy at the present amount of S27m. It has been accepted in the pas!, let us hope it will be accepted in the future. Let us get on with the job for another five years.' That is not good enough. If a bounty is to be paid to support this industry, no-one in this place could argue sensibly and logically that the amount which has been granted in the past should be the amount granted for the future. lt is six years since the Committee made its findings available to the Government, but no plan of any real consequence is yet before the Government, so it says to the industry: "We will give you this S27m a year, lt is what we paid you in the past an'l you have been reasonably quiet about it so let us hope you will remain quiet in the future. Let us get on with the job'. This is not good enough particularly when we take into account the problems of tha industry and the genuine and sincere endeavours which have b?en made in the past, and I trust will be made in the future, by people in the industry to try to eke out some kind of livelihood.

Senator Websterreferred to the problem associated with the size of properties. This is a very real problem. Whereas once upon a time a person could get by fairly well milking thirty dairy cows which turned in a production per cow of about 200 lb of butter fat a year, these days one would have to milk forty very good dairy cows and have an annual production of 300 lb of butler fat to make a living. Let us suppose that the property upon which a farmer milked the thirty cows has noi been extended and he is now endeavouring to milk forty cows on it. This means that production from that property must be increased. There has to be resort to irrigation; there has to be resort to heavier applications of fertiliser: there has to be resort to the purchase of additional machinery to keep abreast of modern practices in agriculture; there has to b: an improvement in dairy techniques and there has to be the employment of the latest technology in this field. All of these things cost money, so the diary farmer's difficulties continue,

When dealing with the economics o': individual families I am not so concerned with the larger producer as with the relatively small producer. We must recognise that dairying is the fifth largest primary industry in Australia, and the small Dro.ducer makes a very valuable contribution to this section of primary industry. He is compelled, as was mentioned by Senator Webster, to upgrade the quality of his herd and to adopt the latest techniques available to him. He must bear in mind all the time that the cost of doing this is ever on the increase. He is confronted with a problem to which I think too little attention has been given in the past, the problem of obtaining the finance with which to improve his property, to adopt the latest techniques and to put in the various new installations so necessary on a modern dairy farm. He is actually no better off. In fact, I suggest very seriously to the Senate that he is in a much worse position than he was in the past. His position has deteriorated. 1 return to the $27m subsidy, which is a kind of blanket payment made on the basis of production without regard to the particular and special problems of the small operator. I have the deepest regard for the small dairy farmer and 1 would have liked to see a display of courage in the introduction of a scheme which I believe is so necessary to deal with the modern-day problem of providing greater assistance to the small operator through the medium of this subsidiary and, of course, in other ways as well. I do not believe in the blanket kind of approach which favours the dairy farmers who are in reasonably good circumstances. I refer here to the bigger operators, those with 100 and more dairy cows and quite extensive holdings. They are not in as much difficulty financially as are the small operators.

talk.start.para: - Does the honourable senator want a means test on efficiency?

- 1 want a sense of realism to be brought into this so that we can do the things that this Government has talked so much about to retain people in the country areas of Australia and to promote this idea of decentralisation. Since the war, I believe about 15,000 primary producers of Australia have left the land and flocked to the cities. What good is that doing this country? We want to see decentralisation. We want to be practical about it. If we are going to preach decentralisation then, for goodness sake, let us do something positive about it. In the two years that I have been here I and other honourable senators have been talking about these things, but I do not believe that one positive step has been taken by this Government to bring about the decentralisation about which we talk so much and do so little.

speech.para: I say that it is a question of need here. There is a necessity to sustain people in the field of primary industry where they can be of most value to the Australian community. It is as simple as that. In the main, these people have been born and bred on properties in the country. In many instances they are the stock of pioneers. I believe that we owe some sort of debt to them because their forebears went into these areas of the country, rolled up their sleeves, cleared the heavy timber and scrub and cut out their properties. They did not have very much in their day but they were able to say they had done something towards the development of this nation and I think they are entitled to recognition for this. So the generations have gone on until we see in these areas today second and third generations of farmers who ought to be entitled to say: 'The fruits of our labour are coming back to us.' But, instead of this being the case, the position is becoming more and more acute as time goes on and we are going to see this continual drift away from the land. 1 do not think this is a good thing. I have seen it in the area in which I was farming myself a few years ago. There I saw old pioneering families which had done so much for this country in the past being compelled to leave properties because of the economic circumstances which exist there. We have a very solemn responsibility in connection with this money that we are giving. Over a period of five years, we are going to spend from the public purse the sum of $135m ostensibly and presumably for the purpose of making sure that this industry is a viable proposition.

item.label: I.
item.para: suggest to the Government as seriously as I possibly can that the way in which we are handling this matter now - this mere blanket approach to the problem - does not do anything at all to cure the ills of this industry about which we have heard so much during the course of this debate. There are no definite plans for reorganisation. Certainly there are references in the Minister's second reading speech to things which can come about, but there is nothing definite. Had the Government had the interests of this industry seriously at heart, knowing the condition in which it is, one would have expected that in this day and age, conscious of its responsibility in the expenditure of public funds, the Government would have come up with a definite plan for the rehabilitation of the industry to give it an opportunity of surviving.

speech.para: I have heard in the course of this debate and I have read in the course of the past few days that dairying is being carried on in parts of Australia over a lactation period of five months and with a production per cow of only 75 lb of butter fat a year. Surely this is the problem which has to be tackled and overcome. If areas of country upon which dairying is being carried out are not suitable for this purpose, then part of this money that is being expended year by year through the system of bounties that operates at the moment ought to be utilised on some plan that should have been developed by this time for examining the potential of properties for higher production and greater output. If this is not a feasible proposition, the person concerned should be put into some other form of agriculture from which he could derive a reasonable livelihood and so he able to fulfil his obligations and responsibilities to the community. I suggest again that no dairy farmer can carry on a property on the basis of a five months lactation period and an annual butter fat return of only 75 lb a cow.

Yet these properties do exist in Australia. Possibly it is a question of going into the practicability of irrigation projects - not small fiddling backyard irrigation projects, but large scale projects which can rehabilitate whole areas. Let us face it: one cannot go out into the back of beyond and set up a dairy farm without having an outlet for one's product. The best systems that can be employed in circumstances such as these are those where facilities for the treatment of the product after it leaves the farm are readily available. There is no point in sending the products of a dairy 200 miles or more to the nearest processing factory. Rehabilitation of these areas has to be undertaken on a large scale, having regard to the potential of the area with the use of superphosphate and nitrogenous fertilisers with the use of irrigation. While we continue willy nilly to hand out year by year such a sum as S27m without regard to these factors I suggest we are failing in our responsibility to the public of this country to ensure that funds of this kind are put to the best possible use.

The system of subsidies to this industry has operated since 1947. My reading tells me that at one stage since its inception £21m or $42m was provided in one year. I fancy that on another occasion since the scheme was initiated £18m or $36m was provided to assist the industry. The scheme was introduced twenty years ago and at the present time we are paying out something less than that by way of bounty. I will grant that particular circumstances operated in those years when the higher subsidies were paid, but again I say we are begging the question by saying that all the industry needs is an injection of $27m from the Government and that is that. It is not that at all.

I put it to the Senate that ten years ago it was estimated that every farm in England received a subsidy of about £900 a year. So this subsidy we are paying at the present time is not a very magnificent gesture to this industry when we find that in a country like the United Kingdom subsidies of the character to which I have referred are paid out. Again, while we talk a good deal about the free enterprise society of the United States of America, I think we ought to bear in mind also that in the course of a year the Government of the United Slates of America passes out something between S500m and S600m. So this bounty which we pay to the dairying industry is not something unusual. Frankly, 1 have very little time for people who criticise the fact that we are granting a subsidy to the dairying industry of Australia.

This industry provides direct and indirect employment to 600,000 people or 5% of the total population of Australia each year. There are 500 factories of one kind or another treating and processing dairy products. These factories employ 12,000 people and their annual payroll is in the vicinity of S50m. I mention these figures to the Senate to indicate that this is not just a small industry; it is a very big Australian industry. It is extremely valuable to this country. The price now received for butte, fat on the farms throughout Australia to my knowledge is less than it was in 1954. I would have to give and take a little here because I am not completely au fait with the point but I believe that the dairy farmers are receiving in the vicinity of 40c to 41c per lb for butter fat. This figure is below that which they were receiving in 1954. It is about equivalent to the figure that they received in 1956. The returns have not increased despite all the bounties that are involved in the running of an industry of this kind. The costs and so on that have occurred in that time have left the position that the return per lb of butter fat has not increased in the last decade. So, the dairy farmers who have been able to stay on their properties have had to absorb pretty substantial costs. They must have engaged to the limit of their capacity in the latest technological practices and so on that are taking place in this industry.

The availability of finance to assist the dairy farmers and primary producers generally in Australia has been pretty poor over the years. There have been countless occasions in the past when the injection of a bit of borrowed capital into the activities of the man on the land would have enabled him to institute practices and to provide machinery, implements, and things of that kind which would have assisted him greatly. But the interest rates that were being charged to him were crippling to the extent that, very often, he could not take up finance even if it was available to him. This points to one of the great difficulties facing the dairy farmer.

I can recall that, a few years ago, a very good farmer on the north-west coast of Tasmania with assets of £18,000 had, because of illness, to go out of production for a short period. He was rehabilitated. He needed £3,000 cash to restock his property and to get it under way again. Not only did he have to submit to the normal form of borrowing by way of mortgage, but also his bank manager called him in a few days later and said: 'Look, I do not think that the security that you have made available to us is good enough. I am afraid that I have to request you to undertake a second mortgage'. The farmer said: 'Goodness gracious me, I. have banked with this institution all my life. I am not a fly-by-night type of person. I have a farm property. 1 have housing property. On your estimation, 1 have £18,000 worth of capital property. You are asking me to go to a second mortgage. I will sell my farm and gel off before I will do that at an interest rate of 7% or 8%'. I suggest to the Senate that a person cannot pay that sort of money and carry on in an industry as valuable and as vital as the dairying industry is.

I know that this problem has hit many dairy farmers. Again 1 refer to the position of the large producer as against the position of the small producer. The large producer, by and large, can obtain financial accommodation with ready facility most times. But the small man, because of his difficult financial position and because he needs the net income from his farm finds it extremely difficult to meet any additional financial commitment in the servicing of loans and this sort of thing. I notice that in his second reading speech the Minister for Repatriation (Senator McKellar) made reference to a farm development loan fund through the Development Bank. I suggest that this was very little more than a passing reference to the proposal to set up this fund. This is one of the matters that ought to be looked at very seriously, I believe. If the small operator in the Australian farming community is to be sustained - he is an awfully valuable citizen there - then we need to have a much better regard for his welfare than we have had in the past. 1 suggest that we will not achieve this by passing out a subsidy in respect of butter fat to sustain him. Ultimately he will succumb to the difficulties unless he can see that we are interested in his welfare and that we are prepared to do something positive and realistic to help sustain him in his position. I cannot see that there is any hope for him to stay on his property unless we do this. What do we find then? Senator Webster referred to the question of amalgamation. We find the proposal of amalgamation. When this happens, a drift away from the farming community takes place. Another family leaves the Australian rural community.

talk.start.para: - That is not necessarily so.
- This can be so and it usually is so.
- But it would not be necessarily so.

- It does not have to be so. But let us look at the situation and find out just what is happening .in the rural community. If a farmer has approximately 100 acres of land, he may be able to make a go of it because he can run only a certain number of cows on it. He cannot go to work for the local council or the public works department, whichever it may be in his area, as so many farmers do. He cannot do this in his area. Ultimately he has to sell out and his property is amalgamated with another. 1 know of instances of this happening. The farmer takes his family and drifts into the town. We have a backward move as far as those who are proponents of decentralisation are concerned. This is a retrograde step. Some means has to be found to counter and overcome this drift. If we cannot do this, at least let us be honest and say to these farmers: 'The best think that you can do is pack up and get out. Go into the towns and the cities and let the big operator take over your properties.' These people are extremely important to me. Surely we want to see these people happily settled in these rural communities where they are doing a valuable job for Australia. Surely this is what we want in preference to perpetuating these takeovers and monopolies which have been such a feature of the postwar life of Australia. This state of affairs has not done us a great deal of credit, I suggest.

speech.para: Recent trends relating to butter factory organisation and so on throughout Australia suggest to me that a kind of lethargy has overtaken the people who otherwise could have gone more deeply into the technological processes of the industry and who might be able to convert these processes to the benefit of the people who are their suppliers. The Labor Party, let me put it to the Senate, has had as its policy as far as the rural community is concerned the preservation of the interests of the producer and the consumer. We do not say in our policy that we are deeply concerned with the welfare of the middle man. We say that our concern is for the producer and the consumer. Further, we say that it is part and parcel of our policy to support the proposition of co-operative organisation. The ideal is to have an organisational set-up in the rural communities of Australia where the farmer can carry on with production, can send his product to an organisation for treatment and processing and can receive his return from that organisation. I suggest that a good promotional gimmick would be available there in the fact that if the co-operative organisations could handle, as many of them do, the marketing side of the product which goes through its factory organisation, the consumer will receive a better go also. This can be made so obvious if one looks at the position of the whole milk industry in Australia.

Let us take for instance the fact that 10 gallons of milk produces 1 gallon of cream from which 4 lb of butter fat is obtained. Therefore, 21 gallons of milk would produce 1 lb of butter fat generally for which the producer is receiving about 40c or 41c per lb. Now the consuming public throughout Australia buys milk in individual bottles at 10c each. So there is a return of $2 on 2i gallons of milk. The butter fat producer receives out of this production about 40c to 41c plus the deferred pay, which will come from the factory in due course, of another 5c. The person buying whole milk at the door day by day pays at the level of S2 for the same amount of milk. This is one of the things that should have been inquired into for the purpose of achieving some sort of rationalisation. In certain areas of Tasmania two or three organisations are buying the available milk. The farmer who supplies a butter factory receives 40c per pound of butter fat. Certainly, he may keep the skim milk. A farmer supplying Cadbury-Fry-Pascall Pty Ltd receives 52c per pound of butter fat. A farmer who is lucky enough to supply the whole milk market gets a substantially greater return. These various levels of return all apply in the one industry.

Strong criticism might well be levelled at the co-operative butter factories because, so it seems, they have been content to do nothing for years and to allow somebody else to skim off the cream, if I may use that phrase. They ought to have been wide awake to the latest trends and developments in countries such as Sweden and the United States of America where ultra heat methods of treating milk are used. It should have been possible for them to develop a system of collecting supplies by means of tankers that could travel throughout the dairying areas collecting milk at the dairy or wherever else the farmer chooses to have it collected for delivery to the factory.

Depending on the trend in the market from day to day or week to week - whichever seems best - milk could be used for the whole milk market or for the manufacture of cheese, butter, milk powder, casein or some other product. Ultra heat methods of treating milk could be used, enabling it to be kept for up to three months without refrigeration. This sort of arrangement in the industry would cut costs substantially because deliveries would not have to be made from day to day as at present. Furthermore, the producer would benefit by better returns from the factory since it would have facilities to treat the whole of the farmer's product according to the situation of the market from day to day or week to week. If there were a strong call for powder for reconstitution later in some other part of Australia, the factory ought to be able to produce powder to meet the demand. We certainly ought to be turning our attention to this field of production. If there were a requirement for butter for export or for some other dairy product, the factory ought to be able to supply the demand. The co-operative factories ought to make surveys from time to time to determine current trends at any particular time.

If these methods were adopted producers would get the best possible returns from the co-operative factories. Consumers also would benefit because dairy products would be available to them at prices they could afford to pay. I believe that, despite the promotional efforts that have been made in the last few years to increase the consumption of butter, milk and other dairy products, the record will show that there has been a decline in the per capita consumption of butter and of whole milk, which is a valuable food product.

talk.start.para: - We have found evidence of a decline in consumption.

- That is so. The reason is that people just cannot afford to meet continual increases in the prices of these products that are necessary to sustain life. Before I pass to another matter let me say that I earnestly hope that those who are engaged in the management of co-operative dairy factories will get out of their chairs and have a look at the latest trends in the industry in an endeavour to cash in on the undoubted market that is available for the new products that are now seeing the light of day. A few months ago in Tasmania a private organisation installed equipment purchased from Sweden to treat whole milk by means that would enable it to be kept for three months without refrigeration. So great has been the demand for the new product that the company, I believe, is shortly to take delivery of a second set of equipment. There has been a tremendous demand for the new product in South East Asia, New Guinea and even Australia. It is interesting to note, Mr Acting Deputy President, that it is now possible to supply cream treated by this process to Port Moresby in New Guinea at half the price that was previously paid there for cream.

speech.para: This gives an indication of the potential market in Asia for products of this kind. I believe that if the people of Asian countries had a standard of living measuring up to ours we would be unable to supply anything like the volume of dairy products that they would require. The co-operative dairy factories should have investigated the ultra heat treatment process and should already have in operation plants using this process. Had they adopted it, they would have been able to give the producers a much better return for their labours and the consuming public would have been able to get a good product at much lower prices than they are at present paying.

Last Thursday Senator Wright mentioned the impact on the returns to primary producers made by decisions arrived at from time to time by the wage fixing tribunals of Australia. In his remarks there seemed to be implied the suggestion that the whole responsibility for the economic plight Df Australia and of various sections of industry throughout the country rested on the shoulders of the working man.. Nothing could be further from the truth. I suggest to you, Sir, that wage and salary earners are the only ones in Australia who have to go before tribunals to justify increases in their income. They have to justify increased wages and salaries on the basis of cost increases throughout the community from time to time. However, any increase in wages and salaries is eroded almost overnight by the rapacity of some sections of industry. As soon as the basic wage is raised there is a clamour for an increase in prices. The seller of a commodity is not required to justify a price increase before any tribunal, court or judicial body. It is necessary only for him to go round his shop and mark up the prices of the commodities that he sells. In these circumstances, the value of any wage increase given to the workers of Australia is lost to them almost overnight.

Some years ago when an increase in margins was granted to the workers I was horrified to hear what was do:ne by one shopkeeper. That increase meant about ls 3d a day, or approximately 6s a week, for the workers. The morning after it was awarded, a shopkeeper in Tasmania who sold prams, bassinets and other things needed by young couples to raise their families - articles that are necessaries of life for young couples raising families - went round his shop and marked up every item by 10%. The wage increase had made no impact on him whatsoever, but that was his approach to it. That is the sort of thing that has been happening for years. What did the Government do about it on that occasion? This Government is supposed to be greatly concerned about the incomes of wage and salary earners, but it did absolutely nothing. In effect, it condones the sort of objectionable practice that occurs whenever a wage increase is awarded. As I have said, wage rises arc taken from the workers almost overnight by practices such as this.

talk.start.para: - In the instance mentioned, was not the matter in the hands of the Tasmanian Government?

- lt was in the hands of the National Government, which stood idly by and made no attempt to deal with the situation. Having made absolutely certain that wages and salaries will be controlled by the arbitration processes that it administers, the Federal Government absolutely vacates the field when it comes to a question of preserving the value of wages and salaries and enabling the workers, on whom the prosperity of this country depends, and who have created the nation's wealth, to retain the benefit of wage increases that they are awarded. lt is beyond doubt that an> increase in wages and salaries granted by the operation of the arbitration processes of this nation hits the dairy industry and other industries. This is bound to happen. Until the Government wakes up to the fact that the stabilisation of the nation's economy involves two factors - the prices of goods as well as wages and salaries - we shall be faced with this inflationary spiral, which does us no credit. Let Senator Wright speak to somebody else about what happens as a result of wage and salary increases. Do not let him try to sell it to me because this system has been continuing for years.

speech.para: The only result of the Government's abject failure to do anything about controlling costs and prices is to make it just that little bit more difficult for us to sell our goods on world markets. This is a competitive world with competitive markets. Until we wake up to the fact that there are responsibilities on both sides and until the Government realises that you cannot stop the flow of a river by putting a dam half way across, we will have these perpetual problems with us. I am on the side of the salary and wage earner because after all he is the person who by the sweat on his brow and by working with his hands for this country has created prosperity. He is entitled to share in it.

Let me make one final observation about the dairying industry. Let us face facts. We know that the dairying industry in Australia has problems, but the Government will not solve those problems by year after year taking out of the public purse some $27m and saying to the dairy farmers: 'Split that up amongst you.' I know that there are trends in this industry which will lead to its ruin as a viable and valuable industry in Australia. Until we get to the stage in this place where we are prepared to be men enough and women enough to face up to the fact that problems exist in the industry and to do something positive to overcome them, we will just beg the question as we have done for so many years in the past.

talk.start.para: - Mr Acting Deputy President. I am really surprised that debate on a Bill on which both sides of the chamber are in reasonable agreement has taken so long and has brought forward so many figures. 1 should have thought that it would have been possible to have dealt with this Bill and to have brought forward some suggestions in a much shorter time. I am speaking at this stage, nol to add further to the extensive debate that has taken place on this Bill, but more or less to clinch the nail which has been driven and which I feel has been submerged in the mass of figures and arguments that has been introduced. It seems to me that there is a place in this debate for someone to advance the arguments from the viewpoint of the dairy farmer himself. Although some speakers who I feel have had some close association with the industry have skirted around this point, I think that the speaker who got closest to it was Senator Webster who apparently was reared on a dairy farm. Anyway, he drank some of the milk that was produced on the farm and was able to speak about it.

speech.para: I warn to raise a few points as a person who actually owned and operated a dairy farm for some years. I think that in raising these points in fairly strong terms 1 can clinch this nail which has been driven on this side of the chamber but which, as I have said, has been lost in a mass of figures and arguments. I think that my experience has been most valuable because it has given me the opportunity of seeing the point of view of the small dairy farmer. I took over a property which had excellent possibilities but which represented an impossible job for the farmer who ran it. He was milking twenty-seven cows which was a very small number for the size of the property. He used to get up at five o'clock in the morning and hand milk twenty-seven cows. When he had finished he drew water from a well in order to water the stock. He had a rest then because he needed it, and he started milking again at three o'clock in the afternoon.

talk.start.para: - 1 thought that the honourable senator was referring to drawing water for the purpose of watering down the milk.

- No. lt was for the stock which needed it. This was a good property but the farmer could not make ends meet. He could not develop the property to its potential. He had to give it up. 1 took it over from the Agricultural Bank. I did not have extensive financial backing but I had some finance. In a very short time it was possible to instal a milking machine which enabled me to increase the herd which could be carried, lt was possible at no great expense to instal a windmill which would provide water. Later, it was possible to construct dams. This made the property a good proposition because stock could obtain water whenever they needed in the paddocks in which they were situated. The result of this was that 1 had plenty of time on my hands, which my predecessor did not have, with which to develop the property. 1 put down good permanent pastures and arranged for irrigation in order to bring the property to a stage where it was able to function as a financial proposition. This experience to which I am pointing is relevant to the position of small dairy farmers particularly in the south west of Western Australia.
- Does not the honourable senator think that that is an indication of the results of efficiency and inefficiency and that this is something that should be looked at in this industry?

- That is so. 1 had intended to refer later to Senator Webster's remarks because I thought ha was right on the ball in a number of statements that he made about the industry and what should be done. I am happy to do that now. The point about the industry in the south west of Western Australia, which is the land that 1 know best, is that in the early days heavy timber had to be removed in order to put down pastures. Initially, this was done by farmers who were just making ends meet. But later, particularly when the war service land settlement scheme commenced in Western Australia, this work was done by contractors on behalf of the Government and the property was then handed over to the farmer. It was ready for him to fence, to stock and to put in pastures. Of course at that stage he was billed for a tremendous capital cost. Our experience in Western Australia has been that we have had to write off large sums of money in respect of dairy farm land in order to help these dairy farmers to carry on. I want honourable senators to understand the point that I am making from my own experience and from what others have seen. Because these farmers had a millstone around their necks as a result of the capital which had been invested in the properties they were unable to improve either the carrying capacity of the farm or the stock which they were carrying.

speech.para: At this stage I want to draw attention to the remarks of Senator Prowse who believed that the industry had reached a quite high degree of efficiency. I was pleased to hear that in his opinion there was nothing to worry about, so far as dairy farmers were concerned. This was also borne out by Senator Lillico and Senator Benn who referred to average acreages in the various States of Australia, which really surprised me. I know this area in Western Australia fairly well. I shall take Western Australia because that is the only State about which I can speak with some authority. I find that the average acreage of a dairy farm is 470 acres according to the figures that were presented by Senator Benn. An average of 470 acres seems rather large for dairy farms. 1 know of plenty of dairy farms of about 100 acres. For the average dairy farm to be 470 acres in Western Australia there must be some pretty big dairy farms there. I do not question the accuracy of the honourable senator's figure. I am just wondering how it is arrived at. Honourable senators will notice that the figures he gave for Western Australia are singularly high.

talk.start.para: - He is a Queenslander, is he not?

- The average for Queensland was 433 acres and for Western Australia it was 470 acres. When a farmer has a highly productive dairying property he may also have another property on which he puts down clover for dry stock. It seems to me that in calculating the averages quoted by Senator Benn regard has not been had to that factor and that the properties on which dry stock are run have been included in the calculations. The land on which dry stock are run cannot properly be counted as dairying land. Senator Benn also said that on the average farm of 470 acres, an area of 359 acres was under pasture.
- What were those areas sown to?

- It is not stated. It simply says 'pasture'. I presume the figure of 359 acres relates in Western Australia to outlying areas carrying subterranean clover. Dry stock are run on such land together with vealers. Senator Benn also stated that Western Australia has a high average number of dairy cows to a herd. He said that the average is 124 - higher than any other State - and that the next highest is 90 in New South Wales. This surprises me. From my experience in Western Australia I cannot imagine that it is correct. I believe that the numbers of vealers must have been included in the calculations, but they are not dairy cows.
- Does the honourable senator think that the figures are reliable?

- I am not sure of the source from which Senator Benn obtained the figures, but he made quite a feature of them and used them as the basis of a lot of his arguments. He said that the average gallonage per cow in Western Australia was 468. That also surprised me, because 1 know that on average the result has not been anywhere near that figure.
- The figures must be taken from the 'Benn Report'.

- I am not sure where the figures came from, but the honourable senator vouched for them. The next figures given relate to the quantity of milk produced by each cow in Western Australia and the average amount of income received by the farmers. I have made some conservative calculations. An average dairy farmer in Western Australia with a property of 470 acres, a herd of 100 cows - I am not using the figure of 124 because it is necessary to allow for dry stock - and an average gallonage of 468 for each cow, with an average butter fat content of 4%, would receive an average income of $7,500 annually. To that figure must be added the value of his vealers. The young stock would be retained and the mature stock would be sold. Assuming a return of $2,500 from vealers, the total income would be $10,000, which is not too bad as an average. Running expenses must be deducted. The cost of superphosphate, wages, interest on capital, repairs and so on would be about $4,000, leaving an annual profit of about $6,000. Considered in the terms put forward by Senator Prowse, that indicates that the industry is in a pretty good way.

speech.para: I turn now to figures resulting from a survey by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics. I find the situation shown by these figures very difficult to understand in view of the statements that have been made about the efficiency and financial standing of the industry. According to the Bureau dairy farmers in Western Australia have the lowest average income. After paying expenses they are each left with an average income of $1,700, or $34 a week. I defy any honourable senator to tell me that that is a just return for a man who is working his insides out from early morning to late at night. I know what it is like to be called out on a cold winter night because my bull has got into my neighbour's paddock. I have had to go and drag it out, and I did not get overtime for that task.

talk.start.para: - Why drag it out?

- A farmer who is interested in his property tries to keep on good terms with the farmer next door. That is why he will go along and drag out his bull from a neighbour's property in the middle of the night, lt cannot truly be said that that situation arises because of bad fences. I had a six-strand barbed wire fence, but I could not keep my bull on my property and my neighbour could not keep his bull on his property.
- They say that a change is as good as a holiday.

- I gather that the honourable senator is implying that I should have kept my neighbour's bull and that he should have kept mine, and then they would not have broken out. I have explained to the Senate my calculations showing how an average dairy farmer in Western Australia on the figures quoted by Senator Benn should make an annual profit of about $6,000 after meeting all his expenses, including repairs. The Bureau of Agricultural Economics has stated that the average annual return of a dairy farmer in Western Australia is $1,700.

speech.para: The Government has promised that it will look at the situation of marginal dairy farms within the next twelve months. This point has been hammered in various way by the Opposition and it is referred to in the Minister's second reading speech. I claim that there are marginal farms not only in Western Australia but throughout Australia, even in lush Tasmania. I hope that the Government honours its promise and will submit a proposition on marginal dairy farms to Parliament within twelve months.

talk.start.para: - Would the honourable senator think that there is any primary, secondary or retail industry that is not open to criticism as inefficient?

- I am not arguing about the other industries. At the moment I am considering what should be done for the dairying industry, and I think it is an important matter. I believe that the dairying industry has a tremendous contribution to make to the world. I am not saying that its methods cannot be improved. I believe that they can, but under present conditions dairy farmers in the lower income bracket are unable to increase the quality of their herds or carry out necessary pasture improvements. About half the pastures used in Australia for dairying are not suitable for that purpose throughout the year. A balanced pasture is essential. It is not simply a matter of sowing clover or paspalum. It is necessary to strike a proper balance. Under the subsidy scheme dairy farmers should be provided with the means of sowing balanced pastures. I am not speaking against the subsidy, but unfortunately it is going largely to the wealthy producers who do not need it, because their properties are already developed to the highest level.
- Could they be subjected to a means test?

- That might be possible, but I am not suggesting it. I do not have a proper opportunity to suggest it. I think an inquiry should be conducted by the Government and a plan put to the Parliament. If the Government does not put forward a plan in the next twelve months, as it has promised to do, I believe that it would be our place to come forward with one. We would have plenty of opportunities to indicate ways in which the industry could be improved. It would be our place to do that then, but not at this moment.

speech.para: At the present time we are not arguing anything more than that this Bill should be carried and that there is need for a sympathetic inquiry into the problems of the marginal producers. In view of the fact that the world needs milk, the fact that the industry does not want to be closed up and the fact that it is decentralised, as almost everybody who has spoken has said, it is important and reasonable that we should do all we can to see that the industry is put on a better basis. I believe that that could be done. I hope that the Government will come forward in twelve months with a plan that will do that.

talk.start.para: - in reply - I think there have been eleven speakers on this Bill. I regret that I was unable to be present throughout the debate. Duties took me away from the Senate last Thursday evening. I am sure that the debate has brought forward much information which could be useful and instructive to many people who have not really understood the position of the dairy farmers over the years. Some dairy farmers have been in dire straits - I use that phrase deliberately - for quite a number of years. One point which I wish to emphasise and which I mentioned in the second reading speech is this: the fact that the dairy farmers receive the returns that they do receive through the operation of the bounty means that the prices of butter and cheese paid by the Australian consumers can be held down to levels which otherwise would not be possible. The dividends from the provision of the bounty can be seen clearly in increased production, improved productivity and increased foreign exchange earnings from the export sales of our dairy products in the face of the keen competition that exists in the international trading of these products.

speech.para: Quite a deal of stress has been placed on the importance of the decentralisation measures brought about by the dairy industry, lt is true that it brings about decentralisation. The number of people engaged in the industry and the total amount earned by it have been mentioned. Mention has been made of the fact that the amount of the subsidy has been static over the years in spite of cost rises. Because there has been some criticism of that, 1 remind honourable senators that the amount of $27m, which is mentioned in the Bill, is the amount that the dairy farmers have considered to be reasonable. Honourable senators have pointed out that production has increased. This redounds to the credit of the dairy farmers. Although I have no experience of dairy farming, I have always been very sympathetic towards the industry because it involves very hard work and very long hours on the part of most of the people engaged in it. I get a little hot under the collar when I hear people who should know better, and who could know better if they took a little interest and educated themselves in the position of the industry, criticising dairy farmers for being inefficent and saying that, they should get out of the industry.

Mention has been made of the position of marginal dairy farmers. Their position depends on where their farm is, the area in which it is and the position of the farmers themselves. The number of cows or the number of acres for a particular property cannot be laid down. It would be very difficult to put down some hard and fast definition of a marginal area. We might say that generally a marginal dairy farm is regarded as being one which has high costs and low income and which obtains its return predominantly from the dairy enterprise but has insufficient output to provide the surplus needed for investment to increased productivity. That is probably as close as we can get to a definition of a marginal dairy farm.

Reference has been made to what will happen to the Australian dairy industry when the United Kingdom enters the European Common Market. This will mean quite a deal to Australia and even more to our sister country, New Zealand. We have obtained additional markets over the period since the United Kingdom first thought of entering the Common Market in 1962. I believe that we can take comfort from the fact that the Australian Government will take whatever measures and action it can take in respect of the Australian dairy industry and Australia generally to ensure that Australia's interests are protected. At this juncture none of us knows to what extent the actions and endeavours of the Government will be successful. The Australian dairy industry is well organised in the marketing of its products. For some years it has been very active in the diversification of its markets. Almost daily we see some expansion of the milk products industry of this country.

The question has been asked whether the bounty is actually received by the dairy farmer. I am told that the dairying subsidy audit section, which audits the books of every factory, does so at least once every year. That is a pretty efficient way of ensuring that the producers do receive the bounty that they are supposed to receive.

talk.start.para: - The bounty is so much per lb of butter, is it?

- I think it was Senator Ormonde, who has just interjected, who referred to dairy farmers and other people on the land eating margarine. I remember, as he probably does, that many years ago many people did not eat butter, but ate dripping - not because they preferred dripping to butter, but because it was cheaper. That is one of the reasons why margarine is being eaten today, even in the dairy industry.
- Nonsense!

- That is the honourable senator's opinion, but it is not mine. Why anybody would want to eat margarine when he could eat butter I would not know. There has been a conflict of opinion on the effects of butter and margarine on the human system. Doctors disagree on the effects. Two or three years ago it was popular to believe that butter was injurious to people who ate it. I think that belief has been disproved very largely. I understand that for some people, such as people suffering from blood pressure, margarine is more suitable than butter. Not being a medical man, 1 cannot say whether that is right or wrong. I believe that the majority of Australians, given the opportunity, will eat butter. 1 hope that they will continue to do so.

speech.para: I propose to be brief in replying to this debate, but honourable senators may be interested to know that over the whole milk sector of the industry the average net farm income is $3,000 a year. Twenty per cent of dairy farmers receive a net income of less than $1,000 a year; 30% between $1,000 and $1,999; 10% between $2,000 and $2,999; 10% between $3,000 and $3,999; 10% between $4,000 and $4,999, and 20% receive $5,000 per annum and over. I should think that in the main the dairy farmers of Victoria are more prosperous than those in any other State, and that perhaps the dairy farmers of Queensland and New South Wales, especially on the north coast of New South Wales outside the milk zone, receive the lower incomes. This is to be deplored. Senator Ormonde mentioned the constitution of the Milk Board in Sydney, which has done much good for the dairy farmers who dispose of their milk within the milk zone, but has not been so good to the farmers outside the zone. The solution apparently does not lie in allowing the farmers outside the Sydney milk zone to send their milk into the city, for that would mean a lower return for the farmers already within the milk zone. As I understand it, the dairy farmers inside the milk zone are confined mainly to producing milk, whereas the mcn outside the zone in many cases have sidelines, such as pigs, as well as being able to produce milk for butter. Despite this it seems that the New South Wales dairy farmers outside the milk zone believe that they should be included in it. The solution of this problem is not easy.

The intention of the Government has been made clear; that is, to try to do something for the alleviation of the conditions of people who are on farms that are too small, by amalgamating the smaller farms and thereby assisting the people who own the small farms to have a better chance of obtaining a reasonable return. That is to be commended. Nothing can be gained by the Government's deciding, as suggested by some people, that this should extend over a period of only one year. This period would be far too short, and it is the intention of the Government to carry out this experiment - and that is what il amounts to - over a longer period. 1 believe this can be well justified, and I hope that a speedy passage will be given to this measure in Committee.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.
