talk.start.para: - This Bill relates to the policy of tie Government to establish an Australian Tourist Commission for the purpose of encouraging visitors to Australia and travel in Australia by people from other countries. The Opposition does not propose to oppose the measure, but there are many facets of the legislation that could well be brought to the notice of the Senate when this most important matter is being discussed.

speech.para: The tourist industry is growing in importance throughout the Western world, and emphasis is being placed on improving the means of transport, air travel, communications, and the interchange of information in various countries by such mass media as television and films. In addition people have now come to realise that they are not confined to the countries in which they live. This has created a tremendous desire in the minds of many people to visit other countries and to see how the other half lives. National legislation on this subject whereby the whole of the efforts of government instrumentalities can be directed towards the co-ordination of tourist activities, is overdue in this country. It is interesting to know that each State in the Commonwealth has a highly developed tourist department and representation in the other States to encourage tourists to visit their respective States. In some parts of the Commonwealth the tourist industry is becoming the main income earner. We must give full recognition to the fact that when people are spending their money in this way, their money is widely shared in the community. A tourist has a certain amount of money to spend, but it creates a demand for transport from his place of residence, and for accommodation; this in turn gives a stimulus to the accommodation industry and leads to higher standards in motels, hotels and the other places that provide accommodation for tourists. There is an incentive for States to develop places of interest which have not been developed to a stage where they can be visited by numbers of tourists. There is a challenge to State instrumentalities and private persons to build up the standards of tourist resorts. 1 have the good fortune to live in a State that abounds in tourist attractions. Our climate is temperate. Many people do not realise that although Tasmania is a relatively small State the rainfall varies from 120 inches annually on one coast to 20 inches annually on another coast. Our mountains soar to a height of over 5,000 feet. We have reliable snow fields that can be used for three or four months of the year. We have a magnificent attraction in a plateau with thousands of small lakes and tarns. I could go on reciting the advantages of Tasmania as regards the attraction of tourists but it was not my intention to elaborate on these. I am very pleased that we shall probably have as our next speaker someone who will speak of the advantages of New South Wales in attracting tourists. We of the Opposition feel that the Commission, in co-ordinating tourist activities through the Commonwealth, can start a chain reaction which will be of advantage to Australia.

talk.start.para: - The measure which is receiving support from all around the chamber tonight is one which also has my support. It has, of course, the support of all honourable senators and, indeed, of the community at large. I am rather sorry that Senator O'Byrne did not develop his ideas a little further and go beyond Tasmania for I remind him that the Bill is, after all, for the establishment of a commission to attract visitors from overseas to Australia. I certainly hope that when they come to Australia they will go to Tasmania, because they will enjoy lots of things about Tasmania. But Australia is a very big place and there are many features and attractions to be seen, to be enjoyed, and to be understood, so that they provide people with not only a certain amount of pleasure during their holidays but also knowledge of this part of the world. So because the Government is establishing the Australian Tourist Commission and because it is receiving this kind of unanimous support it is clear that the matter of tourism - a word which has been very much overworked - has become a matter of national policy and national interest.

speech.para: The Bill is designed to promote travel and tourism. This Commission, I suggest, is the first step in promoting this kind of movement. Fairly obviously, in a world of great movement and travel the results are enormous while the possibilities of it are really quite phenomenal. I know it has been said in other words and in other ways but I think it would be a good idea for the record to observe that the benefits that flow from tourist activities are quite spectacular. A wide range of business and commercial interests stand to benefit. They go far beyond the airline, railway and other transportation interests, which are fairly obvious when we think about travel, and through them to all of the servicing industries. The accommodation and food services similarly expand their range of supporting agents, while the retailer, manufacturer, banker, insurance officer and the rest directly or indirectly benefit from this great and widespread movement. It goes without saying that employment meets a new demand which is of ultimate benefit.

So the Government is wise to seek its share of international tourism, which has been described in very many documents as being today the largest single item in foreign trade. In the last two decades there has been a phenomenal rise in world travel, both nationally and internationally. In the year before last the world tourist receipts reached $11.6 billion for international tourism and $43 billion for domestic tourism. Since 1961 international tourist movements have increased at an average of 12% a year. This Bill proclaims the Government's recognition of this fact and seeks to take advantage of it. Incidentally, I do not know that I like the word tourism'. I indicated that a moment ago. I am not sure that I like the word 'tourist', with its connotation of pleasure travel. It is granted that when we are talking of the tourist industry we are thinking in the main of people on holidays, people who are travelling for their pleasure, people who are travelling in circumstances that are, perhaps, rather more luxurious than those in which they normally travel. Nevertheless, I prefer reference to traveller, to travel and to the travel industry.

This Commission is being set up against a background of world travellers on the move for pleasure, for education or for business, travellers who are going somewhere to see something, to inspect something, to confer on some matter or to learn something. In today's world, travel starts in the early years of an individual. We live in a world of travel competitions, organised visits, escorted tours, and a score of arranged travel patterns. Travellers range from the camping hitch hiker to the millionaire in a luxury liner. There are student travellers. There are youn« farmers tours. I was very impressed with the exercise recently carried out by the Royal Commonwealth Society, which brought a group of young executives Iron England to Australia under a scheme which it called Operation Kangaroo. All these activities are part of the material and part of the great traffic which will be the working area of the Commission which is being established, lt takes up its duties in the midst of what has been described as the world travel explosion.

The internation! travel industry during the past twenty years has been gaining not only in numbers and percentages but also in stature and maturity. Almost every country, including some of the newly independent countries of Africa, has established some form of travel organisation in recent times. In a great many countries these organisations are under the control of or are initiated and directed by some form of government instrumentality the function ot which is to develop and promote the travel industry.

A recent tabulation showed that in sixty or more countries 522 overseas offices devoted to the promotion of travel are operating. The International Union of Travel Organisations has worked out that fifty-two government tourist organisations are spending at the rate of over $150m annually for travel promotion. It is true that a great part of this spending is directed to the American market but in addition great sums are being spent on travel promotion by airlines, hotel organisations and other related agencies. The United Nations is not without interest in this sort of world development. In 1963 it recommended what it called greater technical assistance for travel because of its importance in strengthening economic development policies of developing countries. This was underlined only eighteen months ago when a United Nations sub-committee in its conference on trade and development put out a. statement to this effect with the interesting title Committee on Invisibles and Financing.' It is apparent that there is not only a world wide movement but also a world wide interest.

In his second reading speech the Minister pays a tribute, as did Senator Morris and other honourable senators with whom I join, to the Australian National Travel Association. While we are proclaiming the wonder of this piece of legislation it is important to recount here that the Government's recognition of the importance of overseas travel is by no means new. As the Minister pointed out, the Australian National Travel Association, which is a voluntary body, has since 1929 undertaken in a splendid fashion the task of promoting tourism to Australia. In fact, the Government's decision to establish the Australian Tourist Commission has resulted from a proposal put forward by the Association. As most honourable senators know, the Association commissioned studies by two United States firms of consultants of the tourist situation in Australia and of the Australian tourist potential. I have been looking at the Association's very interesting report for 1965-66. Its graph covering the five years 1962 to 1966 inclusive gives a very illuminating account of the growth of the overseas visitor industry. The graph shows that earnings from overseas visitors in the five years have increased from S47m to $76m and that the number of visitors has increased from 132,000 to 210,000. The Association's budget has more than doubled.

It is interesting to consider the areas from which our overseas visitors have come. There have been a considerable number from Commonwealth countries with quite a body of movement from South Africa. From the Americas, during the twelve months period under review Canada sent nearly 4,000 visitors whereas the United States, as was to be expected, sent a much larger number than that - some 23,000. From the Asian continent, the group Ceylon, India and Pakistan sent just over 2,000 visitors, which incidentally was an increase of 6% over the previous year, and a similar number came from Hong Kong. Malaysia and Singapore sent over 5,000 visitors in the year. The United Kingdom and Ireland sent a total of 22,000 visitors and lesser numbers came from various European countries, making a total for the year of 173,000 visitors. Adding to this the number of cruise passengers who arrived In Australia we had a grand total of 192,000 visitors.

Succeeding pages are devoted to the Harris, Kerr, Forster report which has been very much the basis of the legislation before the Senate. Because this has been summarised in the speeches of honourable senators and in the Bill itself there is no need to develop it any further at this stage. It is already familiar to the Senate. However, while the Bill seeks to promote visits to Australia by people from other countries, the range of discussion surely is related also to movement and visits within Australia. I do not think it is unimportant to refer to that aspect.

Every State Government Tourist Bureau in its local efforts to promote travel within State borders is surely encouraging the kind of development which is planned in this Bill. Earlier today Senator Morris gave some statistics relating to Queensland. I should like to take a moment of the Senate's time to look at the position as it affects South Australia. I have some figures supplied by the South Australian Government Tourist Bureau for 1965. Estimated arrivals from various points of entry into South Australia, such as the upper Murray, the Western Australian border, the north east and the south east areas - those who come by air, road and rail- add up to a total of 627,000. As one would expect, the Tourist Bureau works on the basis of tourist days, or staying days. For the twelve months in question South Australia had a total of four million tourist days. In round figures the Bureau points out that this represents something like 627,000 visitors a year who are spending S28m on the basis of a daily expenditure of $7. This is interesting to a South Australian particularly when one sees from the Bureau's figures that in the previous year there were some 500.000 visitors who spent $101m.

The figures I have cited do not take into account all movement in South Australia because many people pass through the State into and out of the Northern Territory, which is a not inconsiderable tourist attraction today. I make the point that although South Australia has many good reasons why people should visit it, the State does not have such attractions as the Great Barrier Reef, a snowfield or some of the advantages of the more populous States. As I have said, the figures I have mentioned relate to South Australia. They surely must be multiplied many times for the whole of Australia. The movement of visitors creates both a local demand for travel services and a critical choice amongst the travelling community. I do not mean critical in terms of being unreasonable. Because people are able to travel they obtain a certain critical ability. This creates a better range of amenities not only for themselves but also for overseas travellers.

When the Commission is established and is devising ways and means of fulfilling its charter and discharging its stewardship, as outlined in the title of the Bill and in the Bill's clauses, we may well ask what it has to sell to induce people to come to Australia. Our various tourist attractions are well known and I do not think there is any point or value in taking the time of the Senate to mention any of them now. We know our main tourist attractions, but what does the tourist want? What does the overseas traveller want? No doubt this is a subject of debate and discussion. Recently in the United States an estimate was made of this kind of thing and it was revealed that a traveller spent 25% of his money on accommodation, 20.8% in shops, 17.8% in restaurants and another 17.8% on entertainment. 1 imagine that those percentages reflect the habits of most people who are on the move. It has been estimated by the Australian Hotels Association that by 1968 Australia will require almost another 3,000 first-class rooms to cater for travellers. With this emphasis on accommodation 1 have been very interested to study part of an account given to the national executive of the Australian Hotels Association following an international convention in the United States of America. The Australian representative, Mr Stewart, of Queensland, in giving an account of his visit to this international convention said:

quote.para: In particular relation to hotels 1 was able to give a good deal of guidance, and, among many other questions two in particular, recurred frequently and are worthy of special note. They were firstly that travel agents frequently had inquiries for comfortable accommodation at a price below our top echelon hotels, and secondly, many people wished to avoid staying at hotels which were replicas of American hotels.

speech.para: This, I found in my recent movement across the world, is a point of view quite frequently expressed. Naturally, in a country so travel conscious and so hotel conscious as the United States, it follows that their great chains of magnificent hotels are finding their roots in many of the great cities and tourist centres of the world. To people who have to travel for business it is probably a matter of very great convenience for them to move from one to the other of a particular chain of hotels. But it is interesting that people interested in the travel industry have drawn attention to the fact that many people wish to avoid staying at hotels which are simply replicas of the big hotels at home. Mr Stewart pointed out that the latter group were not particularly price conscious but wished to stay in hotels which for them had a foreign atmosphere. One hopes that no Australian hotel, whatever one's experience might have been, would provide a foreign atmosphere as we understand the word 'foreign'; but the point these particular people were emphasising was that they were anxious to be in a position where they could meet Australian fellow guests.

I suppose none of us goes very far before running across somebody who draws attention to a list of things wrong with Australian factors that are deterrents to tourism and it is interesting that the consensus of travel agents was that factors that were quoted as deterrents to tourism in Australia were not, in their view, deterrents. They said that basically the tourist wished to see the country as it is. They said, for instance, that the often condemned liquor laws were not considered to be a deterrent because the liquor laws in the United States vary more from State to State than they do in Australia. It is interesting to have these observations on hotels from an international conference in view of the fact that tourists spend a considerable portion ot their money on accommodation. I suggest that in what I might call our 'high powered search for comfort' for our travellers we should not loose our identity. I do not ..uggest over emphasis on whatever you or 1 may consider to be our Australian identity. We all have our opinion of the Australian identity. I suggest there are ways and means by which the traveller can be encouraged to come to this country and enjoy, shall I say, the comforts, conveniences and facilities for him to be able to move and speak without at the same time experiencing just replicas of any other country.

I want to take this a little further by suggesting that it is our duty to seek out ways and means of encouraging opportunities for the visitor to meet our own people as individuals either in our homes or in places of entertainment. In a further study of a magazine which is interested in world travel, I find reference to the fact that countries which develop what they call home host schemes' are amongst those with the best record for providing visitor satisfaction. There is no better way to make a p." -.on feel that his trip has been worth while than to enable him to establish a per on to person contact in the country he is \ siting. This is what he will remember and he will look forward to the time when he can reciprocate.

May I take this a little further by underlining a point of view that was put by Mr Basil Atkinson of the Australian National Travel Association to whom reference was made earlier in the debate? When he was speaking on one occasion, he made the point that to develop true understanding between peoples we must find the means to speak a language understandable to all. The need to adopt a new approach to languages was clear when it was considered in the light of the relationship between the mushrooming of the world population on the one hand and the number of international travellers on the other, ft has been reliably forecast that in ten years the number of international tourists could reach 250 million, which would be 51% of the world's population. Might I paraphrase that by observing that we may expect the tourist explosion to outboom the population explosion? Relate this, if you will, to the problem of languages and it will be readily seen that with so many more people moving round the earth trying to understand and to make themselves understood it becomes imperative that some thought should be given to this.

talk.start.para: - What about Esperanto?

- Yes. the question of Esperanto has been raised in this place, but there does not seem to be a great deal of enthusiasm for it. Languages are a matter of very great importance so far as communications are concerned. The world of immigration is not unrelated to the world of travel because, as most honourable senators know, the Department of Immigration is the very Department that facilitates our movement, that sees to the provision of our visas and passports so that we may have access to other countries. Similar departments do these things in other places.

speech.para: In its other spheres of activity, the Department deals with many tens of thousands of travellers who come into this country under other auspices and for other reasons altogether, but at the same time, questions of language and communication loom large. I do not suppose many of us who are able to speak only English would be prepared or indeed would have the time to study a second language.

talk.start.para: - Most of us can speak bad language.

- That may be so. It may be that if we encourage some other people to embark upon a study of some other language or languages so that with this vast movement of people which, according to all statistics, research and forecasts, is going to increase across our country, we would probably be providing one of the greatest encouragements for people to come to Australia. They would be encouraged by the knowledge they would be able to communicate with us. As there were further movements, so would we be able to join in a total programme.

speech.para: In conclusion, the Commission around which this legislation revolves is not only concerned with the promotion of tourism and travel to Australia. It is involved, also, in the total philosophy of world wide movement that is going on now and which will increase very rapidly in the future. The Commission will be the main instrument responsible for promoting an attractive travel image. It will have to be aware of the social implications of this work. I think all honourable senators will appreciate that the introduction into a comparatively small community of large numbers of people who may be of different standards and who may have different requirements could involve a number of social situations. There could even be social problems. I like to think that Australians are sufficiently sophisticated to meet changes and situations of this kind, but at least someone needs to be geared to it. The question of foreign relations and ils extension to human relations and public relations are tied up in the Commission's activities. The responsibility of the Government does not stop with the formation of the Commission. Many things will ultimately influence not only the pattern of travel but the consideration which the Commission gives to whatever comes before it. The length of the working week, the period of a paid vacation, the whole matter of long service leave, the arrangement of staggered holidays, foreign currency regulations and even customs regulations - all these things will influence the employment and attitude of the traveller. They will move with the attitude of the traveller who comes from abroad.

So, we have gone beyond the leisure stage, Wc have gone beyond the stage of travel for pleasure. We are a world of travellers for one reason or another. The Australian Government, in setting up the Australian Tourist Commission not only to encourage the promotion of visits but also to make such arrangements as are necessary and to work with travel agents and travel agencies, is endorsing what is already going on in the world and taking its place with the many authorities that are engaged in and looking after this kind of travel. If the opportunity arises, Mr President, I may say something in Committee on one or two matters that, are concerning me, but, in general terms, I wish to leave my contribution to the debate at that, I support the measure before the Senate.

talk.start.para: - Mr President,I wish to support the remarks of the previous speakers on this side of the House. I want to examine in some detail certain aspects of the second reading speech presented to this chamber by the Minister for Supply (Senator Henty) and to look at some of the problems that I feel we will encounter in this important Australian industry. First of all, the Minister stated:

quote.para: The purpose of this Bill is to establish an Australian Tourist Commission for the purpose of the encouragement of visits to Australia, and travel in Australia, by people from other countries.

speech.para: This seems to be the paramount intention of the Bill. The tourist industry itself is a very important industry. At the present time, it is capable of great expansion. The earnings from tourism for the financial year 1965-66 totalled at least $65m. Some sec tions of the income from the tourist industry are, for all practical purposes, hidden, and it is quite impossible to get the exact figures. However the stage has been reached where the tourist industry is now Australia's ninth most important source of foreign exchange. This fact was admitted by the Minister when presenting the Bill.

One of the largest organisations associated with tourism is the Australian National Travel Association. An examination of the figures reveals that since 1952-53 grants totalling almost $5m have been paid by the Government to ANTA. This total includes the grant allocated in 1966-67. which is $862,000. That is a large sum in anybody's language. We are advised by the Minister that a survey commissioned by this organisation and carried out by a group of United States consultants regarding the tourist situation in Australia and Australia's tourist potential produced the estimate that by 1975, not many years from now, the tourist industry will attract to this country more than 607,000 visitors.
The Minister in his second reading speech said:

quote.para: The Commission will be empowered to work with the industries servicing tourists, such as travel agents, transport operators and others--

speech.para: I wish to refer to this sentence in the Minister's speech in order to place it on record. I think that it is important to the aspects that 1 am developing in my contribution to this debate. The Minister says that the Commission will work with travel agents, transport operators and others - who, both in Australia and overseas, play a vital commercial role in stimulating an overseas visitors interest in coming to Australia and facilitating his visit by planning his tour, making the necessary travel and accommodation bookings for him and providing the whole range of services needed to ensure that the tourist is properly looked after.

As 1 develop my contribution to the debate, I want to point out that in addition to these people there are a number of Australian interstate tourists and others travelling intrastate who also need to be catered for. I hope that the terms of the activities of the Commission will be wide enough to encompass all aspects of the tourist industry.
The Minister went on to say:

quote.para: The Commission may produce magazines, pamphlets, brochures and other publications to further stimulate this interest.

speech.para: The Minister's speech continues:

quote.para: It may also produce sales aids for the travel agents and other industries concerned with attracting and servicing the tourists, so that these enterprises will not only be stimulated into selling Australia but will be assisted by informative literature spelling out the attractions Australia possesses-

speech.para: I mention these points because 1 wish to enlarge on them at a later stage. I will be quite critical regarding some of them.

A further matter is that there is indecision at the moment as to how much money the establishment of this Commission will cost the Australian taxpayer. I hope the Minister, in his reply to the debate will help the Senate with information on this point. I am not quibbling about the fact that we have to spend money in order to attract industries. This applies to not only the tourist industry but also other industries. But I think that this aspect of the Bill is rather vague. Let me quote the words of the Minister to emphasise my point. He said: lt is not possible, of course, at this early stage to indicate the finance which the Government may make available for the Commission's first year of operations, which for practical purposes will begin in July this year.
As I have already indicated, the allocation to the Australian National Travel Association in 1966-67 was $862,000.
The final reference to the Minister's speech that I wish to make is contained in the last two paragraphs. The Minister said:

quote.para: Just as important is the development of the many amenities, services and facilities inside Australia needed to ensure that the tourist is. effectively entered for during his visit. Massive capital investments will be needed from the industries concerned. 1 do .not underestimate the difficulties and problems which may be faced in mounting the efforts necessary to meet the expected demands. State governments also will be aware of this problem.

The Government hopes that its decisions in the overseas promotional field will stimulate equivalent decisions within Australia so that the total network of Commonwealth, State and private enterprise interests involved will work together to achieve the rich potential which Australia possesses in this field.

speech.para: Ithink that the last sentence is very important. Within the Australian tourist industry some great shortcomings indeed are to be found. Unfortunately, some sections of private enterprise are involved in the tourist industry purely with a profit motive. Now, in any established business the desire to make a profit is very important, but frequently in the tourist industry exploitation of the tourist takes place so that the profit margin is much greater than it should be. During certain seasons of the year - may I use the Australian term - the rake-off is much greater than it ought to be if the tourists are to be encouraged.

Timetables for major tourist bus lines - not all of them, but some of thom - are so light that the drivers cannot allow their passengers to have a really good look at points of interest while travelling from one part of the country to another. We should remember that overseas tourists make up a large proportion of the people who go on conducted bus tours. Only yesterday, a serious accident involving a tourist bus occurred in the Northern Territory. From time to time such accidents happen. Are they caused because the firms conducting these tours force their drivers to stick to timetables that are not within the bounds of safety on the very poor roads that exist in most of the Australian States? Only a few months ago I followed a tourist bus and witnessed certain incidents. Mr Acting Deputy President, I made a note of the name of the owner of the bus, of its registration number and of the date on which I made my observations. In 35 mile an hour zones it was quite common to see the bus travelling at speeds up to 50 miles an hour. The driver ignored traffic whether or not he had the right of way. Double lines seemed not to exist for him. At one stage, apparently in an endeavour to keep to an exacting timetable, he passed a large transport on a bad stretch of road. Partly by good driving but more by luck than anything else he was able to keep his bus on the road.

Road tours represent a big part of the tourist industry and most of them are conducted by private enterprise. If we are to attract tourists to our roads we must see that safety requirements are observed on all services. I mention these matters because I believe them to be very important. For every tourist who is killed in an accident involving a tourist vehicle another six will be frightened away from road services and will use other methods of moving about the country. Much the same thing applies to conducted air tours, particularly in small aircraft. Safety margins and proper timetables sometimes are not adhered to. If we are to develop a reputation as people who are able to look after tourists properly we must carefully watch this safety aspect, which is important. I hope that the proposed Australian Tourist Commission, in its examination of the problems associated with the tourist industry, will consider this problem of safety as well as other factors.

We also have the big problem, particularly in the coastal areas, of tourist monopolies, which in their conduct of tourist services look only for the greatest possible profit. 1 do not condemn the making of profits, but I suggest that tourists should not be treated like sheep and subjected to what may be described as mass handling methods while they are forced through in droves, the only considerations being the extraction of the last possible penny from them and the provision of the minimum possible service. I propose to describe the sort of thing that I have known to happen in two or three instances. The facts can be checked by anyone who wishes to do so. Near Cairns, off the north Queensland coast, there is a resort known as Green Island. The launch service and the facilities there are conducted by an organisation that services boats and provides ferry services and the like. This organisation has a virtual monopoly of tourist centres off the north Queensland coast from Magnetic Island north, not only in the transport of tourists but also in the servicing of the islands themselves.

Tickets for a visit to Green Island may be obtained at a number of places. Not many months ago, when I wanted to show a southern visitor the tourist attractions of the north, I arranged to purchase tickets for a visit to Green Island from an agency at Cairns. I was assured that the tickets would afford us all the available facilities. I particularly checked on this because I wished to make the most of the opportunity to show the southern visitor around so that he would go away impressed. We were not told by the travel agency, however, that lunch at the Island had to be taken in relays. We were told very abruptly when we went for lunch at a time when we thought it was available that our tickets were not sufficient to admit us for lunch and that we had to check at the counter and get a chit. This is the sort of thing that jars tourists. We finally got the chit and took it to the dining room only to be told that we would have to wait another hour for lunch because the large number of people wanting a meal could not be adequately catered for.

We decided to go to the lounge off the main bar for a drink. We found that we could not get ginger ale there but we were told that we could go to the shop where soft drinks were sold, buy some and take it to the lounge area to drink it. The tickets that we held entitled us to see a film that was to be shown in a special theatre on th; island. This was probably one of the most uncomfortable theatres that one could find anywhere in Australia. The film shown was lauded as being the only one of its kind in existence. If it was, thank God. One can see on television many films that show most of the things shown in the film that we saw at Green Island, though they may not be exactly the same. Contrary to what we had been told, our tickets did not admit us to the film and we had to pay 40c each to view it. After seeing it, we lined up for our lunch, very hungry and getting rather testy, only to find that the menu was limited to this or that. There was nothing beyond this and nothing beyond that. Only two courses were available.

I now come a little further south to Magnetic Island, the tropical isle. It is a very beautiful place indeed. Some of those on the island who cater for tourists are doing their very best for them, but others only try to exploit tourists. The Island is only a few miles from Townsville, just off the coast, but there is no night boat service from that city. Surely to goodness navigation rules can be relaxed - if they are the reason for the lack of a night boat service, though I doubt it - if we wish to attract overseas visitors. A night boat service would be convenient for the people living on the Island also, because they would then be able to attend late entertainments on the mainland. I do not condemn those who provide the present boat services. If local residents do not want a night service, that is fair enough for them. But tourists will want such a service and it ought to be provided for them. Indeed, it will have to be provided if we wish to attract them.

talk.start.para: - The same people who run the boat services conduct other facilities.

- Yes. This sort of thing is a particular problem in the tourist industry. One can find it repeated many times over in the coastal tourist areas. However, ali visitors from overseas do not want to look only at the beaches, though I suppose Australia's beaches are better than those to be found anywhere else. Many overseas tourists want to have a look at the outback and visit centres such as Bourke, in New South Wales, Mount Lyell, in Tasmania, and Mount lsa, in Queensland. They wish particularly to see the cattle and sheep country. 1 know from talking to them that they do not want to see only the bright lights on the coast. But what do we find when we get a few miles inland, as well as at many coastal centres? I can describe the situation in my own State best because I am most familiar with it. At places like Cloncurry some of the hotels do not yet have septic systems or sewerage, and one is forced to resort to the old earth closet located many yards from the hotel building. I do not criticise the hotel owners in general because I know that the ambition of most of them is to provide first rate facilities wherever they can. However, there is a minority of owners who are not interested in providing proper facilities. All they want is to take most of their money over the bar. They seek only a continual increase in their takings over the bar and they are not interested in providing accommodation of a standard that will attract tourists from either interstate or overseas. This Government and the banks are supposed to be interested in developing Australia. The banks ought to be able to provide credit for extensions of premises and for facilities that cannot be afforded by small companies or private individuals.

speech.para: In motels throughout Australia rates charged for accommodation are exorbitant. There are hardly any exceptions to this. In many, facilities are sub-standard and service is non-existent. Some overseas visitors are fairly affluent. Money is no real problem to them. They want to spend their money and have a good holiday, at the same time enjoying some measure of luxury if they can afford it. How many motels or, for that matter, hotels, throughout Australia have air conditioning? This might not worry anybody in Tasmania very much, but lack of air conditioning is a very great inconvenience. Air conditioning should be provided in places, for instance, north of the border between New South Wales and Queensland. It should be provided in Queensland, the Northern Territory, Western Australia and in some parts of South Australia and New South Wales. I suppose I can say that I have stayed in motels in probably all of the capital cities in Australia and in all of the major provincial cities in my own State. I have also stayed in motels in provincial cities in Tasmania, Victoria and, to a lesser degree, in New South Wales. Only about one in every ten has air conditioning. Again we find that many of the motels and a lot of the hotels north of the Tropic of Capricorn do not have a ceiling fan or a fan that will allow the air to circulate so that a reasonable degree of comfort can be obtained in order to sleep.

Heating apparatus is essential in the south. I know that my Tasmanian colleagues will appreciate this point. A couple of years ago 1 stayed in a hotel in Hobart which was supposed to be one of the better hotels in that city. I froze all night because there was no heating system in the room. I complained bitterly about this next morning and was told that if I had gone to the office and had asked for a radiator I could have got one. Why was not this part of the equipment in the room in the middle of winter? Another night I stayed at Kempsey in New South Wales. The same sort of thing happened. There was no heating whatsoever in the middle of winter, ft is cold enough in the autumn and in the spring without having to put up with this discomfort in the winter. How often does one find refrigeration in hotel or motel rooms? Of course some of the better hotels provide refrigeration in the rooms or provide room service. No motel in Australia, unless it is worked in conjunction with a hotel, provides any sort of room service. People who come to this country expect a better type of service because, as I said before, they are used to a more affluent standard of living than we are. Imagine putting these people in a hotel room in the north of Queensland in the middle of summer that had no air conditioning, no proper fan system and no refrigeration. Sometimes there will be a jug in the room. Apparently biscuits are a very expensive item because not even two biscuits are supplied. Sometimes there will be sugar but no tea. Sometimes there will be a packet of coffee that has been given away by some firm as a sample. I am not criticising all motels and hotels, but there are many which lack the facilities that encourage tourists.

In many instances when people go out to a function at night and they return to their hotel room - this does not apply so much to the larger hotels in the metropolitan areas, but it can be found in most hotels in country areas - they find that there are no facilities at night with which to make a cup of coffee or tea. During the past few days a number of people who have visited Canberra have stayed at one of the largest and newest motels in this city. I will tell honourable senators about a few of the things that have happened to these people. This motel is crowded with tourists. I am so disgusted with the service that has been provided to these people that I shall name the motel. It is the Deakin Motel. I know of one person who stayed there and who was supplied with three breakfasts in a single room yesterday morning. His colleague who was staying in the room next to him did not. get any breakfast at all. In addition, another person whom I know was booked into that motel for two nights. He did not get any breakfast on the first morning but because of the accommodation shortage in this city he did not complain. When he went to the office he was told thai he was no longer booked in for the following night.

There are a lot of people in Canberra at the moment who are attending a convention and a lot of them are slaying at this motel. Another instance concerned several people who ordered breakfast for 7 o'clock in the morning but at 8.30 a.m. it still had not been served. These people were going out and they were unable to get a meal. Whether these people were tourists or whether they were otherwise engaged, this is no way in which to encourage people to this city. I do not think this is good enough. We are trying to attract people from overseas to this country, but if they, receive this sort of treatment do we think that they will return? This does not apply only to this particular motel. There are a couple of other places in this city which provide similar service. The tourist industry is one of the best industries in Canberra. I must refer to another person who got marmalade for breakfast but no toast on which to spread it. He is saving the marmalade in the hope that the toast will turn up in a couple of days time.

As I said earlier, these conditions do not apply only to Canberra, Queensland and Victoria. They apply to the whole of Australia. We speak about encouraging tourists to this country. The Australian Tourist Commission has a tremendous job in front of it. I hope that it faces up to the realities of the situation. I want to refer now to the so called caravan parks which operate from one end of Australia to the other. In many instances, these parks are run with the minimum of facilities at the maximum overnight charge. Some of them are situated on the outskirts of town in mosquito ridden swamps. People hire out caravans. Some three or four years ago I remember staying in a caravan on the Diamond Coast of New South Wales. When the rains came water came into the caravan not only through the roof but also through the walls. We were paying approximately £8 per week for this caravan. It had a stove that could be filled with some sort of spirit, but probably the only way in which a person could light it was by putting Bundaberg rum into it because nothing else seemed to burn. The refrigerator operated at about half freezing rate. These are instances of which I have personal knowledge. There are many other instances in which people intend to stay for three or four days in order to see the local sights, but instead of doing so they are glad to get out next morning and camp by a creek somewhere because it is more comfortable.

I appeal to the Commission to look at the possibility of encouraging the Government to give financial aid in this regard. In this country we have some of the best scenery in the world. Some of it is unmatched in any other country. 1 refer in particular to our local scenery. If people want to drive to the top of Mount Kosciusko in the summer season they risk their lives and their motor car. There are no facilities anywhere along this road until one reaches the top of the mountain. When one reaches the top one sees a symbol there that has been battered by vandals and has never been repaired. There are no toilet facilities and no picnic facilities except at a couple of places which are situated on small creeks lower down the mountain.

Another outstanding example is the Mulligan Highway in north Queensland. One can reach the Mulligan Highway either through Mount Molloy going in from Mossman or through Mareeba. There is something like 250 miles of road, of which only about ten miles is bitumen - it might be a little longer than that. I might stand corrected on that particular mileage but there is a great deal of dirt road. There are many rocks sticking up on this road that will ruin motor car tyres.

We are trying to encourage people to go into this country to look at Australia and at some of the more primitive parts of this country, if we want to describe it that way. The Bloomfield Highway which runs down to the Bloomfield River is a complete exercise in road safety, lt is virtually impossible to negotiate the inclines and the creeks. Yet situated around this road is scenery that cannot be bettered anywhere in Australia. For the expenditure of a comparatively small sum of money, by way of a Commonwealth grant, this road could be carried through to Cairns. This would be one way in which we could attract people to this particular area of Australia where the scenery is absolutely fantastic. The Government could probably pay for the road as a result of the access made available to the worthwhile timber stands in this area.

Some twelve months ago in the middle of the tourist season I took a party of visitors to lunch at the local kiosk at Lake Barrine in my State. We waited an hour for service. I saw visitors from interstate and overseas drive away disgusted. The water in the lake was magnificent. The facilities provided at the lakeside by private enterprise were absolutely atrocious.

talk.start.para: - The visit would not be enjoyable on an empty stomach.

- It certainly would not. On that occasion and on other occasions I heard people say that they would not go there again unless they took their own sandwiches or hot pies. I am deeply critical of this sort of thing. While we talk about encouraging people to visit our tourist resorts we are actually discouraging them. The motel to which I have referred accommodated more disgruntled people in that few days than would be found in six other motels around the city. Is that encouraging tourists?

speech.para: I turn now to examine some of our transport facilities. In Queensland we have the air conditioned 'Sunlander' train. Other States have air conditioned trains, but tourists do not always travel by them. Often they are told in advance that the seats on those trains are booked out. So they board trains without air conditioning and travel under most primitive conditions. Trains which do not have meal facilities aboard pull up at stations with little refreshment rooms where travellers are served cold sausages that are probably cooked and recooked about sue times in a week to avoid throwing them away. A few pieces of crumbly, dry toast are served. The pies available were probably made two or three days before. Why cannot we have decent meal facilities available at railway stations where stops are made for meals? I appreciate that with today's high speed trains not so many stops are made for meals as were made a few years ago, but for heaven's sake improve the facilities at stations where meals are served so that people may be encouraged to revisit the areas.

I invite honourable senators now to study some of the people who make a quick quid at seaside resorts and other holiday places. At holiday times they put up their rentals beyond the means of people who wish to take their kiddies for two or three weeks holiday. Their prices are exorbitant and people are unable to pay them. But the advertisements still appear in the provincial newspapers saying: 'Come here. We have all the facilities.' Of course, when the visitors arrive they cannot find half of the advertised attractions. They get touched because of the rentals that are charged and must put up with primitive toilet facilities and living conditions, including broken down stoves and refrigerators. Yet according to the travel brochures the proprietors at holiday resorts are doing a magnificent job. I wish to criticise travel agencies; not all of them, but a minority. In many places they are not properly organised. The Queensland Tourist Bureau operates a fairly effective service in advertising holiday resorts and places to visit, but a minority of private travel agents do not do this job adequately. I am not criticising Senator Ian Wood. Some travel agents leave much to be desired.

This Bill provides for the establishment of the Australian Tourist Commission. This organisation should operate effectively. Let us improve our roads to places that tourists arc likely to visit. Let us improve the facilities at those places. Everyone has a role to play in this regard. The banks should provide loans for the construction of proper facilities. The people who run holiday resorts ought to take a more personal interest in people to see that the services for which visitors pay are in fact received by them. The Opposition wants to see massive grants by the Commonwealth Government for tourism, if they can be organised, so that roads, bridges, highways and other facilities can be improved. In Queensland, travellers by road at least have drinking water and fireplaces available to them. Toilets are provided; in many instances they are a bit primitive, but they are there. I have not seen provided in many other parts of Australia facilities equal to those provided in Queensland. In New South Wales fireplaces are provided but only in isolated instances is drinking water available. I am referring to areas away from the towns. State governments can play their part, through the provision of better facilities in encouraging people to travel.

I hope that my contribution to this debate will be noted by the Government and that the Commission not only fosters the tourist industry but also ensures that people who are currently being exploited get a fair go.

talk.start.para: - I ask for leave to make my remarks at a later stage.

speech.para: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

subdebate.1.para: That the Senate do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: - I wish to refer to an answer 1 received today from the Minister for Customs and Excise (Senator Anderson), who represents the Postmaster-General (Mr Hulme) in this chamber, to a question that I placed on the notice paper two or three weeks ago. My question concerned the fact that no longer does prominent journalist and well known television personality Miss Dita Cobb appear on the Australian Broadcasting Commission programme 'Let's Find Out'. Having studied the Minister's answer and knowing something of the facts of this case I believe that political influence on the part of somebody in the Government or fear of political pressure on the part of somebody in the ABC has brought about the decision that Miss Cobb is not to continue to be invited to appear as a guest artist on the programme. The Minister, or the Australian Broadcasting Commission in providing him with the answer, has attempted to cover up that situation.

speech.para: In his answer the Minister told me that Miss Cobb made forty appearances as a guest artist on the programme 'Let's Find Out'. The Minister stated that this radio programme is broadcast on five days a week and that the twenty-five people named in his answer were all engaged as guests for one programme at a time. Miss Cobb took part in this programme on forty different occasions, and it is well known that she appeared on a Tuesday morning at 9.30. The Minister has stated that the ABC changes the panel whenever it becomes desirable to inject fresh thoughts and points of view into the programme. I could understand that situation if a guest artist were not attracting adequate or proper ratings, but I think that if the Minister or the ABC checked the ratings for 'Let's Find Out' it would be found that for the last Tuesday on which Miss Cobb appeared the overall rating for the programme was an estimated 88,000 listeners. For the Monday it was 54,000 listeners; for the Wednesday, 44,000; for the Thursday, 78,000; and for the Friday, 60,000. So, on a comparison with any other day on which the programme was being broadcast-

talk.start.para: - Where did the honourable senator obtain those rating figures?

- They have been provided to me. I think the Minister could obtain them from the Australian Broadcasting Control Board or any other source from which they might be available to the Postmaster-General. On the ratings that have been supplied to me, if they are correct, the fact is that' Miss Cobb appeared on the programme on the Tuesday and on that day the ratings were better than those for any other comparable day.
- She would be more enjoyable than Andrea, would she not?

- I would tend to agree with the honourable senator. Despite what I have said, the Minister says that the ABC changes the panel whenever it becomes desirable io inject fresh thoughts and points of view into the programme. Yet suddenly, after forty appearances on the programme and notwithstanding the high rating to which I have referred, one of the guests on the panel is not asked to reappear. As can be seen from the Minister's answer, her last appearance was on 14th March.

speech.para: Frankly, I do not accept the reason stated by the Minister for her nonappearance because, in her capacity as a journalist as distinct from her capacity as a radio personality, on 6th March - eight days before she was not invited to reappear on the programme - in an article that she wrote in the Sydney 'Sun', she sent the ABC up. I do not agree for one moment' with what she wrote, but it was as follows:

quote.para: I hope we do get Utzon back. I think it is more than generous of him to want to forgive and forget. I have become very fond of that Opera House? Remember how I hated the idea of spending all that money on it when it was needed for so many other things? Well, driving across the bridge it looks so marvellous. I have succumbed to its beauty.

I only hope the ABC will see its way clear to drop the bit of almost blackmail it is perpetrating and let the big hall be used for more than just symphony concerts which after all only cater for a minority group.

Surely the ABC, who live on the taxes of the community, should not be so piddlingly one-sided. 1 think they are so heavily over-staffed that it is virtually impossible for them to ever be out of 8 muddle. I am sure more than half the people they employ are completely unnecessary. Commercial stations manage to do a pretty good job without all those managers and odds and sods.

Someone from the ABC once told me that, if all broadcasting and televising stopped today, half the staff would not even be aware of it. They would go on for ten years having their meetings, their cups of tea and their bits of cosiness. My, we must be an awfully rich country to bc able to afford to keep such luxuries going!

speech.para: I reiterate that 1 am not agreeing with what Miss Cobb said about the ABC. Generally speaking, 1 believe that it does a pretty good job, although there is ample room for improvement. Miss Cobb wrote that article on 6th March. To me it is very significant that her last appearance on the programme was on 14th March - a mere eight days after that article was written. [ say quite frankly that I would have much more respect for the Minister and for the Australian Broadcasting Commission, which provided the answer for the Minister, if he had openly said in his reply that Miss Cobb was no longer invited to appear on the programme because she had criticised the Commission in her newspaper article. The Minister gave the reason for her non-appearance as:

quote.para: The ABC changes the panel whenever it becomes desirable to inject fresh thoughts and points of view into the programme.

speech.para: This is really gilding the lily and is not a reason that will be swallowed' by the listening public. Frankly, it seems to me that Miss Cobb, in her article, was loo fresh for the ABC.

talk.start.para: - 1 want to point to anomalies in the navigation regulations that are now causing a dispute on a New Zealand ship, the 'Koromiko' It is at Port Osborne, which is adjacent to Port Adelaide in South Australia. The ship was loading gypsum at Thevenard on the west coast of South Aus.dia. The gypsum was loaded into the hold of the ship by a chute. The vessel was only half loaded and had to go to Port Adelaide to take on additional cargo consisting of motor car bodies. The gypsum had to be spread - this is termed trimming - to form a flat bottom so that the motor car bodies could be placed on top of it. If this had been done at the Thevenard wharf, as it should have been, members of the Waterside Workers Federation would have done the work at award rates of pay and would have observed the appropriate safety regulations. The regulations provide that an internal combustion engine cannot be used in the hold of a ship if explosives are stored there and that such an engine cannot be used in the hold unless sufficient ventilation is provided. Blowers are used to exhaust the fumes from the hold. Either the company or the ship's captain decided not to trim the gypsum at the wharf. The ship was taken out to sea with a bulldozer in the hold and a 44 gallon drum of petrol, which would be used by the bulldozer. The local owner of the bulldozer and his son of school age were employed on a sub-contract basts. The owner worked for thirty-six hours without a break. His son had to knock off at nine o'clock at night because he had to go to school at nine o'clock the next morning.

speech.para: The members of the crew of the Koromiko' decided at a meeting at Port Adelaide that they would not work on the ship unless the captain gave a guarantee that there would bc no further open hatches at seu and that the regulations would be observed. They decided that they would take the ship to New Zealand only on those conditions. The dispute caused the port authorities to inquire into the allegations. The company gave an assurance to the men that, if regulations had been broken, action would he taken immediately to ensure that they were not broken again.

talk.start.para: - Was this a New Zealand ship or an Australian ship?

- A New Zealand ship. The lives of members o. the crew were endangered. There was a possibility of fire and explosion on the ship. A written guarantee was given that any breach of regulations would be immediately rectified. The port authority who was investigating in South Australia on behalf of the Department of Shipping and Transport advised me that he would agree this practice was undesirable and dangerous, and that if there were a breach of regulations he would recommend prosecutions. However, he very much doubled whether there had been a breach of regulations insofar as the regulations refer to offences committed by the person in charge of the loading and unloading of a ship. He pointed out that he did not know how he could legally interpret that the ship was loading or unloading when it was at sea. although at all times it was in Australian territorial waters and therefore under the control and powers of the Australian Government. The point is that we have regulations that govern the loading and unloading of ships, but this new practice to provide for a cheaper method of labour supply, which involves taking the ship to sea to do certain of the trimming, seems to be outside the regulations. This has caused the dispute, which will continue until these guarantees are met.

speech.para: I ask the Minister to give urgent consideration to this matter. I found it necessary to mention it on the adjournment of the House because I could not expect the Minister at question time to give a reply off the cuff, and I realised that if I had put the question on the notice paper in the dying stages of the session it would be unlikely that 1 would get a reply. Obviously, as no-one could justify this action, which endangers the life and limb of people on this vessel, regulations should be promulgated to cover the circumstances. The crew and the appropriate union believe that a full coverage exists to prevent this practice if the ship were loading or unloading or if the trimming were taking place while the vessel was tied to a wharf, but they think that it cannot be classified as loading or unloading when the ship is at sea. I ask the Minister to give urgent consideration to this matter and. although 1 assume that this dispute will he over, action along the lines I suggest will prevent a recurrence.

talk.start.para: - It is interesting to note that Senator Cavanagh has brought forward this matter at such a late hour, especially in view of the fact that the loading of gypsum at South Australian ports for transport to New Zealand has been going on for some time. That is why I asked the honourable senator whether it was an Australian ship or a New Zealand ship. For some years it has been the practice when the loading is taking place from South Australian outports to take the ship to sea where the gypsum can be shaken down a bit. It is true that an internal combusion engine machine - to use the honourable senator's phrase - is shipped on board the vessel to trim the gypsum in order to get an even settlement of the cargo while the ship is at sea. It has been claimed, and I have no reason to doubt it, that this is the most effective method of getting an even trim.

speech.para: The machine used is an English product, known as a Ransome. It has a small bulldozer blade, similar to the ones used in gardens; it would not be two-thirds the size of Senator Cavanagh's desk. The ship moves from the outport to Port Adelaide. Then they trim the ship with the deep heavy-weighted cargo lying at the bottom of the hold. This is done not only to ensure that the ship is adequately trimmed but because the New Zealand waterside workers demand a specified distance between the top of the gypsum cargo and the underbeams. If this height is not available they refuse to unload the motor cars that have been loaded in South Australia. It seems to me to be most extraordinary that this caused an industrial dispute when this custom had been operating for some years on New Zealand ships operating from Port Adelaide to New Zealand. Suddenly after these events have become common practice an industrial dispute has emerged to tie up a ship. I do not see why the Commonwealth Navigation Act or the regulations under that Act should be applied in an Australian port to a matter that relates to a New Zealand ship. This is an illustration of a phony industrial demarcation dispute which is an attempt to overcome a practice which has been accepted by the crews of these ships in South Australian waters and by the Waterside Workers Federation for many years.

talk.start.para: - in reply - I will refer first to the last matter mentioned. All 1 can say is that I will immediately bring to the attention of the Minister for Shipping and Transport (Mr Freeth) the comments of Senator Cavanagh and the supplementary remarks by Senator Cormack which gave some background to the procedure referred to. If the Minister thinks a reply is required, I will endeavour to get it before the Senate rises for the recess.

speech.para: Senator McClellandcommented on a reply which I gave him today to question No. 154 on the notice paper. It seems to me that the honourable senator is making a judgment on the reply given by the Postmaster-General (Mr Hulme) about why Miss Dita Cobb was not retained on a programme called 'Let's Find Out'. I gather that he clearly suggests that this person wrote her own obituary for the Australian Broadcasting Commission because of something she said about the Opera House. I do not accept that as a reality. My impression of the answer given by the Postmaster-General was that it appeared to be perfectly simple and straight forward. No doubt it would have been supplied by the ABC to the Minister. Five questions were asked, and the first four answers were factual answers which named the people who appeared on the programme, mentioned the number of times Miss Cobb had appeared, and gave the date of her last performance on the programme. The final answer stated, with what I thought was sensible candour, that the Commission changes the panel whenever it considers it desirable to inject fresh points of view into the programme. I think that was a reasonable statement.

talk.start.para: - Did he question the truth of it?

- I do not think the truth of it could be questioned, because the statement that the Commission changes the panel obviously fits in with the other answers. I would not think there was anything sinister in that. It would not be the first time in history that a person has gone off a programme. In allt ypes of programmes people come on and go off, and the injection of new ideas and thoughts is a normal process of programming. I would not think for one moment that there was any suggestion that this person was taken off the programme because she committed the unpardonable sin of criticising her employers. I would not dream that this could happen.
- She was not an employee; she was a guest.

- She was an employee in the sense that she was on the programme. It is ridiculous to suggest that this should happen because of some comment about the Opera House. Goodness me, there are about two million people in Sydney and 1 suppose, every one has, at some time or other, made some kind of comment about the Opera House.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.
